PARKS ADVISORY COMMISSION




§ 32.001  PURPOSE AND INTENT.



   The Parks Advisory Commission shall assist in the development,
planning, maintenance and expansion of new and existing parks in the city.



(Ord. 526, passed 7-11-2006)



§ 32.002  MEMBERSHIP AND APPOINTMENTS.



   (A)   All Commission members shall be residents of the city for not
less than one year prior to appointment. Insofar as possible, members shall
have interest, background or education in the fields of architecture,
biology, education, environmentalism, geology, history, physical education,
preservation or other disciplines related to parks, or a demonstrated
commitment to parks and greenspace in the city.



   (B)   The Commission shall consist of not less than five members,
with two appointments by the Mayor, three appointments by the City Council
and two appointments by the Hamtramck School Board. The term of office of
each Commissioner shall be three years, with terms to begin July 1. Members
of the first Commission appointed after the adoption of this subchapter shall
be appointed as follows.



      (1)   Mayoral appointments.  One for two years and one for
three years.



      (2)   Council appointments.  One for one year, one for two
years and one for three years.



      (3)   Additional appointment.  One additional appointment may
be made by any city educational institution with a student enrollment
exceeding 4% of the total enrollment of all city schools as reported the
previous year.



   (C)   All appointments may include members of the appointing body
and shall be made within 30 days after the effective date of this subchapter.



(Ord. 526, passed 7-11-2006)



§ 32.003  OFFICERS.



   (A)   Within three weeks of appointment, Commissioners shall meet to
elect a chairperson, vice- chairperson and secretary.



   (B)   Thereafter, officers are to be elected annually in July.



(Ord. 526, passed 7-11-2006)



§ 32.004  MEETINGS.



   All meetings are to conform to the State Open Meetings Act. During its
first meeting, the Commission will establish a meeting time and schedule,
including one regular meeting per month.



(Ord. 526, passed 7-11-2006)



§ 32.005  QUORUM.



   The quorum shall be three appointed members. Any Commissioner shall
vacate his or her position on the Commission following two consecutive
absences, unless the absences are excused by a majority vote of those
Commissioners present when the absences are announced by the presiding
officer.



(Ord. 526, passed 7-11-2006)



§ 32.006  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   The Commission is to assist in planning for development,
maintenance and expansion of new and existing park lands and recreation
facilities in the city which conform to the City Charter, school district
by-laws and policies and state laws.



   (B)   This shall include, but not be limited to:



      (1)   Advising City Council, Mayor, and City Manager on
matters related to parks, park and recreation facilities and greenspaces
within the boundaries of the city, so that these lands and facilities are
preserved in a natural condition and conserved in accordance with an approved
management plan;



      (2)   Preparing and updating a master plan for park space and
greenspace, including specific plans for individual parks in the city;



      (3)   Making recommendations to the City Council, Mayor and
City Manager on the suitability or desirability of surplus real property to
be used as park land, recreation facilities and greenspaces;



      (4)   Formulating policies on the use of public parks and
greenspaces for approval by the City Council;



      (5)   Making recommendations to the City Council, Mayor and
City Manager for preparation of the annual operating and capital improvements
budgets for parks;



      (6)   Identifying grant and funding opportunities;



      (7)   Making recommendations to City Council, Mayor and City
Manager on designation of natural landmarks;



      (8)   Cooperating with other governmental agencies and civic
groups in the advancement of sound park planning and programming;



      (9)   Consulting with academic and professional organizations
in appropriate disciplines in making all recommendations;



      (10)   Delivering to the people of the city cultural, social
and physical programs presented at well maintained parks and parks and
recreation facilities; and



      (11)   Submitting to the City Council annually, on June 30, a
report of the Commission’s activities for the preceding year.



(Ord. 526, passed 7-11-2006)




YOUTH COUNCIL




§ 32.020  CREATION.



   The City Youth Council is hereby created. The Youth Council shall serve
in an advisory capacity to the City Council, Mayor and City Manager.



(Ord. 525, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 32.021  PURPOSE.



   The primary purpose of the Youth Council is for youth to actively
participate in matters concerning the community. The Youth Council is to
identify issues and concerns of the community’s youth and make
recommendations for projects and programs to address them for the betterment
of the community.



(Ord. 525, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 32.022  COMPOSITION; ELECTION OF MEMBERS; TERMS.



   (A)   Students at each private, charter school, public school or any
other type of school offering enrollment in grades nine, ten and/or 11 shall
elect one representative to the Youth Council from each of the grade levels
offered.



   (B)   The first election of the Youth Council shall be conducted by
a group independent of the city or any school, and shall be completed no
later than November 30, 2006. Thereafter, the Youth Council shall conduct its
own elections provided that the elections are completed by November 30 each
year.



   (C)   Members elected by the respective student bodies shall be
appointed by the City Council for terms of one year beginning on January 1.
Members may serve no more than two terms. The Mayor shall fill any vacancies
for the remainder of the term.



(Ord. 525, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 32.023  DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT; DUTIES.



   The City Manager shall appoint a Director with approval of City
Council. The City Manager shall prescribe the duties of the Director and set
the rate of compensation, if any.



(Ord. 525, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 32.024  ORGANIZATION; MEETINGS; RULES OF PROCEDURE; ACCOUNTS; QUORUM.



   (A)   Officers.  The Youth Council shall conduct election of a
president, vice-president and clerk from among its members. A member shall
not be eligible to serve more than two successive terms as president. The
president shall preside at all meetings and retain rights accorded to members
of Council.



   (B)   Meetings.  The Youth Council shall meet once a month in
Council chambers, City Hall and shall designate the time and date thereof.
The Youth Council may, from time to time, hold special meetings and have the
power to designate time, date and place of the meetings.



   (C)   Proceedings.  The Youth Council shall adopt by-laws and keep
record of proceedings. Proper accounts shall be kept of receipts and
expenditures in accordance with established city procedure. Meetings are open
to the public.



   (D)   Quorum.  A majority of members will constitute a quorum for
the transaction of business.



   (E)   Advisory boards.  The Youth Council may appoint nine
associate members to serve on advisory committees on matters as determined by
the Council. Associate members may serve for terms not to exceed one year and
must be under the age of 18. Associate members may be removed by a majority
vote of the Council meeting in quorum.



(Ord. 525, passed 6-27-2006)




ARTS AND CULTURE COMMISSION




§ 32.035  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ART, CIVIC.  Visual art pertaining to a person, place or event
relating to, sponsored by or belonging to a city or municipality.



   ART, PUBLIC.  One or more pieces of civic, visual or performance art
designed specifically for ownership by the public or display on property
owned by the public.



   ART, VISUAL.  The conscious production or arrangement of colors, forms
or other elements in a manner that affects the human senses in a graphic or
plastic medium.



   COMPETITION.  A process established by the Arts and Culture Commission
to review specific art work(s) for a specific site, for the purposes of
making a recommendation to the Arts and Culture Commission.



   JURY.  An ad hoc committee or individual appointed by the Arts and
Culture Commission to review specific art work(s) for the purposes of making
a recommendation to the Arts and Culture Commission.



   PERFORMANCE ART.  Works of art that create a situation and are
conducted for a duration determined by the artist and/or spectator.



   RULES OF PROCEDURE.  A written description of the Arts and Culture
Commission’s mission statement, objectives, organization of meetings,
membership, terms of service, procedure for the election of officers and
procedures for the review of public art work.



(Ord. 515, passed 6-13-2005)



§ 32.036  CREATED.



   There is hereby created an Arts and Culture Commission for the city.
The Arts and Culture Commission is a locally organized commission and is not
established by any enabling legislation of the state.



(Ord. 515, passed 6-13-2005)



§ 32.037  COMPOSITION AND TERMS OF MEMBERS.



   (A)   The Arts and Culture Commission shall be appointed by the City
Council and consists of the Community and Economic Development Director or
his or her designated representative(s) as nonvoting ex-officio members and
seven voting members.



   (B)   At least four members of the Arts and Culture Commission shall
be residents of the city. The remaining members and ex-officio members may or
may not be residents of the city.



   (C)   Insofar as possible, the members shall represent a major
cultural institution such as the Detroit Institute of Arts, a registered
architect of the state, an artist, an art historian and an art consultant.
Members of the Arts and Culture Commission may also be members of the
Historic District and Design Review Commission, the Beautification Commission
or the Planning Board.



   (D)   The initial members of the Arts and Culture Commission shall
be appointed for the following terms: two for one year, two for two years and
three for three years. Thereafter, all appointments, except to fill
vacancies, shall be for a term of three years.



(Ord. 515, passed 6-13-2005)



§ 32.038  VACANCIES.



   All appointments for the purpose of filling vacancies occurring
otherwise than by expiration of term of office, shall be for the remainder of
the term of office.



(Ord. 515, passed 6-13-2005)



§ 32.039  COMPENSATION.



   The members of the Arts and Culture Commission shall serve without
compensation.



(Ord. 515, passed 6-13-2005)



§ 32.040  ORGANIZATION AND ELECTION OF OFFICERS.



   (A)   The Arts and Culture Commission shall, from its appointed
members, annually elect a chairperson and vice-chairperson whose terms of
office shall be fixed by the Rules of Procedure of the Arts and Culture
Commission. The chairperson shall preside over the Arts and Culture
Commission and shall have the right to vote. The vice-chairperson shall, in
absence, or disability of the chairperson perform the duties of the
chairperson and shall have the right to vote. The City Manager or his or her
authorized representative shall act as secretary of the Arts and Culture
Commission, and maintain a record of all of its proceedings.



   (B)   The Arts and Culture Commission shall, at its first meeting
establish the Rules of Procedure for conducting its business.



(Ord. 515, passed 6-13-2005)



§ 32.041  MEETINGS AND QUORUM.



   (A)   The Arts and Culture Commission shall set a time and place for
a regular meeting which will be held at least four times annually and shall
determine the manner in which special meetings may noticed and held.



   (B)   All meetings of the Arts and Culture Commission shall be open
to the public. Any person or his or her duly constituted representative shall
be entitled to appear and be heard on any matter applicable to the business
at hand before the Arts and Culture Commission makes its recommendation to
the City Council.



   (C)   At least four members of the Arts and Culture Commission shall
constitute a quorum for the transaction of its business.



   (D)   The proceedings of each meeting of the Arts and Culture
Commission shall be recorded by the City Manager or his or her authorized
representative, acting as secretary.



(Ord. 515, passed 6-13-2005)



§ 32.042  ASSISTANCE.



   The Arts and Culture Commission may call upon the City Manager for
information and services from the various city departments as it may require.
The Arts and Culture Commission may recommend to the City Council the
securing of professional and consulting services as it may require, however,
no expenditures of funds shall be made or contracts entered into for
providing the services unless the same shall first be approved and authorized
by the City Council.



(Ord. 515, passed 6-13-2005)



§ 32.043  OBJECTIVES.



   The objectives of the Arts and Culture Commission are as follows:



   (A)   To enrich the city’s civic and cultural heritage, the Arts
and Culture Commission is established to provide a level of expertise and
objectivity to recommend to the City Council works of art to become the
property of or for display upon property owned by the city;



   (B)   To promote a rich, diverse and stimulating cultural
environment in order to enrich the lives of the city’s residents, business
owners, employees and visitors and to enhance the city’s image both
nationally and internationally;



   (C)   To establish an environment where differing points of view are
fostered, expected and celebrated by providing the opportunity for the
expression through the display of public art;



   (D)   To promote, sponsor and organize festivals, events, activities
and materials that celebrate the cultural diversity and traditions of the
various peoples of the city in order to enrich the lives of the city’s
residents, business owners, employees and visitors and to enhance the
city’s image both nationally and internationally;



   (E)   To offer assistance to promoters, event organizers, business
owners engaged in the arts in the city; and



   (F)   To seek grants and funding from all available sources in order
to enrich the lives of the city’s residents, business owners, employees and
visitors and to enhance the city’s image both nationally and
internationally.



(Ord. 515, passed 6-13-2005)



§ 32.044  DUTIES.



   (A)   The Arts and Culture Commission shall establish rules of
procedure to describe the Board’s mission statement, objectives,
organization of meetings, membership, terms of service, procedure for the
election of officers and procedures for the review of public art work.



   (B)   With the exception of art works to be placed in museums or art
galleries, the Arts and Culture Commission shall have the responsibility to
review all works of art to become the property of or placed upon property
owned by the city.



   (C)   The Arts and Culture Commission shall have the responsibility
to review publicly owned property for the purposes of consideration for the
display of public art. The Arts and Culture Commission shall recommend to the
City Council the establishment of general guidelines for site selection,
maintenance program(s) for ensuring the structural integrity and aesthetic
quality of the site and any work of art, including the removal of any work of
art.



   (D)   The Arts and Culture Commission shall have the responsibility
to pursue sources of public funding for arts and cultural education, design
competitions, special events and the like, that may be necessary to advance
the objectives of the Arts and Culture Commission. In fulfilling these
duties, the Arts and Culture Commission may seek assistance from city staff,
and others for the completion of applications for grants, scholarships and
other sources of public funding, including the administration of the funds.
The city may also accept private donations and gifts to advance the goals,
objectives and duties of the Arts and Culture Commission. The City Manager
shall be responsible for the administration of any funds, account or
endowments created to accept gifts or donations and to administer any
honorariums or other expenses incurred for the activities of the Arts and
Culture Commission including but not limited to juries and design
competitions.



   (E)   It shall also be the responsibility of the Arts and Culture
Commission to increase public awareness and promote education of the
importance of public art as an enrichment of the quality of life for the
residents, business owners, employees and visitors to the city.



   (F)   The Arts and Culture Commission shall prepare an annual report
of its activities, accomplishments and a description of how the Arts and
Culture Commission has attempted to achieve its objectives. This report shall
be presented to the City Council.



(Ord. 515, passed 6-13-2005)



§ 32.045  REVIEW OF PUBLIC ART.



   (A)   The Arts and Culture Commission, within its rules of procedure
shall establish its vision statement and processes for the review of public
art works. The Arts and Culture Commission may also appoint a jury or hold
design competitions for the selection and review of public art works.



   (B)   The Arts and Culture Commission shall make a recommendation
regarding the proposed public art work to the City Council. However, a
positive recommendation shall not be required to advance the proposed artwork
for review by the City Council.



   (C)   In the event that a display and/or installation of civic,
public or visual art is proposed on a site that is within the jurisdiction of
another board of this city, it shall be reviewed by and reported on by that
board before it is presented to the City Council.



(Ord. 515, passed 6-13-2005)



§ 32.046  SCOPE OF AUTHORITY.



   (A)   The Arts and Culture Commission may select and appoint a jury
or hold a competition for the review of any public art project as provided
for in. The jury or competition held for any public art project shall serve
the Arts and Culture Commission as an ad hoc committee for the duration of
the project only.



   (B)   The Arts and Culture Commission is a non-administrative board
serving to make recommendations to the City Council but may not assume any
legislative or administrative authority in the operation of any city
department or publicly owned property, except as specifically provided in
this subchapter.



(Ord. 515, passed 6-13-2005)




OFFICE OF COMMUNITY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT




§ 32.060  TITLE.



   This subchapter shall be known as the Community and Economic
Development Subchapter.



(Ord. 509, passed 2-14-2005)



§ 32.061  CREATION.



   The Office of Community and Economic Development shall be created to
seek and administer grants, promote the city in general, develop policies to
attract and retain businesses in the city, administer a façade improvement
program, serve as press secretary to the City Council and the city, represent
the city at conferences and programs, serve as liaison between municipal,
state and federal economic development officials, serve as liaison to the
downtown development authority, develop and maintain a city web site, and
perform any other duties as assigned by City Council by resolution. The
Office of Community and Economic Development shall serve as an advisor to
City Council on matters of community and economic development. The City
Manager may assign other duties and responsibilities to the Department as
necessary for the operation of the city.



(Ord. 509, passed 2-14-2005; Am. Ord. 530, passed 1-23-2006)



§ 32.062  COMMUNITY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT;
REQUIREMENTS; TERM OF OFFICE; POWER AND DUTIES.



   (A)   Appointment.



      (1)   The City Council shall appoint a Community and Economic
Development Director.



      (2)   The Community and Economic Development Department shall
be under the supervision of the Director of Community and Economic
Development, who shall be responsible for the preparation of a plan and
program for the orderly development of the city.



   (B)   Requirements.  No person may be considered for the position
that does not possess at least a four-year undergraduate degree in public
administration, marketing, architecture, historic preservation, advertising,
journalism, planning, business or related field.



   (C)   Term of office.  The City Council, through either a separate
policy or employment agreement, shall establish the term of this position as
well as salary and other conditions of employment.



   (D)   Power and duties.



      (1)   The Director shall be responsible for the preparation of
needed revisions and adjustments to the community plan, as determined by the
City Planning Commission and City Council.



      (2)   The Director shall be responsible for the preparation of
basic information and data required by other departments in connection with
the preparation or execution of any planning program.



(Ord. 509, passed 2-14-2005; Am. Ord. 530, passed 1-23-2006)




HUMAN RELATIONS COMMISSION




§ 32.075  PURPOSE.



   The Human Relations Commission is established to promote mutual
understanding and respect for multi-culturalism and diversity, advocate for
peace and justice and encourage tolerance and constructive communication in
order to develop a functional, safe and harmonious community. The Commission
will work to safeguard equal opportunity, overcome divisiveness, violence and
all forms of discrimination against people for reasons including nationality,
religion, race, class, physical and mental disability, gender, marital status
and sexual orientation.



(Ord. 507, passed 10-26-2004)



§ 32.076  COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENTS; TERMS; QUALIFICATIONS.



   (A)   Composition.  There is hereby created and established a
commission to be known as the Human Relations Commission consisting of 12
members.



   (B)   Advisory groups.  The Commissioners shall have the power to
select additional volunteers to various advisory groups as needed.



   (C)   Appointments.  Initially, after gathering suggestions from
the community at large, the Mayor and City Council shall each appoint six
Commissioners; two each for a term ending July 1, 2005, two each for a term
ending July 1, 2006 and two each for a term ending July 1, 2007. Each year on
July 1, the Mayor shall appoint one Commissioner, the City Council shall
appoint one Commissioner, and the Commission shall nominate at least five
candidates with one to be chosen by the Mayor and then one to be chosen by
the City Council. No approvals are necessary.



   (D)   Terms.  Initially, four Commissioners shall be appointed for
a term ending July 1, 2005; four Commissioners shall be appointed for a term
ending July 1, 2006; and four Commissioners shall be appointed for a term
ending July 1, 2007. Each year on July 1, four Commissioners shall be
appointed for three-year terms.



   (E)   Qualifications.  The members of the Human Relations
Commission, as nearly as possible, shall be representative of the various
racial, religious, national, cultural, labor, business and ethnic groups of
the city. They should support the purpose of this subchapter. Membership
shall not be limited to residents of the city, but appointments may be made
from the entire local community.



(Ord. 507, passed 10-26-2004)



§ 32.077  OFFICERS; RULES; REMOVAL; REPLACEMENT; QUORUM.



   (A)   Officers.  The Commission shall designate one of its members
as chairperson, secretary and other essential officers.



   (B)   Rules.  The Commission shall adopt rules and regulations
governing its meetings and procedures.



   (C)   Removal.  Upon written recommendation by the Commission, the
Mayor may remove a Commissioner for reasons consistent with the rules and
regulations of the Commission, with approval by the City Council.



   (D)   Replacement.  In the event of death, resignation or other
termination of membership, the authority who appointed that Commissioner
shall appoint a successor for the balance of the unexpired term.



   (E)   Quorum.  Shall be defined as six Commissioners.



(Ord. 507, passed 10-26-2004; Am. Ord. 527, passed 10-10-2006)



§ 32.078  COMPENSATION.



   The members of the Human Relations Commission shall serve without
compensation, but subject to approval of the Mayor and City Council and
within the amounts as appropriated by the city, shall be reimbursed for
expenses actually and necessarily incurred in connection with their duties as
members of the Commission.



(Ord. 507, passed 10-26-2004)



§ 32.079  OFFICE SPACE; SUPPLIES; CLERICAL HELP.



   The City Council shall make available to the Human Relations
Commission, when possible, the necessary accommodations or office space
required for the performance of its functions, and shall provide reasonable
supplies and clerical and secretarial help for the chairperson and for the
Commission.



(Ord. 507, passed 10-26-2004)



§ 32.080  DUTIES.



   In order to achieve the purpose set forth in § 32.075, the Human
Relations Commission shall:



   (A)   Promote mutual understanding and respect among all residents
of the community;



   (B)   Discourage and prevent by persuasion, prejudice, intolerance
and discriminatory practices against any individual or group;



   (C)   Disseminate information and educational materials consistent
with the purpose of this subchapter;



   (D)   Investigate, collect data and study complaints and problems
arising between groups or individuals which result or may result in tensions,
discrimination or prejudice in the city;



   (E)   Provide conciliation and mediation services as a means to
resolve complaints. May request the City Attorney to issue subpoenas for
information relevant to ongoing investigations;



   (F)   Formulate educational programs and campaign to assist various
groups and agencies in the community;



   (G)   Coordinate programs with schools that promote mutual
understanding and respect in the school system;



   (H)   Cooperate with city, state, federal and other governmental or
private agencies in the promotion of better human relations;



   (I)   Prepare and submit reports to the Mayor and the City Council
of its activities, making at least one complete report annually by January 1,
and any other reports and recommendations requested by Mayor or City Council;



   (J)   Review employment practices and hiring procedures and make
recommendations to the Mayor and City Council on ways to ensure a diversified
work force;



   (K)   Adopt, promulgate, amend and rescind suitable rules and
procedures to carry out the provisions of this subchapter; and



   (L)   Review the dissemination of important city information, voting
materials and other information critical to the health and welfare of the
residents of the city, in languages other than English, and make
recommendations to the city.



(Ord. 507, passed 10-26-2004)




HISTORICAL COMMISSION




§ 32.095  TITLE.



   This subchapter shall be known and may be cited as the City Historical
Commission Subchapter.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)



§ 32.096  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CITY.  The City of Hamtramck.



   COMMISSION.  The Historical Commission as herein created.



   COUNCIL.  The City Council of the City of Hamtramck.



   SHALL.  Always mandatory and not merely directory.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)



§ 32.097  PURPOSE.



   This subchapter is enacted for the purpose of establishing an
Historical Commission in the city to identify, assemble, collect and preserve
objects, material, writings, buildings and sites relating to the history and
culture of the city and its citizens, both past and present; and to assist
the State Historical Commission in carrying out its powers and duties under
Public Act 271 of 1913, being M.C.L.A. §§ 399.1 through 399.10, as amended.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)



§ 32.098  CREATION.



   A City Historical Commission consisting of seven members is hereby
created and established in and for the city.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)



§ 32.099  APPOINTMENTS TO COMMISSION.



   Five members of the Commission shall be appointed by the Council, and
two members of the Commission shall be appointed by the Mayor within 30 days
after the effective date of this subchapter. As far as possible, the members
of the Commission shall have interest, background or education in issues
relating to city history, historic preservation and community development. As
far as possible, the members of the Commission shall reflect the broad
ethnic, racial and religious diversity that exists in the city.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)



§ 32.100  TERM OF OFFICE.



   The term of office of the members of the Commission shall be three
years. Members of the first Commission shall be appointed for the terms of
two Council-appointed members for one year, two Mayor-appointed members for
two years, and three Council-appointed members for three years, respectively.
Annually thereafter, the number of members whose terms expire shall be
appointed for a term of three years.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)



§ 32.101  RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT.



   All members of the Commission shall be residents of the city.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)



§ 32.102  COMPENSATION.



   Compensation of the members of the Commission, if any, shall be
established by Council resolution in accordance with the provisions of the
relevant portions of the City Charter.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)



§ 32.103  VACANCIES.



   (A)   The office of any member shall become vacant upon the
occurrence of one or more of the following events before the expiration of
the term of office:



      (1)   For any reason specified by state law creating a vacancy
in public office;



      (2)   When a member shall miss two consecutive regular
meetings of the Commission, unless the absence, shall be excused by the
Commission and the reason therefore entered in the proceedings of the
Commission; or



      (3)   Upon written resignation being filed with the secretary
of the Commission.



   (B)   The Council may fill any vacancy occurring on the Commission
for any reason cited above. Any vacancy shall be filed by the Council for the
remainder of the unexpired term.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)



§ 32.104  REMOVAL.



   The Council may remove members of the Commission for misfeasance,
malfeasance or nonfeasance in office.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)



§ 32.105  ORGANIZATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF COMMISSION.



   (A)   Organization.  Within 30 days after their appointment, the
members of the Commission shall meet in a regular session at the City Hall
and elect from their members a chairperson, a vice-chairperson and a
secretary. Officers shall be elected annually thereafter. The Commission
shall adopt its own rules of procedure subject to provisions of the City
Charter. The Commission shall conform to all the rules and regulations
provided by the City Charter that are applicable to all other boards and
commissions.



   (B)   Meetings.  The Commission shall hold at least six regular
public meetings each year, every other month beginning in January, on a date
and at a time and place as may be established by resolution of the
Commission. The Commission shall meet in a public building within the city
limits, unless authorized by the Council to meet at another location.



   (C)   Special meetings.  Special meetings may be called by the
secretary on the written request of the chairperson or any three members of
the Commission on at least two days notice.



   (D)   Quorum.  Four members of the Commission shall constitute a
quorum for the transaction of business.



   (E)   Voting.  A simple majority vote of the members of the body
present shall be sufficient to pass any resolution at a meeting at which a
quorum is present.



   (F)   Offices.  The City Council shall provide for the offices of
the Commission at a suitable location in City Hall or another public building
in the city.



   (G)   Records.  The Commission shall keep a written or printed
record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which
record shall be public and property of the city.



   (H)   Expenditures.  All expenditures of the Commission, exclusive
of the expenditure of gifts as described in § 32.107(J), shall be within the
amount appropriated by the City Council.



   (I)   Employees.  Any personnel employed by the Commission shall be
subject to civil service and part of the classified civil service, except for
any personnel that have supervisory power over other classified civil service
personnel.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)



§ 32.106  COMMISSION PUBLICATIONS.



   The secretary of the Commission shall be the custodian of the
publications of the Commission, and shall distribute and/or exchange
publications with other municipalities, governments and institutions under
the rules and regulations as shall be established by the Commission. Copies
of any of the above items or other materials of the Commission may be sold by
the secretary at prices to be fixed by the Commission to the public at large.
The money arising from the sales and from certified copies of documents shall
be placed in the Historical Fund.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)



§ 32.107  POWERS AND DUTIES OF COMMISSION.



   The Commission shall have the following powers and duties to be
exercised and performed in conformity with the City Charter and state
statutes.



   (A)   In general, it shall be the duty of the Commission to collect,
arrange, catalogue and preserve historical material including books,
pamphlets, maps, charts, manuscripts, papers, records and archives,
paintings, statuary and other objects and materials relating to the history
of the city; to procure and preserve narratives and oral histories of the
early residents of the city; to collect, prepare and display objects
indicative of the life, customs, dress and resources of the early residents
of this area; and to make available from time to time publications, source
materials and historical studies relative to and illustrative of the history
of the area.



   (B)   The Commission shall have power, and it is hereby made the
duty of all public officials to assist in the performance of this power, to
collect from the public offices in the city reproductions of any records,
files, documents, books and papers as are not in current use and which are,
in the opinion of the Commission, of historical value. The Commission shall
provide for the classification, arranging and indexing of the reproductions
so that they may be made available for the use of the public.



   (C)   The Commission shall cooperate with and assist the State
Historical Commission in carrying out its powers and duties as established by
of the Public Act 271 of 1913, being M.C.L.A. §§ 399.1 through 399.10, as
amended, and Public Act 10 of 1955, being M.C.L.A. §§ 399.151 et seq., as
amended.



   (D)   The Commission may recommend to the Council purchases of
historical material including books, pamphlets, maps, charts, manuscripts,
papers, copies of domestic and foreign records and archives, paintings,
statuary and other objects and material illustrative of and relating to the
history of the city; provided, however, that all purchases shall be
accomplished in accordance with the City Charter and applicable ordinances of
the city.



   (E)   The Commission may recommend to the Council the establishment
of Historical Districts throughout the city, in conformity with all relevant
local, state and federal laws.



   (F)   The Commission may receive any money appropriated to it by the
state and shall deposit same with the City Treasurer as provided in the City
Charter.



   (G)   Subject to the approval of the City Council, the Commission,
in the name of the city, may acquire and hold by purchase, lease, gift,
devise, bequest or otherwise any historical sites, buildings, landmarks or
properties which it may deem suitable or appropriate for carrying out the
objects, functions or purposes of the Commission. Furthermore, with approval
of the Council, the Commission may use any building or property for the
purpose of housing or displaying any part of its collection of objects or
documents therein. The Commission may locate and erect plaques or markers at
historic sites, buildings or properties in the city with the consent of the
owner or owners of any property and subject to approval of the Council. The
disposal of any real property or building shall be subject to approval of the
Council.



   (H)   (1)   The Commission shall make and submit to the Council
and to the Mayor an annual report of the general activities, operation and
condition of the Commission for the preceding year. This report shall
include, but not be limited to, an accounting of all accounts, funds, monies
and other property under the control of the Commission, the number and nature
of historical materials on hand, the number added by gift, purchase and
otherwise during the year and other statistical information and suggestions
as may be required by the City Council. This report shall be verified by
affidavit. This report shall be submitted by the first day of May of every
year.



      (2)   The Commission shall, from time to time, as the occasion
requires, either in the annual report, or at any time deemed necessary by the
Commission, advise the city in writing on all matters necessary and proper
for the operation of the Commission and any of its activities or properties.



   (I)   The Commission shall present to the Budget Board according to
provisions of the City Charter, a complete itemized budget for the ensuing
fiscal year.



   (J)   (1)   The Commission shall have the right to accept
donations of money or personal property or real estate for carrying out the
historical purposes as provided in this subchapter.



      (2)   Gifts of money shall be deposited in a special account
to be established by the Treasurer, upon resolution of the City Council
authorizing the establishment, from which disbursements shall be made as
provided in the Charter, in accordance with the terms of the instruments
making the gifts.



(Ord. 466, passed 4-30-1998)




CITY BEAUTIFICATION COMMISSION




§ 32.120  CREATION.



   There is hereby created and established a City Beautification
Commission for the city.



(Ord. 353, passed 3-28-1974)



§ 32.121  COMPOSITION.



   (A)   The City Beautification Commission shall consist of seven
members who shall be appointed by the Mayor in the same manner as other
appointed officials as hereinbefore set forth in the City Charter.



   (B)   Members of the Commission shall be appointed for terms as
follows: all terms of office shall commence May 1 and shall be for a period
of five years, except that initially, two Commissioners shall be appointed
for a term of five years; two for a term of four years; one for a term of
three years; one for a term of two years; and one for a term of one year and
thereafter as their respective terms expire.



   (C)   Vacancies on the Commission occurring before the expiration of
any term shall be reported by the Commission to the Mayor and filled by
appointment for the unexpired term.



   (D)   All members shall serve without compensation.



   (E)   No person shall be eligible for appointment who is the holder
of any city public office, elective or appointive.



   (F)   All members shall be qualified electors residing in the city.



   (G)   The Community and Economic Development Director shall serve as
a member ex-officio and shall have all the voting rights and other rights as
a member appointed by the Mayor.



(Ord. 353, passed 3-28-1974; Am. Ord. 514, passed 6-13-2005)



§ 32.122  CHAIRPERSON; BY-LAWS; MEETINGS.



   The City Beautification Commission shall immediately after appointment
meet and organize by the election of one of their members a chairperson and
by election of other officers as they deem necessary. They will adopt by-laws
for the orderly conduct of their meetings, and for proper process of their
functions. Meetings of the Commission will be held as often as may be deemed
necessary by a majority of the members of the Commission.



(Ord. 353, passed 3-28-1974)



§ 32.123  FUNCTION OF COMMISSION.



   The Commission shall have the following function: it shall be the duty
of the Commission to study, conceive, formulate, promulgate and develop plans
for the beautification of streets, highways, alleys, utility installations,
parks, streams, playgrounds, yards, lots and buildings; to study, investigate
and develop plans for improving the health, sanitation, safety and
cleanliness of the city; to foster the prevention of fires, diseases and
other public hazards; to encourage and recommend the placing, planting and
preservation of trees, flowers, plants, shrubbery and other objects of
ornamentation in the city; to collect, study and evaluate information on
community improvements and to make recommendations thereon; to sponsor, plan,
promote, coordinate and carry out the annual spring Clean-Up Paint-Up Fix-Up
campaign activities and to otherwise promote public interest in the general
improvement of the appearance of the city; provided, however, that nothing
herein shall be construed to abridge, invade, supplant or change the powers
or duties of the other commissions, departments, boards and agencies of the
city.



(Ord. 353, passed 3-28-1974)




HOUSING COMMISSION




§ 32.135  CREATION.



   Pursuant to Public Act 18 of 1933, being M.C.L.A. §§ 125.651 through
125.709e, as amended by Public Act 80 of 1935, being M.C.L.A. § 125.655,
Public Act 265 of 1937, being M.C.L.A. §§ 125.651 through 125.709e and
Public Act 5 of 1938, being M.C.L.A. §§ 125.651 through 125.709e, a
commission is hereby created in and for the city, to be known as the Housing
Commission.



(Ord. 173, passed 7-20-1939)



§ 32.136  APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS.



   The Mayor of the city is hereby directed to appoint the members of the
Housing Commission as soon as possible after this subchapter shall take
effect.



(Ord. 173, passed 7-20-1939)



§ 32.137  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The Housing Commission shall have all the powers and duties vested or
permitted to be vested in housing commissions by Public Act 18 of 1933, being
M.C.L.A. §§ 125.651 through 125.709e, as heretofore or hereafter amended,
and any laws heretofore or hereafter enacted which are supplemental thereto,
it being the intention of this subchapter to vest in the Housing Commission
all powers and duties permitted by law.



(Ord. 173, passed 7-20-1939)



§ 32.138  COMPOSITION AND COMPENSATION.



   (A)   The Housing Commission shall select and appoint employees as
it shall deem necessary for the proper exercise of its powers, functions and
duties.



   (B)   The Housing Commission shall pay the employees compensation as
it shall, with the approval of the Mayor, fix and determine.



(Ord. 173, passed 7-20-1939)



RECREATION COMMISSION



§ 32.150  CREATION.



   In accordance with the authority conferred by the provisions of Public
Act 156 of 1947, being M.C.L.A. §§ 2389 through 2392, inclusively, and with
the cooperation and consent of the Board of Education of the city, a
Recreation Commission is hereby created, which shall consist of seven
members. The City Council shall appoint three members, the Board of Education
of the school district of the city shall appoint three members and the
majority of the members so appointed shall appoint shall appoint one member
of the Recreation Commission of the city. At least one member appointed by
the City Council and one member appointed by the Board of Education shall be
citizens not holding public office or public employment in the city or in the
public school system in the city. A person to be appointed member of the
Commission by the other members in accordance with the foregoing provisions
of this subchapter shall be likewise a citizen not holding any public office
or employment in the city or in the public school system in the city and in
addition thereto shall be a member of the Chamber of Commerce, but shall not
be an officer or employee receiving salary or wages for services rendered for
the Chamber of Commerce.



(Ord. 207, passed 12-23-1947)



§ 32.151  APPOINTMENT.



   The initial appointment of the members of the Commission shall be for
the following terms in the manner hereinafter mentioned:  two members for a
term of one year, one of whom shall be appointed by the City Council and the
other by the Board of Education of the city; two members for a term of two
years, one of whom shall be appointed by the City Council and the other by
the Board of Education of the city; one member for a term of three years to
be appointed by the City Council; one member for a term of four years to be
appointed by the Board of Education; and one member for a term of five years
to be appointed by the member of the Recreation Commission. Thereafter all
subsequent appointments of any member of the Commission shall be for a term
of five years, providing further, that each member of the Commission shall
continue to hold his or her office or appointment until a successor has been
duly appointed. All appointments for the purpose of filling vacancies
occurring before the expiration of the term shall only be for the remainder
of the unexpired term and shall be filled by the appointing authority who
under the provision of this section was authorized and empowered to make the
appointment to the office or position in which the vacancy occurred.



(Ord. 207, passed 12-23-1947)



§ 32.152  COMPENSATION.



   Members of the Commission shall serve without compensation.



(Ord. 207, passed 12-23-1947)



§ 32.153  OATH.



   Every member of the Commission shall before entering upon the discharge
of the duties of his or her office and within ten days after receiving notice
of his or her appointment take and subscribe the oath of office prescribed by
the State Constitution and file the same duly certified by the officers
administering it in the office of the City Clerk and a copy thereof in the
office of the secretary of the Board of Education of the school district of
the city.



(Ord. 207, passed 12-23-1947)



§ 32.154  DUTIES.



   It shall be the duty of the Recreation Commission to operate a system
of public recreation suitable to the needs of the city by coordinating and/or
combining the separate departments of recreation maintained and conducted by
the city and the school district and to assume and exercise control and
supervision over all persons employed therein or any person connected with
any recreation work and heretofore employed by the city or the school
district, including to the extent deemed necessary the supervision and
maintenance of playgrounds, playfields, gymnasiums, bathing beaches, swimming
pools, indoor recreation centers, winter sports and any other place of public
recreation hereinbefore not specifically mentioned, and the Commission shall
have power to expend for this purpose any funds appropriated for recreation
by the City Council and the Board of Education, and any funds donated or
bequeathed for recreational purposes by private individuals or organization
or received from other legitimate sources. The Commission shall adopt and
maintain a system of bookkeeping and accounting of receipts and
disbursements. The Commission shall likewise keep a full, complete and
accurate record of all its proceedings.



(Ord. 207, passed 12-23-1947)



§ 32.155  OFFICERS.



   (A)   The members of the Recreation Commission shall elect their own
chairperson and select other necessary officers and shall appoint a Director
of Recreation and all other persons as it may deem necessary.  The Director
of Recreation shall be deemed to be in the unclassified service and shall be
under the sole jurisdiction of the Recreation Commission, who shall determine
his or her duties, compensation and tenure of office and who shall have the
right to enter into a written contract for his or her service. All other
employees of the Recreation Commission, except the members of the Commission,
shall be required to take a competitive examination to be conducted under the
supervision of the Hamtramck Civil Service Commission.



   (B)   Subject to the powers herein conferred upon the Recreation
Commission, all persons appointed by the Recreation Commission, except the
members of the Commission and the Director of Recreation, shall be governed
with respect to their appointment, classification of position, promotions,
transfers and removal in like manner as other municipal employees in the
classified service in accordance with the provisions of  9-19 of the City
Charter, and all the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder, unless
hereinafter otherwise determined by ordinance or resolution of the City
Council and the Board of Education, and no person so appointed by the
Recreation Commission, except persons appointed for seasonal employment, and
the Recreation Director, shall be subject to removal except upon cause and
proper charges to be determined at a public hearing before the Hamtramck
Civil Service Commission and in compliance in all other respects with the
procedure outlined in  9-19 of the City Charter.



   (C)   The Recreation Commission shall have the power to adopt rules
and regulations for the conduct of its own meetings and the operation of
recreation facilities not in conflict with the provisions of this subchapter,
and to adopt further rules and regulations governing their employees with
respect thereto, as the Recreation Commission may deem necessary.



   (D)   All employees of the Recreation Commission who at the time of
this subchapter shall take effect shall have been in the employ of the
Recreation Department whether maintained by the city or the school district
for more than one year, including also employees, who were on leave of
absence by reason of military service duly granted by proper authority, shall
hold their positions without examination until discharged, reduced, promoted
or transferred in accordance with the provisions of division (B) above. All
other employees of the Recreation Department who shall have been employed for
less than one year prior to the effective date of this subchapter shall be
required to the competitive examination.



   (E)   All persons permanently employed by the Recreation Commission
shall be included in and become a part of the pension plan and system
governing the permanent employees of the municipal government of the city,
and the cost of contributing to the city pension fund shall be borne equally
by the city and the school district, but that those permanent employees of
the Commission who shall qualify under the State Teachers’ Retirement
Pension Act, may elect to retain their rights under the Teachers’ Pension
System and may continue to contribute to the State Teachers’ Retirement
Fund and shall not be included in or become a part of the pension plan
governing the permanent employees of the city.



   (F)   The provisions of the foregoing divisions shall not be deemed
applicable to the tennis director or tennis recreation program, it being the
legislative intent of the City Council that the tennis director act and the
tennis recreation program be conducted independently from the provisions of
this subchapter.



(Ord. 207, passed 12-23-1947; Am. Ord. 207, passed 7- -1949; Am. Ord. 227,
passed 9-23-1952)



§ 32.156  REQUIRED FILINGS.



   (A)   On or before the first Monday in May of each year, the
Recreation Commission shall prepare and file with the City Controller and the
Board of the school district, or any officer authorized by the Board of
Education to prepare and tabulate its requirements of the budget, estimates
in detail of the expenses of operation and maintenance of recreational
facilities for the next fiscal year beginning in the first day of July
following and the City Budget Board together with the City Council and the
Board of Education of the school district shall appropriate in equal shares
the sums of money in the respective budgets of the city and school district
as they shall deem necessary. The Recreation Commission, however, shall not
commit the city and the school district, by contract or otherwise, to the
expenditure of any funds not officially authorized for recreation, nor shall
the Commission expend money or incur liability in excess of its budget
allowance or the amount of grant, gift, bequest or endowment received from
other sources, for recreational facilities, and any member violating the
forgoing provisions of this section shall be personally liable in an action
of law for the overdraft or overexpenditure brought by the city, or the
school district or by any taxpayer of the city, in addition thereto shall be
liable to removal by his or her appointing authority.



   (B)   The City Treasurer shall be custodian of all funds
appropriated or allocated for the use of the Recreation Commission and no
money shall be paid from the fund or funds by the City Treasurer, except in
pursuance of a resolution of the Recreation Commission and upon warrants
signed by the secretary of the Commission and countersigned by the City
Controller, City Clerk and City Treasurer.



   (C)   The city and the school district of the city shall conduct a
joint biennial audit of all the financial books of the Recreation Commission
through the City Controller and the Finance Director of the school district
of the city, or its deputies or duly delegated representatives from their
offices which the audit shall cover a period ending with the second fiscal
year in every two-year period.



(Ord. 207, passed 12-23-1947)



§ 32.157  REQUIRED REPORTS.



   On or before June 30, in each year the Recreation Commission shall
submit to the Mayor, City Council and the Board of Education a full and
complete report of its recreational activities, amounts received and
allocated for its purposes, amounts spent in connection therewith the
balance, if any, remaining at the end of the fiscal year.



(Ord. 207, passed 12-23-1947)

   33.999   Penalty




GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 33.001  QUALIFICATIONS; POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   For information concerning police officers, please see the
Charter for the city, Chapter 10, § 10-04.



   (B)   For information concerning the Chief of Police, please see the
Charter for the city, Chapter 9, § 9-16 and Chapter 10, § 10-03.



§ 33.002  WORK WEEK.



   Except as provided for herein or in any collective bargaining
agreement, the work week of all police officers shall be for each police
officer five days in every seven days, with two days off duty in each
seven-day period and two days leave of absence shall be in addition to a
furlough of 20 days in each year, of which at least ten days shall be
consecutive. Provided, however, that this shall not prohibit the Chief of
Police from suspending the leave of absence or furlough temporarily as a
matter of discipline for misconduct or dereliction of any police officer.
Provided, further, that this section shall not apply in case of an emergency
and the existence of an emergency shall be within the sole determination of
the Mayor.



(Ord. 257, passed 5-31-1960)



§ 33.003  POLICE DEPARTMENT; POLICE CHIEF; POWER AND DUTIES.



   (A)   The Police Department shall be headed by a Police Chief, who
shall be the commanding officer of the police force and be responsible for
the enforcement of law and order. All police officers shall have the right
and duty to arrest persons for any and all violations of the ordinances of
the city. The divisions of the Police Department and the responsibilities
thereof shall be set forth in departmental regulations.



   (B)   The City Manager may assign other duties and responsibilities
to the Police Department as necessary for the operation of the city; other
duties and responsibilities may be assigned to an existing division or
additional division as deemed necessary.



(Ord. 530, passed 1-23-2007)




DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY IN POSSESSION OF POLICE DEPARTMENT




§ 33.015  CUSTODY OF STOLEN, LOST OR ABANDONED PROPERTY; PROPERTY DEFINED.



   (A)   All property or money alleged or supposed to have been
feloniously or wrongfully obtained or which shall be lost or abandoned, and
which shall be thereafter taken into the custody of any member of the police
force or the police or District Court of the city, or which shall come into
custody shall be, by the member or lay order of the court, given into the
custody of the Chief of Police or his or her duly designated agent.



   (B)   The word PROPERTY as used in this subchapter shall not include
animals.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.016  RECORD OF STOLEN, LOST OR ABANDONED PROPERTY TO BE KEPT.



   All property and money shall be particularly registered by the Chief of
Police or his or her  duly designated agent in a book kept for that purpose,
which shall contain also a record of the names of the persons from whom the
property or money was taken, the names of all claimants thereto, the place
where found, the time of the seizure, the date of the receipt, the general
circumstances connected therewith, and any final disposal of the property and
money.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.017  RETURN OF PROPERTY BY CHIEF OF POLICE OR HIS OR HER DULY
DESIGNATED AGENT; TWO OR MORE CLAIMANTS; LIABILITY OF CHIEF OF POLICE OR HIS
OR HER DULY DESIGNATED AGENT; PROPERTY REQUIRED AS EVIDENCE.



   (A)   Upon satisfactory evidence of the ownership of property or
money described in § 33.015, the Chief of Police or his or her duly
designated agent shall deliver the same to the owner, his or her next of kin,
or legal representative, and to him, her, or them only. If in any case, it is
proven impracticable for the owner, next of kin,  or legal representative to
appear, the Chief of Police or his or her duly designated agent may deliver
the property or money to any person having a duly executed power of attorney
from the owner or his or her next of kin, or legal representative, upon the
filing of the power of attorney in the office of the Chief of Police or his
or her duly designated agent and the signing of a receipt for the property or
money.



   (B)   In the event two or more persons claim ownership of any
property or money, the Chief of Police or his or her duly designated agent
may give notice by registered mail to all claimants of whom he or she shall
have knowledge of the time and place of a hearing to determine the person to
whom the property or money shall be  delivered. At the time and place so
designated, the Chief of Police or his or her duly designated agent shall
hear and receive evidence of ownership of the property or money  concerned,
and shall determine the identity of the owner. After the hearing, the Chief
of Police or his or her duly designated agent shall deliver the property or
money to the person whom the Chief of Police or his or her duly designated
agent determines is the owner, his or her next of kin, or legal
representative, and to him, her, or them only. If, in any case, it is proven
impracticable for the owner, next of kin, or legal representative to appear,
the Chief of Police or his or her duly designated agent may deliver the
property or money to any person having a duly executed power of attorney from
the owner, his or her next of kin, or legal representative, upon the filing
of the power of attorney in the office of the Chief of Police or his or her
duly designated agent and the signing of a receipt for the property or money.



   (C)   The Chief of Police or his or her duly designated agent shall
not be liable in any official action performed hereunder in good faith.



   (D)   Except as provided in §§ 33.023, 33.024 and 33.025 hereof,
no property or money in the  possession of the Chief of Police or his or her
duly designated agent alleged to have been feloniously obtained or to be the
proceeds of crime shall be delivered under this section if it is required to
be held under the provisions of § 33.019 hereof; nor shall it be delivered
within one year after the date of receipt of the property or money by the
Chief of Police or his or her duly designated agent unless the property or
money is not needed as evidence in the prosecution of a crime.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.018  RETURN OF PROPERTY TO ACCUSED UPON ACQUITTAL.



   Whenever property or money shall be taken from persons arrested, and
shall be alleged to have been feloniously obtained, or to be the proceeds of
crime, and whenever so brought with the claimant and the person arrested
before any court for trial, and the court shall be satisfied from evidence
that the person arrested is innocent of the offense alleged, and that the
property rightfully belongs to him or her, the court may, in writing, order
the property or money to be returned, and the Chief of Police or his or her
duly designated agent, if he or she have it, to deliver the property or money
to the accused person himself or herself, and not to any attorney, agent or
clerk of the accused person.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.019  CLAIMS OF THIRD PERSON.



   If any claim to the ownership of the property or money shall be made on
oath before the court, by or in behalf of any other persons than the person
arrested, and the accused person shall be held for trial or examination, the
property or money shall remain in the custody of the Chief of Police or his
or her duly designated agent until the discharge or conviction of the person
accused.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.020  PROPERTY COMING INTO POSSESSION OF POLICE TO BE TRANSMITTED TO
CHIEF OF POLICE OR HIS OR HER DULY APPOINTED AGENT; DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY
OF DECEASED PERSONS.



   All property or money taken on suspicion of having been feloniously
obtained, or of being the proceeds of crime, and for which there is no other
claimant than the person from whom the property was taken, and all lost
property coming into possession of any member of the police force, and all
property and money taken from pawnbrokers as the proceeds of crime or from
persons supposed to be insane, intoxicated or otherwise incapable of taking
care of themselves, shall be transmitted as soon as practicable to the Chief
of Police or his or her duly designated agent, to be fully registered and
advertised for the benefit of all parties interested, and for the information
of the public as to the amount and disposition of the property so taken into
custody by the police. Whenever any money or property of deceased persons
coming into the custody of the Chief of Police or his or her duly designated
agent of the Police Department shall remain in his or her hands for the
period of one year without being claimed by the legal representatives of the
deceased person, the money or property, when not exceeding $100 in value,
shall be disposed of as lost or abandoned property as provided in this
subchapter.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.021  SALE AT AUCTION; BALANCE TO CITY TREASURER.



   (A)   All property, except perishable property, that shall remain in
the custody of the Chief of Police or his or her duly designated agent for
the period of six months, with the exception of motor vehicles which shall be
held for a period of three months, without any lawful claimant thereto after
having been advertised in some daily newspaper of general circulation
published in the city, shall be sold at public auction, and the proceeds of
the sale, having been retained by the Chief of Police or his or her duly
designated agent for a period of three months without a lawful claimant,
shall then be paid to the City Treasurer and all money that shall remain in
his or her hands for the period of six months shall be so advertised, and if
no lawful claimant appear, shall be likewise paid to the City Treasurer.



   (B)   All funds received by the City Treasurer shall be credited to
the General Fund. The Chief of Police or his or her duly designated agent
shall designate the time and place for holding the auction.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.022  SALE OF PERISHABLE PROPERTY.



   All perishable property so taken and unclaimed shall be sold at once.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.023  DELIVERY OF PROPERTY TO OWNER PENDING TRIAL.



   Whenever any article of property (except perishable property) other
than money, returned to the Chief of Police or his or her duly designated
agent as the proceeds of crime, are shown by sufficient evidence to be
necessary for the current use of the owner and not for sale, the Council has
power, in its discretion, to authorize the Chief of Police or his or her duly
designated agent to place the same in the custody of the owner, upon
sufficient bonds being given by the owner in the sum of twice the value of
the property, conditioned for the production of the same at any time within
one year when required for use in court as evidence in any proceedings
thereon.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.024  PERISHABLE PROPERTY MAY BE DELIVERED TO OWNER; SECURITY.



   Perishable property, returned to the Chief of Police or his or her duly
designated agent as the proceeds of crime, may be delivered to the owner on
ample security being taken by the court for his or her appearance to
prosecute the case.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.025  QUANTITIES OF GOODS HELD FOR SALE; DELIVERY TO OWNER.



   (A)   When large quantities of goods held for sale by the owner come
into the possession of the Chief of Police or his or her duly designated
agent as the proceeds of crime, the same may be delivered to the owner, his
or her heirs or representatives, as provided in § 33.017, upon ample
security to prosecute the case.



   (B)   However, goods with an estimated value of $50 or less shall be
retained by the Chief of Police or his or her duly designated agent until the
discharge or conviction of the accused.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.026  USE OF PROPERTY AS EVIDENCE.



   If any property or money placed in the custody of the Chief of Police
or his or her duly designated agent shall be desired as evidence in any
criminal court, the property shall be delivered to any officer who shall
present an order to that effect from the court; but the property shall not be
retained in the court but shall be returned to the Chief of Police or his or
her duly designated agent to be disposed of according to the provisions of
this subchapter.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.027  PROPERTY NOT CALLED FOR WITHIN ONE YEAR TO BE TREATED AS
ABANDONED.



   Any property or money returned to the Chief of Police or his or her
duly designated agent as the proceeds of crime, and which shall not be called
for as evidence by any proceeding in the municipal court within one year from
the date of the return may, unless specially claimed by the owner within that
time, be thereafter treated as other unclaimed abandoned or lost property or
money, as provided this subchapter.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)



§ 33.028  UNCLAIMED PROPERTY MAY BE ASSIGNED TO CITY DEPARTMENTS; METHOD OF
EFFECTUATING ASSIGNMENT.



   (A)   After expiration of the time period within which property
subject to the provisions of this subchapter maybe, reclaimed as herein
provided and no claim, has been made, the property may upon the request, of a
city department head or other city official be assigned by resolution of the
City Council to a city department for use by the department.



   (B)   All property thus assigned shall be appraised, identified and
enumerated by the Chief of Police or his or her duly designated agent and
accountable therefor assumed on the records of the department receiving the
property and a record of all transfers of property shall be kept by the
Police Department, the City Controller and any other departments as the City
Council may designate.



(Ord. 340, passed 7-27-1971)




CIVILIAN CROSSING GUARDS




§ 33.040  APPOINTMENT.



   The Chief of Police is hereby authorized and authorized and directed to
appoint special officers as he or she may deem necessary to perform police
duties under the direction of and in compliance with rules and regulations as
the Chief of Police shall promulgate.



(Ord. 253, passed 12-15-1959)



§ 33.041  DRESS.



   Civilian crossing guards shall wear badges, dress and insignia as the
Chief of Police shall direct, and shall be equipped in the manner which he or
she deems necessary for the proper discharge of their duties.



(Ord. 313, passed 9-24-1968)



§ 33.042  QUALIFICATIONS.



   The Chief of Police shall promulgate rules relating to the
qualifications, appointment, and removal of the civilian crossing guards.
Persons shall serve with compensation as may be provided for by the City
Council.



(Ord. 313, passed 9-24-1968)



§ 33.043  RIGHTS AND BENEFITS.



    Civilian crossing guards shall be entitled to all rights and benefits
provided under the provisions of Public Act 317 of 1969, being M.C.L.A. §§
418.101 through 418.941 and the amendments thereto; the same being known as
the worker’s compensation law of state.



(Ord. 313, passed 9-24-1968)



§ 33.044  UNLAWFUL TO WEAR UNIFORM WHEN OFF DUTY.



   It shall be unlawful for any civilian crossing guard to exercise his or
her authority as a guard or to wear the uniform or insignia, or to display
his or her badge in an attempt to exercise his or her authority, except
during the performance of actual authorized police duty.



(Ord. 313, passed 9-24-1968)



§ 33.045  UNLAWFUL TO NEGLECT OR REFUSE TO RESPOND TO ASSIGNMENT.



   It shall be unlawful for any civilian crossing guard to knowingly and
willfully neglect or refuse to respond for assignment or duty when called
under rules and regulations as promulgated by the Chief of Police.



(Ord. 313, passed 9-24-1968)



§ 33.046  UNLAWFUL TO IMPERSONATE CIVILIAN CROSSING GUARD.



   It shall be unlawful for any person not duly appointed and sworn in as
a civilian crossing guard to impersonate the officer, or to wear, carry or
display the badge, designated dress or insignia, of the civilian crossing
guards.



(Ord. 313, passed 9-24-1968)



§ 33.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Generally.  Any person violating any provision of this
chapter for which no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.999.



   (B)   Civilian crossing guards.  Any person or persons violating
any of the provisions of §§ 33.040 through 33.046 shall, upon conviction,
be subject to a fine of not to exceed $500 or imprisonment for a period of
not to exceed 90 days, or both a fine and imprisonment in the discretion of
the court.



(Ord. 313, passed 9-24-1968)



CHAPTER 34:  FIRE DEPARTMENT
