   72.999   Penalty




PARKING ON PUBLIC LOTS




§ 72.001  RESTRICTIONS.



   A person shall not park a vehicle on any parking lot open to the public
for the purpose of doing any of the following:



   (A)   Displaying the vehicle for sale;



   (B)   Washing, polishing, greasing and repairing the vehicle, except
for repairs necessitated by an emergency;



   (C)   Displaying advertising;



   (D)   Selling merchandise from the vehicle except in a duly
established market place or when so authorized or licensed under the
ordinances of this governmental unit; and/or



   (E)   Storage for more than 48 continuous hours.



(Ord. 449, passed 10-20-1994)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.002  REMOVAL AND IMPOUNDMENT.



   The Police Chief and/or any person or persons designated by the Police
Chief may remove and impound any vehicle from any area where it is parked in
violation of this subchapter.



(Ord. 449, passed 10-20-1994)



§ 72.003  REGISTERED OWNER.



   The registered owner of any vehicle parked in violation of this
subchapter shall be presumed to be the party who committed the violation.



(Ord. 449, passed 10-20-1994)




IMPOUNDMENT




§ 72.015  IMPOUNDMENT SITUATIONS.



   The Police Chief and/or a person or persons designated by him or her
may remove and impound a vehicle from public or private property in any of
the following situations:



   (A)   The vehicle is in a condition that the continued operation of
the vehicle would constitute an immediate hazard to the public;



   (B)   The vehicle is parked or standing in a manner as to create an
immediate public hazard or an obstruction of pedestrian or vehicular traffic;



   (C)   The vehicle is parked in a posted tow away zone;



   (D)   There is reasonable cause to believe that the vehicle or any
part of the vehicle is stolen;



   (E)   It is necessary to seize the vehicle to preserve evidence of a
crime or there is reasonable cause to believe that the vehicle was used in
the commission of a crime;



   (F)   Removal of the vehicle is necessary in the interest of public
safety because of fire, flood, storm, snow, natural or man-made disaster and
other emergency;



   (G)   The vehicle is hampering the use of private property by the
owner or person in charge of that property or is parked in a manner which
impedes the movement of another vehicle;



   (H)   The driver of the vehicle is taken into custody by the Police
Department and the vehicle would thereby be left unattended;



   (I)   Removal is necessary to permit snow removal, street
construction, cleaning and repair; tree work and other public utility work
after at least 24-hours notice thereof has been posted;



   (J)   A vehicle is unattended and the registered owner of the
vehicle has six or more unpaid outstanding citations for parking violations.
In lieu of or prior to impoundment under this provision, the Police Chief
and/or a person or persons authorized by him or her may attach to the vehicle
a device that will prevent the vehicle from being moved. A fee set by Council
resolution shall be charged for attachment and removal of the device. The
device may be removed by the Police Chief and/or a person or persons
designated by him or her if the violations and fee for attachment and removal
are paid, if security is posted for court appearance on the violations, if
the violations are dismissed, or if it is necessary to impound the vehicle it
is unlawful for any person to remove a device without authorization of the
Police Chief and/or a person or persons designated by him or her;



   (K)   Inoperative vehicles.



      (1)   No person shall park, store, leave or allow to be left
upon private property controlled by him or her, any motor vehicle in a
rusted, wrecked, junk and partially dismantled or inoperative condition
whether attended or not, unless in connection with an auto maintenance or
repair business or unless the vehicle is completely enclosed within a garage.



      (2)   Provided, however, that while no vehicle can be
maintained in the rear yard for a period not to exceed 30 days after notice
to remove the vehicle is served by the city so long as the vehicle is not
within 20 feet of an abutting residential lot.



   (L)   Unregistered vehicles.  No person shall park, store, leave or
allow to be left upon the streets, highways or parking lots of the city, any
motor vehicle not displaying current license plates registered to that
vehicle; and



   (M)   In any other situation in which impoundment is authorized
under the State Motor Vehicle Code and adopted by the Uniform Traffic Code.



(Ord. 440, passed 1-30-1992)



§ 72.016  POLICE CHIEF ACTION.



   (A)   If a vehicle is impounded under § 72.015(L), the Police Chief
and/or his or her assigns shall proceed in accordance with the requirements
of § 252d of the State Motor Vehicle Code.



   (B)   If a vehicle is impounded under § 72.015(J), the Police Chief
and/or his or her assigns shall not require a bond or cash deposit by the
owner of the motor vehicle in excess of $500 in order to recover the
possession of a motor vehicle pending final adjudication of the case.



(Ord. 440, passed 1-30-1992)




PARKING OF BOAT OR TRAILER ON RESIDENTIAL STREETS




§ 72.030  RESTRICTION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to park a boat or a boat trailer
for longer than one hour on any residential street or city owned property in
the city.



(Ord. 427, passed 6-30-1988)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.031  VIOLATION.



   Any person who violates this subchapter shall be responsible for
committing a civil infraction.



(Ord. 427, passed 6-30-1988)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.032  ENFORCEMENT.



   All of the provisions of this subchapter shall be enforced by any
officer of the City Police Department.



(Ord. 427, passed 6-30-1988)




PARKING METERS




§ 72.045  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CITY.  The City of Hamtramck, Wayne County, Michigan.



   CLERK.  The City Clerk of the City of Hamtramck, Michigan.



   DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS.  The Department of Public Works in the
city.



   OPERATOR.  Every individual who shall operate a vehicle as the owner
thereof or as the agent, employee and permittee of  the owner, or is in
actual physical control of a vehicle.



   PARK or PARKING.  The standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not,
upon a street otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of, and while
actually engaged in, receiving or discharging passengers or loading or
unloading merchandise or in obedience to traffic regulations, signs and
signals or an involuntary stopping of the vehicle by reason of causes beyond
the control of the operator of the vehicle.



   PARKING METER.  Any mechanical device or meter placed or erected for
the regulation of parking by authority of this subchapter. Each PARKING METER
installed shall indicate by proper legend the legal parking time established
by the city and when operated shall at all times indicate the balance of
legal parking time, and at the expiration of the period shall indicate
illegal or overtime parking.



   PARKING METER SPACE.  Any space within a parking meter zone; adjacent
to a parking meter, which is duly designated for the parking of a single
vehicle by lines painted or otherwise durably marked on the curb or on the
surface of the street adjacent to or adjoining the parking meters.



   PARKING METER ZONE.  Any street or part thereof upon which parking
meters are to be installed and placed in operation.



   POLICE DEPARTMENT.  The Police Department in the city.



   PERSON.  Any individual, firm, copartnership, association or
corporation.



   STREET.  Any public street, avenue, road, alley, highway, lane, path
and other public place or parking lot located in the city and established for
the use of vehicles.



   TREASURER.  The City Treasurer in the city.



   VEHICLE.  Any device in upon or by which any person or property is or
may be transported upon a street, except a device which is operated upon
rails or tracks.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)



§ 72.046  NEED FOR PARKING METERS; RECOMMENDATION.



   (A)   Where it is deemed that because of traffic congestion or other
cause, the public safety is imperiled, the public convenience can be better
served and traffic regulations can be more adequately enforced with the
assistance secured through the installation and maintenance of parking
meters, parking meters may be installed under and in accordance with the
provisions of this subchapter.



   (B)   When the Chief of Police deems that conditions on or along any
particular street or streets in the city appear to require the regulation of
traffic by parking meters, he or she shall make or cause to be made through
the Police Department a survey of the situation to determine the need for the
regulation, and if he or she finds a need therefor, he or she shall make a
determination of the fact, and shall file the determination together with his
or her recommendations with the City Council.



   (C)   The recommendations above referred to shall include among
other things:



      (1)   The parking meter zone or zones;



      (2)   Number of parking meter spaces;



      (3)   State the legal parking time in each zone;



      (4)   State the amount of the parking fee for each zone;



      (5)   State the hours during which the use of parking meters
shall be in operation in each zone; and



      (6)   Make any other recommendation that will facilitate the
movement or control of vehicular traffic and eliminate congestion thereof.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)



§ 72.047  COUNCIL APPROVAL; EFFECT.



   The Council may by appropriate resolution approve, modify prior to
approval and may disapprove any recommendation. If and when the
recommendation is approved by the Council, the recommendations as approved
shall be the equivalent of adoption by the Council and shall have the same
force and effect as though they had been set forth in a resolution in detail,
and shall be deemed to be regulations promulgated by the Council in the
control of traffic on the streets; provided, however, that nothing herein
stated shall be deemed to prevent the Director of the department whose duty
it is to enforce this subchapter to formulate rules and regulations as
authorized by the Charter for the organization and conduct of the department;
provided, further, that the promulgated regulations by the City Council shall
not be effective until signs have been erected sufficient in size and number
to apprise the ordinarily observant person of the existence of the parking
meter regulations. Upon the approval and the regulations becoming effective,
the Department of Parking Meters, as hereinafter established, shall thereby
be authorized and empowered to install parking meters and enforce the
regulations pertaining thereto as herein authorized.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)



§ 72.048  PARKING METER ZONES.



   The following named and described areas, streets or portions of
streets, and any other areas, as may hereafter be included in this section by
amendment hereto or by appropriate resolution of the City Council as provided
in this section, and lying within the corporate limits of the city, shall
constitute parking meter zones, namely:



   (A)   Both east and west sides of Joseph Campau Avenue, starting at
the southerly boundary of the city and extending to the northerly boundary;



   (B)   All streets intersecting the west side of Joseph Campau
Avenue, from the alley immediately west of Joseph Campau Avenue, extending
easterly, to Joseph Campau Avenue and including the south side of Holbrook
Street from the alley west of Joseph Campau Avenue to the westerly street
line of the Holbrook parking lot;



   (C)   The parking lot on the west side of Joseph Campau Avenue and
fronting on Holbrook Avenue and known as the “Holbrook Parking Lot” and
located specifically on Lots 102 to 109, all inclusive of Casgrain’s
Subdivision; and



   (D)   All streets intersecting the east side of Joseph Campau
Avenue, from the alley immediately east of Joseph Campau Avenue, extending
westerly to Joseph Campau Avenue, and including the north side of Holbrook
Street between Joseph Campau and Mitchell Avenues, and the north side of
Caniff Street between Joseph Campau and Mitchell Avenues.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)



§ 72.049  DEPARTMENT OF PARKING METERS ESTABLISHED.



   (A)   There is hereby created and established in the city government
a department to be known as the Department of Parking, which Department shall
be part of the Traffic Control Department, which shall be under the
direction, supervision and control of the Chief of Police, appointed by the
City Manager in accordance with the provisions of the City Charter.



   (B)   The Chief of Police shall have the following powers, duties
and responsibilities:



      (1)   To see that the provisions of this subchapter and the
regulations promulgated in connection therewith are enforced at all times;



      (2)   To install or cause to have installed parking meters in
places and locations as have been determined by Council approval as herein
provided;



      (3)   To see that the meters are properly maintained, serviced
and kept in a state of good repair so that they will be ready, and available
for use and operation when required;



      (4)   To cause the parking meter spaces to be individually
marked or painted on the street surface, curb or parking lots and the
markings to be continuously maintained, after the location thereof has been
designated as herein provided;



      (5)   To make or cause to be made regular collections of the
sealed coin boxes or containers from the meters and to deliver the boxes with
seals unbroken to the Treasurer or to the person or persons designated by the
Treasurer for the receipt of the boxes and the handling thereof and the
accounting for the contents thereof in his or her office;



      (6)   To obtain as often as necessary from the Treasurer the
quantities of sealed coin boxes or containers for inserting in the parking
meters to replace those removed containing coins, and to insert the empty
boxes in the meters for use;



      (7)   To keep a daily record of the sealed coin boxes properly
identified, which have been removed from meters and delivered to the
Treasurer;



      (8)   To file with the Traffic Violations Bureau of the city
on the following business day a carbon copy report of all violation notices
issued on the preceding day covering overtime parking and to file with the
City Council on the tenth day of each succeeding month a monthly report
showing the monies received from overtime parking and the disposition of each
violation notice issued during that current month;



      (9)   To erect or cause to be erected signs in sufficient
number and of suitable size to apprise the ordinarily observant person of the
existence of the parking meter regulation applicable to the parking meter
space and zone;



      (10)   To sign any and all complaints that may be necessary
for the proper enforcement of this subchapter;



      (11)   If the vehicle is not towed away, to issue a notice of
violation to every person, either as owner or operator involving every
vehicle that is illegally parked under the provisions of this subchapter and
the regulations promulgated thereunder; and



      (12)   To make recommendations from time to time to the
Council covering any matters requiring the Council’s help in enabling his
or her Department to function more effectively and efficiently.



   (C)   Any and all of the duties hereinabove specified may be
performed by the Chief of Police or by the person or persons by him or her
duly authorized.



   (D)   The cooperation of the Department of Public Works, the Police
Department and other administrative departments in the city is hereby
requested in setting up the parking meter program and in its continuation to
benefit the city.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)



§ 72.050  DESIGNATION OF PARKING SPACES.



   (A)   In determining the number of parking spaces that shall be
installed in each parking zone, a minimum of 20 feet in length shall be
allowed for each space for parallel parking when the space is interior, and a
minimum of 18 feet when the space is at the end of the zone. All parking
shall be parallel to curb, unless the Chief of Police shall determine and the
Council shall approve angle parking in any zone. A minimum of seven feet in
width shall be allowed for parallel parking, and a minimum of eight feet in
width shall be allowed for angle parking.



   (B)   The individual parking spaces shall be designated by lines
painted or durably marked on the surface of the street or on the curbing.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in a way that the
vehicle shall not be entirely within the limits of the space so designated.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.051  INSTALLATION OF PARKING METERS.



   (A)   After the parking meter zones have been established and the
number of parking spaces determined as herein provided, parking meters shall
be installed upon the curb or sidewalk immediately adjacent to the parking
spaces, the installation to be placed not more than two feet from the curb
and not more than four feet from the front line of the parking space as
indicated. Each meter shall be so set as to display a signal showing legal
parking upon the deposit of the appropriate coin or coins which are lawful
money of the United States of America, for the period of time prescribed by
appropriate Council regulation. Each meter shall be so arranged than upon the
expiration of the lawful time limit it will indicate by a proper visible
signal that the lawful parking period has expired, and in cases the right of
the vehicle to occupy the space shall cease and the operator or owner thereof
shall be subject to the penalties hereinafter provided.



   (B)   Where angle parking is designated for any parking meter zone,
the meter should be installed in the location that the portion of the vehicle
nearest the curb will be closest to the meter.



   (C)   Each parking meter shall be placed or set in a manner as to
plainly show or display, by a signal or otherwise, that the parking meter
space adjacent to the meter is or is not legally in use. Each parking meter
shall also indicate by a proper legend the coin to be deposited; the hours
during which the use of the meter is required; the legal parking time
established; and when operated, each meter shall indicate visibly on and by a
dial and pointer, or otherwise, the elapsing legal parking time, and upon the
expiration of the time, shall indicate the illegal or over-parking.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)



§ 72.052  OPERATION OF PARKING METERS.



   Except in a period of emergency determined by an officer of the Fire or
Police Department, or in compliance with the directions of a police officer,
when any vehicle shall be parked in any parking space alongside or next to
which a parking meter is located, the operator of the vehicle shall, upon
entering the parking meter space, immediately deposit or cause to be
deposited in the meter proper coin of the United States as it required for
the parking meter and as is designated by proper directions on the meter,
and, failure to deposit the proper coin shall constitute a violation of this
subchapter. Upon the deposit of coin the parking space may be lawfully
occupied by the vehicle during the period of time which has been prescribed
for the zone in which the parking space is located; provided, that any
persons placing a vehicle in a parking meter space adjacent to a meter which
indicates that unused time has been left in the meter by the previous
occupant of the space shall not be required to deposit a coin so long as his
or her occupancy of the space does not exceed the indicated unused parking
time. If the vehicle shall remain parked in any parking space beyond the
parking time limit set for the parking space, and if the meter shall indicate
by its dial and pointer that the time has elapsed and that parking is
illegal, then, and in that event, the vehicle shall be considered as parking
overtime and beyond the period of legal parking time, and the parking shall
be deemed a violation of this subchapter.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.053  PARKING TIME LIMITS.



   Parking a vehicle in a designated space in a parking meter zone shall
be lawful for the period of time specified for that zone as shown by a sign
on the meter or by one or more signs posted along the street in sufficient
number and of sufficient size to apprise the ordinarily observant person of
the existence of the limited period within which lawful sparking  can be had
along and upon the street. The parking meters shall be operated in the
parking meter zones Monday through Friday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and
8:00 p.m. and Saturdays between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., except
Sundays and holidays. Parking of a vehicle in any parking meter space for a
period longer than that allowed by the sign shall be deemed to be illegal and
a violation of this subchapter, provided, however, that lawful parking may be
had in the space during any hours when the parking meter regulations are in
effect, and on Sundays and holidays; provided, further, holidays as herein
used shall be deemed to mean and include only the following days, to wit:
January 1, Memorial Day, July 4, Labor Day, December 25 and the day
designated as a day of Thanksgiving.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.054  VIOLATIONS.



   It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this
subchapter for any person:



   (A)   To cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in
the name of, or operated by the person to be parked overtime, or beyond the
period of legal parking time established for any parking meter zone as herein
described;



   (B)   To deposit in any parking meter any coin for the purpose of
parking beyond the maximum legal parking time for the particular parking
meter zone and space;



   (C)   To permit any vehicle to remain in any parking space adjacent
to any parking meter while the meter is displaying a signal indicating that
the vehicle occupying the parking space has already been parked beyond the
period prescribed for the parking space;



   (D)   To park any vehicle across any line or marking of a parking
space meter or in a position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within
the area designated by the lines or markings;



   (E)   To deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break,
destroy and impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed under the
provisions of this subchapter, except persons legally authorized to open the
meter; or



   (F)   To deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any
slugs, device or metal substance; or other substitute for lawful coins.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.055  TOWAGE AND STORAGE.



   (A)   Whenever any vehicle shall be found parked in any parking
meter space overtime and beyond the period of legal parking time established
for the space, or shall be found parked therein during any period when
parking is prohibited or shall be found parked in violation of any of the
provisions of this subchapter, the vehicle may be removed by, or under the
direction of any person authorized to enforce this subchapter by means of
towing the same to the automobile and vehicle pound, and the removal shall be
at the risk of the owner. Before the owner or person in charge of the vehicle
shall be permitted to remove the same from the pound, he or she shall furnish
evidence of his or her identity and ownership or right to possession, shall
sign a receipt for the vehicle, the enforcing officer may in lieu of towing
the vehicle to the pound serve upon the owner or operator of the vehicle, or
attach to the vehicle, a notice directing the owner or operator thereof to
appear at the Traffic Violations Bureau of the city within the time specified
in the notice.



   (B)   The notice shall state the date and location of the meter
adjacent to the space where the violation occurred, the time of violation,
the kind of vehicle, the state license number of each vehicle, and any other
facts relevant to the violation. A copy of the notice may be attached to the
vehicle in a conspicuous place, which will notify the owner or operator that
the vehicle was parked in violation of the provisions of this subchapter and
instructing the owner or operator that the violation can be fully settled and
satisfied by the payment within 24 hours of the time of issuance of the
ticket.



   (C)   All sums thus collected by the Traffic Violations Bureau
relative to and all fines or penalties imposed arising out of parking meter
violations shall be paid to the Treasurer and credited to the Parking Meter
Receiving Fund.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Ord. 264, passed 6-6-1961; Am. Ord. 357,
passed 7-2-1974)



§ 72.056  REGISTRATION PLATE PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE THAT OWNER IS VIOLATOR.



   In any prosecution or proceeding hereunder, the registration plate
displayed on a motor vehicle shall constitute in evidence a prima facie
presumption that the registered owner of a vehicle as the person who parked
the vehicle at the place where the violation occurred.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)



§ 72.057  USE OF FUNDS.



   The coins deposited in parking meters are required and shall be used to
defray the expense of proper regulation of traffic upon the public streets of
the city; to provide for the cost of supervision, regulation, and control of
the parking of vehicles in parking meter zones, and to cover the cost of
purchase, supervision, protection, inspection, installation, operation,
maintenance, control and use of parking meters.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)



§ 72.058  DUTIES OF CITY TREASURER.



   (A)   The monies collected in the meter coin boxes shall be
delivered to and received by the City Treasurer and the City Controller or
his or her authorized representative, and accounted for and deposited by the
City Treasurer as, directed in this subchapter.



   (B)   The City Treasurer shall keep a detailed record of all monies
received from day to day from the several respective meters throughout the
city, and shall prepare a monthly summary of the receipts from each of the
meters. A copy of the summary shall be available to the City Controller and
to any other city official on request. He or she shall also prepare a monthly
report of miscellaneous monies received from fines and penalties from
overtime parking and submit the same the City Council.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)




RESIDENTIAL PARKING AREAS




§ 72.070  DESIGNATION BY CITY COUNCIL.



   The City Council is authorized to designate by resolution an area or
areas within the city in which parking is restricted to residents of the area
and their guests for specified hours of designated days of the week and to
adopt regulations for the administration of the designated residential
parking areas.



(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978)



§ 72.071  RESTRICTIONS TO BE POSTED.



   The hours and days and conditions under which parking is permitted
shall be posted on signs in the designated areas so as to give notice thereof
to the general public.



(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978)



§ 72.072  USE OF PERMIT BY UNAUTHORIZED PERSONS.



   It is shall be unlawful to permit an unauthorized person to use a
residential parking permit or a visitor’s parking permit or, to falsify
information to obtain these permits or to fail to surrender the permit to the
Chief of Police, or any of his or her designees, on his or her demand if the
permits are used in violation of this subchapter.



(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.073  FALSIFIED INFORMATION TO OBTAIN PERMIT.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to falsify information to obtain a
residential parking permit or a visitor parking permit, or to fail to
surrender the permit to the Chief of Police, or his or her duly designated
agent, on demand if it is used in violation of this subchapter or to
otherwise violate the regulations governing the issuance of the permits.



(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.074  PERMIT ISSUED.



   (A)   The Chief of Police upon application shall issue a residential
parking permit to each resident of a designated residential parking area for
each vehicle leased or owned by the resident upon presentation of a current
vehicle registration with the appropriate address, or with a tax bill if the
vehicle is not registered with the appropriate address.



   (B)   A RESIDENT for the purpose of this subchapter is any person
who rents or owns and lives in a designated residential parking area.
Residential parking permits shall be renewed on May 1 of each year.



(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978)



§ 72.075  NUMBER OF PERMITS.



   The Chief of Police shall issue three visitor’s parking permits to
each residential unit making application for a residential parking permit.
The resident’s address shall be recorded on the permit. Visitor’s parking
permit shall be coded and shall be renewed on May 1 of each year.



(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978)



§ 72.076  PERMIT AFFIXED TO INSIDE CENTER BOTTOM OF REAR WINDOW.



   The residential parking permits shall be permanently affixed to the
inside center bottom of the rear window of the vehicle for which the permit
was issued; the visitor’s parking permits shall be displayed so as to be
visible at the center bottom of the rear window of the vehicle.



(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.077  FEES.



   There shall be no charge for initial issue each year of the residential
parking permits or visitor’s parking permits but there shall be a fee of $3
for the replacement of residential parking permits or visitors parking
permits.



(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978)



§ 72.078  PARKING ALLOWED WITH PERMIT DURING DESIGNATED HOURS.



   (A)   No person shall park in a designated residential parking area
without a residential parking permit or a visitor’s parking permit during
the designated hours.



   (B)   Any vehicle parked not in conformity with the provisions of
this section shall be issued a violation tickets for the illegal parking and
the penalty therefor shall be as determined by City Council.



   (C)   The illegally parked vehicles also may be towed away to an
area designated by the Chief of Police.



   (D)   A towing fee as determined by City Council shall be paid by
the owner of the vehicle before it is released.



   (E)   The penalty and fee prescribed in this section shall be in
addition to any penalty otherwise prescribed for violations other than those
contained in this section.



(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.079  THREATENING A PERSON LAWFULLY PARKED PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful to threaten, prevent or hinder any person who has
lawfully parked, or is attempting to lawfully park, a vehicle within the city.



(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978)  Penalty, see § 72.999




PARKING ON PRIVATE PREMISES




§ 72.090  UNLAWFUL TO PARK WITHOUT PERMISSION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave or cause to be
parked or left any automobile or other motor vehicle on the premises of
another after having been warned not to do so by word of mouth or sign or
otherwise, however, the person shall not be held in violation of this
subchapter unless a complaint by the property owner is first made; provided
that this section, shall not apply to employees of the city in the discharge
of their official duties.



(Ord. 236, passed 9-7-1954)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.091  PARKING WITHOUT PERMISSION ON PRIVATE PREMISES PRIMA FACIE
EVIDENCE.



   The presence of an unattended automobile or other motor vehicle on the
premises of one who is not the owner or in control of the automobile or other
motor vehicle shall raise a prima facie presumption that the registered owner
of the automobile or other motor vehicle parked or left or caused to be
parked or left the automobile or other motor vehicle on the premises, and the
burden of proof shall be upon the registered owner to show otherwise.



(Ord. 236, passed 9-7-1954)  Penalty, see § 72.999



§ 72.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Parking on public lots.  Any person who violates any
provision of §§ 72.001 through 72.003 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and
punished by a fine not to exceed $500, or imprisonment not to exceed 90 days
or by both a fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 449, passed 10-20-1994)



   (B)   Impoundment.  Any person violating any of the provisions of
§§ 72.015 and 72.016 shall upon conviction thereof be subject to a find of
not more than $500 or to imprisonment for a period of not more than 90 days
or to both a fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 440, passed 1-30-1992)



   (C)   Parking of boat or trailer on residential streets.  Any
provision of §§ 72.030 through 72.032 which describes an act or omission
which constitutes a civil infraction under the terms of the Michigan Vehicle
Code, being Public Act 300 of 1949, being M.C.L.A. §§ 257.1 through
257.923, as amended, shall be processed as a civil infraction and any person
found to have committed a civil infraction may be ordered to pay a civil fine
of not more than $100 and costs.



(Ord. 427, passed 6-30-1988)



   (D)   Parking meters.  Any person who shall violate or fail to
comply with any of the provisions of §§ 72.045 through 72.058, or the
regulations promulgated by the Council in connection therewith, who shall
counsel, aid or abet any violation or failure to comply, shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine
of not to exceed $100, or imprisonment for not to exceed 90 days, by both a
fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)



   (E)   Residential parking areas.  Any person convicted of violating
any of the provisions of §§ 72.070 through 72.079 shall be punished by a
fine not to exceed $500 or imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or by both a
fine and imprisonment.



(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978)



   (F)   Parking on private premises.  Any person, firm or corporation
violating any provision of §§ 72.090 and 72.091 shall, upon conviction, be
punished by a fine not to exceed $100 or imprisonment in the Wayne County
Jail, or another place of confinement as may hereafter be selected by the
justice of the peace of the city, for a period of not to exceed 90 days, or
both a fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 236, passed 9-7-1954)



CHAPTER 73:  LOADING REGULATIONS



Section



   73.001   Establishment



   73.002   Application for loading zone



   73.003   Erection of no parking signs



   73.004   Installation and maintenance fees



   73.005   Establishment of installation and maintenance fees



   73.006   Exemptions



 



   73.999   Penalty



§ 73.001  ESTABLISHMENT.



   Special loading, shipping or receiving zones in front of entrances may
be provided and established under the conditions herein provided.



(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975)



§ 73.002  APPLICATION FOR LOADING ZONE.



   Any owner or occupant of a building adjacent to a street or alley
desiring a certain loading zone immediately in front of an entrance to the
building shall make application to the Chief of Police setting forth all
relevant information and stating the number of feet desired for that
purposes. The Chief of Police shall have authority to grant or refuse the
application when in his or her judgment the public welfare so requires, or to
grant the same with the restrictions or limitations as he or she may deem
necessary. In case the application is granted, the Chief of Police shall
issue to the applicant a permit, or certificate, setting forth the location
of the loading, shipping or receiving zone the number of feet fixed for the
zone and other limitations that may be pertinent. The permit may, at any
time, be withdrawn or modified by the Chief of Police whenever in his or her
judgment the public welfare so requires.



(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.003  ERECTION OF NO PARKING SIGNS.



   (A)   The Chief of Police, in order to enforce the provisions of
this chapter, shall erect no parking signs and other appropriate signs
marking the limits of the loading, shipping or receiving zones and setting
forth the hours during which the provisions shall be in effect.



   (B)   During the hours when the provisions applicable to the loading
zone are in effect, no vehicle shall be parked in any zone, except for the
purpose of taking on or discharging merchandise or freight, or for the
expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, and in no case for longer
than 30 minutes.



(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.004  INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE FEES.



   The installation and maintenance fees for loading, shipping or
receiving zones established under the terms of this chapter shall be as
hereinafter provided.



   (A)   Where the establishment of a zone does not necessitate the
removal of vehicle parking meters, an installation fee of $1 per foot
frontage shall be paid to the city by the applicant to defray the cost of
establishing a zone. In addition, an annual maintenance fee of $5 shall be
paid to the city by the permit holder on or before May 1 of each year to
defray the cost of maintenance for the following 12-month period, or fraction
thereof. In the event of failure to pay the maintenance fee by May 1, the
permit issued hereunder shall automatically expire.



   (B)   Where the establishment of a loading, shipping or receiving
zone necessitates the removal of one or more vehicle parking meters, an
installation fee of $75 shall be paid to the city by the applicant to defray
the cost of removing the vehicle parking meters and installing signs in each
loading, shipping or receiving zone established on the street. In addition,
the annual maintenance fee of $5 shall be paid to the city by the permit
holder on or before May 1 of each year for the zones established where the
vehicle parking meters were removed, where it was necessary to remove not
more than two meter stalls, and an additional fee of $25 shall be paid to the
city by the permit holder for each meter stall in excess of two which shall
have been removed to provide the zone on or before May 1 of each year, the
fee to defray maintenance and loss of revenues to the city for the 12-month
period, or fraction thereof following. In the event of failure to pay the
above maintenance fee by May 1, the permit issued hereunder shall
automatically expire.



(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.005  ESTABLISHMENT OF INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE FEES.



   The installation and maintenance fees for building entrance zones
established under the terms of this chapter shall be as hereinafter provided:



   (A)   Where the establishment of building entrance zones do not
necessitate the removal of vehicle parking meters, an installation fee of $25
shall be paid to the city by the applicant to defray the cost thereof. In
addition, an annual maintenance fee of $5 shall be paid to the city by the
permit holder on or before May 1 of each year, the fee to defray maintenance
for the 12-month period, or fraction thereof follow the maintenance fee by
May 1, any permit issued hereunder shall automatically expire.



   (B)   Where the establishment of a building entrance zone
necessitates the removal of one or more vehicle parking meters, an
installation fee of $75 shall be paid to the city by the applicant to defray
the cost of removing the vehicle parking meters and installing signs in each
building entrance established on the street. In addition, an annual
maintenance fee of $5 shall be paid to the city by the permit holder on or
before May 1 of each year for each building entrance zone established in an
area where the vehicle parking meters existed, where it was necessary to
remove not more than two meter stalls, and an additional fee of $25 shall be
paid to the city by the permit holder for each meter stall in excess of two
which shall have been removed to provide the building entrance zone on or
before May 1 of each year, the fee to defray maintenance and loss of revenues
to the city for the 12-month period, or fraction thereof following. Failure
to pay the fees shall subject the permit holder to the penalties established
for violation of this chapter.



(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975)  Penalty, see § 73.999



§ 73.006  EXEMPTIONS.



   The installation and maintenance fees to be paid under the provisions
of this chapter shall not be required of governmental institutions, public or
parochial schools, churches, hospitals, asylums, public libraries, public
museums or charitable institutions.



(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975)



§ 73.999  PENALTY.



   Any violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punishable by a
fine not to exceed $500, or imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or both a
fine and imprisonment.



(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975)



CHAPTER 74:  BICYCLES



Section



   74.001   Short title



   74.002   Definitions



   74.003   Authority



   74.004   Operation regulations



   74.005   Registration required



   74.006   Record keeping; payment of fees; rules and regulations
promulgated by Chief of Police



   74.007   Buying and selling bicycles



   74.008   Reciprocal right of bicycle operators



   74.009   Impoundment



 



   74.999   Penalty



§ 74.001  SHORT TITLE.



   This chapter may be referred to as the Bicycle Chapter.



(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003)



§ 74.002  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BICYCLE.  As defined by the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act 300 of
1949, being M.C.L.A. §§ 257.10 et seq. At the time of the adoption of this
chapter, BICYCLE means a device propelled by human power upon which a person
may ride, having either two or three wheels in a tandem or tricycle
arrangement, all of which are over 14 inches in diameter.



   CHIEF OF POLICE.  The person ultimately in charge of public safety
within the city or his or her designee.



(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003)



§ 74.003  AUTHORITY.



   This chapter is enacted under the authority granted to the city under
the Michigan Vehicle Code, being Public Act 300 of 1949, being M.C.L.A. §
257.606.



(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003)



§ 74.004  OPERATION REGULATIONS.



   (A)   No person under the age of 12 years shall operate a bicycle
upon any public highway, street and alley in the city; provided, however,
that the person under 12 years of age may operate a bicycle upon the
sidewalks in the city, and provided further that the person so operating the
bicycle shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an
audible signal before overtaking and passing the pedestrian.



   (B)   A person of the age of 12 years or older and under the age of
18 years shall be permitted to operate a bicycle upon any public highway,
street and alley in the city provided that the person has in his or her
possession a designation on his or her operator’s license, issued by the
Chief of Police in accordance with this chapter, in his or her possession the
written consent to do so of his or her parent or legal guardian.



   (C)   No person shall operate a bicycle during the hours when the
person is forbidden by any regulation establishing a curfew, unless the
person is not considered in violation of the regulation establishing a curfew.



   (D)   If the city establishes a usable and designated path for
bicycles adjacent to a roadway, a bicycle rider shall use that path.



(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003)  Penalty, see § 74.999



§ 74.005  REGISTRATION REQUIRED.



   (A)   Every owner desiring to operate a bicycle upon the public
highways, streets, sidewalks and alleys shall register their bicycle with the
Chief of Police not later than 90 days from the date of purchase or
acquisition of the bicycle, or within 30 days of the passage of this chapter.
The registration shall state the owner’s name, date of birth, residence
address, make of bicycle, serial number, and any other information as the
Chief of Police shall require. A registration fee may also be required.



   (B)   No person in the city shall keep any bicycles for hire unless
the same shall have been registered in accordance with this chapter and shall
be licensed to do business in the city in accordance with the applicable
business licensing regulation.



   (C)   Upon registration of the bicycle with the Chief of Police, he
or she shall cause to attach proof of registration to the bicycle. The Chief
of Police shall be authorized to determine the color, type and form of the
proof of registration to be attached to the bicycle, provided that the proof
of registration is numbered and contains the words “City of Hamtramck,
MI.” A duplicate of a lost, mutilated or destroyed proof of registration
may be secured from the Chief of Police upon filing of an affidavit with him
or her, demonstrating the facts, and upon payment of the appropriate fee.



   (D)   All proof of registration shall remain the property of the
city and the Chief of Police is hereby authorized to confiscate and take
possession or custody of any proof of registration attached to any bicycle
for which it was not issued, or when the owner of the bicycle has made or is
making an unlawful use of his or her proof of registration. Proof of
registration shall not be covered, obscured, bent, altered, or defaced in any
manner likely to impair its legibility. No person shall removed, destroy,
mutilate, alter, or counterfeit any proof of registration, or issue any
forged or counterfeit proof of registration. No person shall operate a
bicycle on the public highways, streets, sidewalks and alleys within the
corporate limits of the city under a proof of registration other than that
issued by the Chief of Police.



   (E)   All proof of registration issued by the Chief of Police shall
expire if and when the owner sells or transfers ownership of the bicycle for
which the proof of registration was issued, unless the proof of registration
is sooner revoked by the City Council for cause following a public hearing
conducted under the procedures determined by the City Council and
incorporated as part of the rules adopted at the first meeting of the new
Council. The Chief of Police may at any time, for cause, temporarily suspend
the proof of registration until the next regular meeting of the Council, but,
in no case, to exceed ten calendar days.



(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003)  Penalty, see § 74.999



§ 74.006  RECORD KEEPING; PAYMENT OF FEES; RULES AND REGULATIONS
PROMULGATED BY CHIEF OF POLICE.



   (A)   The Chief of Police shall keep a complete and accurate record
of all bicycle registrations.



   (B)   All fees required by this chapter shall be established
annually by the City Council during adoption of the annual budget.



   (C)   Any rules and regulations promulgated by the Chief of Police
shall be written and shall be made available for public inspection upon
request.



(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003)



§ 74.007  BUYING AND SELLING BICYCLES.



   (A)   All persons engaged in the business of buying new and
second-hand bicycles shall make a monthly report to the Chief of Police,
containing information and in the form as the Chief of Police shall require.
It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the buying of second-hand
bicycles to purchase any bicycle that has not been registered with the Chief
of Police. All persons engaged in the business of buying second-hand bicycles
shall be licensed to do business in accordance with the general business
licensing requirements of the city.



   (B)   All persons engaged in the business of selling new or
second-hand bicycles shall make a monthly report to the Chief of Police,
giving a list of all sales made by the dealers and containing the information
and in the form as the Chief of Police shall require. All persons engaged in
the business of buying second-hand bicycles shall be licensed to do business
in accordance with the general business licensing requirements of the city.



   (C)   Every person who sells or transfers ownership of any bicycle
shall report the sale or transfer by returning the proof of registration to
the Chief of Police and the name and address of the person to whom the
bicycle was sold or transferred, within seven calendar days of the date of
the sale or transfer. The purchasers or transferee of the bicycle shall
register within seven calendar days of the sale or transfer in accordance
with the registration provisions of this chapter.



(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003)  Penalty, see § 74.999



§ 74.008  RECIPROCAL RIGHT OF BICYCLE OPERATORS.



   Where adjacent municipalities have an ordinance similar to this chapter
and contain a similar provision, then it shall be lawful for a resident of
the adjacent municipality to operate bicycles upon the public highways,
streets, alleys and sidewalks in accordance with the regulations of this
chapter, provided that a nonresident so operating a bicycle shall provide
proof to any police officer in the city, upon request, that he or she
possesses a registration card issued by his or her home municipality.



(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003)



§ 74.009  IMPOUNDMENT.



   Any bicycle, the owner of which has failed to comply with the
requirements of this chapter, may be impounded by the Chief of Police and
released only upon payment of the registration fee, a penalty equal to the
amount of the registration fee, and full compliance with the provisions of
this chapter.



(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003)



§ 74.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   In the event of any violation of this chapter by a person
under the age of 18 years, the Police Department of the city shall be
authorized to immediately impound the bicycle of the person so operating for
a certain period, but not exceeding six months, and in addition thereto shall
notify the parent or guardian of the violator and giving details of the
violation and recommending to the parent or guardian to revoke for a period,
during which the bicycle is impounded, any written permission issued to the
person. The parent of a child or the guardian of a ward shall not authorize
or knowingly permit the child or ward to violate this chapter.



   (B)   Any firm, corporation and person, of the age of 18 years and
over, which violates, disobeys, omits, neglects, or refuses to comply with
any provision of this chapter is responsible for a municipal civil
infraction. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed to be a
separate offense. The fine structure shall be established by annual
resolution of the City Council upon adoption of the budget.



(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003)



CHAPTER 75:  TRAFFIC SCHEDULES



Schedule



      I.   Truck routes



SCHEDULE I.  TRUCK ROUTES.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any truck whether loaded or unloaded,
weighing more than 8,000 pounds as determined by its certificate of
registration, to be operated on any street in the city except those streets
hereinafter designated as “truck routes,” provided, however, the
provisions of this section shall not apply to trucks in excess of the weight
limit herein specified when the operation of the truck is necessary for the
purposes of making one or more deliveries or pickups of materials,
manufactured products, goods, wares and merchandise on streets other than
those designated “truck routes” in the city; provided further, that the
operation shall be permitted only for the shortest possible distance when
necessary to effect the delivery or pickup; provided further that trucks
operated by the city in connection with the rendering of necessary service to
the residents of the city may be operated on any or all streets in the city.



   (B)   The streets designated in this chapter as “truck routes”
shall be posted in a conspicuous place upon or at the entrance to the street
or highway or part thereof affected, with a suitable sign indicating the
words “truck route.”



   (C)   It shall be unlawful to park any truck, weighing in excess of
8,000 pounds as determined by its certificate of registration, on any street
in the city. The Chief of Police, for good cause shown, may grant special
parking permits allowing parking of those vehicles, provided the permit is
granted for a definite and specific period of time.



   (D)   All the provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the
City Police Department.



   (E)   A violation of this chapter shall constitute a civil
infraction subjecting the violator to civil fines and court costs as
permitted by law.



   (F)   The streets hereinabove referred to as “truck routes” are
hereby designated as follows.



 



Alpena Avenue from Caniff Avenue to Edwin Avenue


Buffalo Avenue from Caniff Avenue to Holbrook Avenue


Caniff Avenue from Grand Haven Avenue to Buffalo Avenue


Carpenter Avenue from Conant Avenue to Dequindre Avenue


Commor Avenue from Dequindre Avenue to Grand Trunk RR


Conant Avenue from Hamtramck Drive to Carpenter Avenue


Denton Avenue from Conant Avenue to St. Aubin Avenue


Dequindre Avenue from Carpenter Avenue to Poland Avenue


Hamtramck Drive from Conant Avenue to West City Limit


Holbrook Avenue from St. Aubin Avenue to Buffalo Avenue


Joseph Campau Avenue from Denton Avenue to Hamtramck Drive


Lumpkin Avenue from Denton Avenue to Poland Avenue

(Ord. 416, passed 5-7-1985; Am. Ord. 471, passed 5-13-1999)
