   90.999   Penalty




GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 90.001  SHORT TITLE.



   This subchapter shall be known and cited as Animal Subchapter of the
city.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)



§ 90.002  PURPOSE.



   The purpose of this subchapter is to promote the public health, safety,
comfort and general welfare of the community through the proper control and
care of animals by their owners and others.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)



§ 90.003  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER.  The person or persons employed by the city as
its enforcement officer formerly known as the dog warden.



   ANIMALS.  Shall include but not be limited to pigs, cats, dogs, sheep,
goats, chickens, ducks, rabbits, ponies, horses and any other animals as may
be kept in the city.



   AT LARGE.  Any animal shall be deemed at large when it is off the
property of its owner and not under the control of a competent person.



   BIRDS.  Includes domestic birds, including pigeons.



   EXPOSURE TO RABIES.  An animal has been exposed to rabies within the
meaning of this subchapter if it has been bitten by, or been in contact with
any animal known to have been in contact with any animal known to have been
exposed to rabies.



   KENNEL.  Any establishment wherein three or more dogs or other
warm-blooded animals are confined or kept for sale, boarding, breeding or
training purposes, for remuneration.



   OWNER.  Any person, group of persons, association, partner or
corporation owning, keeping or harboring a dog or other animal.



   PERSON.  Any individual, employee, corporation, co-partnership or
association.



   POULTRY.  Includes all domestic fowl.



   RESTRAINT.  An animal is under restraint within the meaning of this
subchapter if it is controlled by a leash, on or within a vehicle being
driven or parked on the street, or confined within the property limits of its
owner or keeper.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)



§ 90.004  CRUELTY TO ANIMALS; CROPPING DOG EARS.



   Whoever overdrives, overloads, drives when overloaded, overworks,
tortures, torments, deprives of necessary sustenance, cruelly beats,
mutilates or cruelly kills, or causes or procures to be so overdriven,
overloaded, driven when overloaded, overworked, tortured, tormented, deprived
of necessary sustenance, cruelly beaten, mutilated or cruelly killed any
animal and whoever having the charge or custody of any animal, either as
owner or otherwise, inflicts unnecessary cruelty upon the same, or wilfully
fails to provide the same with proper food, drink, shelter or protection from
the weather, shall, for every offense, be punished by imprisonment in jail
not exceeding 90 days or by fine not exceeding $500, or by both fine or
imprisonment. The cropping of dogs ears shall be considered to be a
mutilation or cruelty to an animal within the meaning of this subchapter,
unless the cropping is performed by a registered veterinary surgeon, while
the dog is under an anaesthetic.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)



§ 90.005  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, household or family unit
to harbor, maintain or keep more than a total of four cats and/or dogs when
the cats or dogs are over six months of age unless the owner obtains a kennel
license under § 90.021.



   (B)   For purposes of this subchapter, any person who shall allow,
permit or suffer any cat or dog to remain on or about his or her premises for
the space of ten days or more shall be deemed the owner thereof.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984; Am. Ord. 2014-64, passed 8-12-2014)  Penalty,
see § 90.999



§ 90.006  RUNNING AT LARGE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person owning or keeping a dog or cat to
permit the dog or cat to run at large in any street, alley or public place,
or upon the premises of another without the express permission of the owner
or occupant of the property.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.007  SANITATION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any dog or cat owned or
harbored by him or her to deposit fecal matter in any place other than the
premises where the dog or cat is harbored or kept.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.008  SANITARY REQUIREMENTS.



   Every person lawfully keeping any animal shall maintain the premises in
which it is kept in a sanitary condition and free of insects, vermin or
obnoxious odors.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.009  FAILING TO PRODUCE LICENSE.



   Whoever owns or harbors a dog more than six months of age and fails to
procure and produce a valid dog license upon the request of any person
authorized to enforce this subchapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.010  FAILING TO KEEP LICENSE AND COLLAR ON DOG.



   Whoever owns or harbors a dog more than six months of age and fails to
affix a valid dog license to a substantial collar which shall at all times be
kept on the dog for which the license is issued shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.011  HARBORING A BARKING DOG OR HOWLING CAT.



   Whoever harbors or keeps any dog or cat which by loud and frequent or
habitual and constant barking, yelping, howling or screeching causes an
annoyance to the neighborhood shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.012  HARBORING A VICIOUS DOG OR CAT.



   Whoever harbors or keeps a fierce or vicious dog or cat, a dog or cat
that has been bitten, or any animal known to have been afflicted with rabies
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.013  FAILING TO SURRENDER A RABID ANIMAL.



   (A)   Whoever refuses to surrender any animal in his or her
possession upon the demand of a peace officer who has reason to believe the
animal has contracted rabies, been subjected to rabies, or has bitten any
person is guilty of a misdemeanor.



   (B)   Any animal so surrendered shall be held for treatment and
observation for a period of ten days in a facility designated by the city and
at the sole expense of the animal owner.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.014  FAILING TO REPORT RABID ANIMAL.



   Whoever owns or harbors any animal which is bitten by another animal
showing symptoms of rabies who fails to report the incident to the Police
Department or animal control officer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.015  STRAY ANIMALS.



   It shall be the duty of the animal control officer or any other person
designated by the Chief of Police to seize and impound any dog or cat
straying unlawfully or kept in violation of this subchapter, and, further it
shall be the duty of the animal control officer or designated person to
dispose or destroy the animal in a humane manner. However, if the owner of
the animal is known, he or she shall be notified and if the owner appears
within 72 hours of the sending of the notice and produces proof to the
satisfaction of the animal control officer or the designated person that the
release of the dog or cat will not result in a future violation of this
subchapter, the dog or cat shall be turned over to the owner thereof after
payment of fees set forth herein.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.016  ANIMAL SHELTER.



   An animal shelter shall be utilized by the city at a place and location
as shall be selected and designated by the Mayor and approved by the City
Council.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)



§ 90.017  RELEASE OF DOGS OR CATS.



   (A)   No dog or cat shall be released from the animal shelter unless
his or her owner or authorized agent shall pay to the city a fee as set forth
in the following schedule:



 

For release of dog or cat
 

$25



Payment of the cost of harboring the dog or cat, for each day or fraction
thereof
 

$5




 



   (B)   When a dog or cat is released which has not been properly
immunized against rabies, the owner shall post a cash bond in the amount of
$25 which shall be held pending proof by the owner that the cat has been
properly immunized. The animal control shelter shall keep a record of all
seizures of dogs or cats and the collection of all fees and shall on a weekly
basis deliver all fees and other monies collected to the City Treasurer,
together with a list or copy of receipts containing the name and address of
persons posting cash bonds or paying fees, the fees to be reviewed from time
to time as necessary.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.018  UNCLAIMED DOGS OR CATS.



   (A)   The animal shelter may not sell or otherwise dispose of a dog
or cat within four days after its acquisition. If the dog or cat has a collar
or other evidence of ownership, the animal control officer or his or her
agent or the operator of the animal shelter shall notify the owner, if known,
and disposition of the animal shall not be made within three days from the
date of mailing of the notice. The operator of the animal shelter or the
animal control officer will maintain a record on each identifiable dog or cat
acquired, indicating a basic description of the animal, the date it was
acquired and under what circumstances. The record shall also indicate the
date of notice sent to the owner of an animal and subsequent disposition.



   (B)   This section does not apply to animals which are sick or
injured to the extent that the holding period would cause undue suffering, or
to animals whose owners request immediate disposal. Dogs or cats acquired,
having been exposed to rabies, or any dog or cat that has bitten a person or
other animal, shall be kept until the time and under conditions as may be
required by the Police Department.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.019  PROHIBITION OF CERTAIN ANIMALS AND PIGEONS.



   The owning, keeping or harboring of pigs, horses, cows, sheep, goats,
chickens, ducks, rabbits and pigeons is prohibited and anyone violating this
section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.020  CRUELTY TO BIRDS OR POULTRY.



   Whoever molests, injures, kills or captures any domestic or wild bird
or poultry, or whoever disturbs the nest of any wild birds, unless otherwise
permitted by law, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be imprisoned
for not more than 90 days or fined not more than $500 or by both.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)



§ 90.021  KENNELS, FEES AND REGULATIONS.



   (A)   General.  For the purposes of this subchapter, a kennel shall
be construed as an establishment wherein or whereon three or more dogs or
other warm blooded animals of six months or older, are confined and kept for
sale, boarding, breeding or training purposes for remuneration. Any person
requiring a kennel license shall make application to the City Clerk. The
license shall be issued only after investigation of the Building Department,
Police Department and Fire Department regarding compliance with all codes and
ordinances of the city, and a report regarding same shall be submitted in
writing to the Clerk’s office. The buildings, including walls and floors,
shall be of a construction as will adequately and comfortably house the
animals kept therein and the facilities used to confine the animals shall be
kept clean and free from accumulation of filth, mud, waste matter vermin and
debris. All warm blooded animals kept or maintained in connection within the
kennels shall be furnished with a clean, fresh water supply and adequate and
proper food to maintain the animals in normal condition of health.



   (B)   Fees.  The fee for the license shall be $50.



   (C)   Posting of license.  Each kennel license shall be posted in a
conspicuous place on the premises where the kennel is maintained and no
kennel license shall be transferable.



   (D)   Vaccination and license.  All dogs retained in any kennel
shall be vaccinated and licensed subject to the provisions of this subchapter.



   (E)   Certificate to be provided.



      (1)   Any person or persons, commercial establishment or
organization offering animals for sale shall provide the buyer with a
certificate guaranteeing that the animal is free from all disease and has had
all appropriate shots (including name of veterinarian and date).



      (2)   No animal offered for sale shall be placed in a kennel
or cage where a previously diseased animal was housed until the kennel or
cage is cleaned, disinfected and found to be free from disease in a manner
approved by the County Health Department and or any Board of the Michigan
Humane Society.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.022  KEEPING OTHER ANIMALS.



   Except for common household pets such as dogs and cats, it shall be
unlawful for any person to keep any animal or fowl within 175 feet of any
dwelling other than dwelling of owner, or to permit any animal or any fowl
owned by him or her, or in his or her possession or control, to run at large
in any street, alley or public place, or upon the premises of another without
express permission of the owner or occupant thereof.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)



§ 90.023  RESPONSIBILITY FOR DAMAGES.



   Every owner of a dog or cat shall be liable for damages for any and all
injuries to person or property caused by the dog or cat, to be determined and
collected in appropriate civil proceedings, and nothing in the subchapter
contained shall be construed to impose any liability upon the city, its
agents or employees, for damages caused by a dog or cat.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)



§ 90.024  VIOLATION NOTICES.



    The Police Department of the city and any person employed as an animal
control officer for the enforcement of this subchapter, is hereby authorized
upon the witnessing of violations where it is not practical, possible or
desirable in their judgment to impound the dog or cat, may issue to the owner
of the dog or cat a written notice of the violation pursuant to which the
owner shall pay to the city Police Department or City Clerk within 72 hours
after receipt of the notice a fee in an amount to be imposed pursuant to a
resolution of the City Council. The fees shall be added to the cost of
prosecution if a complaint is obtained against the owner of a dog or cat. If
the owner of a dog or cat shall fail to pay the service fees within the 72
hour period, the person issuing the notice shall forthwith file a complaint
in the court having jurisdiction thereof, and secure a warrant for the arrest
of the owner of the dog or cat, and all further proceedings shall be had in
accordance with the provisions of this subchapter.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)



§ 90.025  LICENSE; APPLICATION; FEE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to own, possess or harbor any cat
or other non-prohibited animal aged six months or over without first having
applied for and obtained a license therefor from the City Clerk of the city.
The license fee shall cost no less than $5 per animal per year and shall be
due on and annually renewable on the May 1; provided however this section
shall not apply to dog licenses which are already covered and mandated under
§§ 90.040 through 90.050.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)




LICENSING, IMMUNIZATION AND REASONABLE CONTROL OF DOGS




§ 90.040  GENERALLY.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to own, possess or harbor
a dog six months of age or over in the city without first having obtained a
license therefor. Every person in possession, of any dog or who shall suffer
the dog to remain about his or her premises for the space of ten days or
more, shall for the purpose of this subchapter, be deemed the owner thereof.



   (B)   No dog shall be permitted upon the public streets or off the
premises of the owner unless the dog has been immunized against rabies in a
manner approved by the Health Department, and unless the dog is under the
reasonable control of the owner or unless the dog is confined in the process
of being transported to and from the premises of the owner. For the  purpose
of this subchapter, a dog shall be deemed under the REASONABLE CONTROL when
the dog is with the owner or some member of the owner’s family or some
other person with permission of the owner.



   (C)   For the purposes of this subchapter, a dog shall be deemed NOT
TO BE UNDER REASONABLE CONTROL when the dog commits damage to the person or
property of any other than the owner, except in the defense of the owner, his
or her family or his or her property; or; in the case of a female dog while
in heat; off the premises of the owner, unless confined in the process of
being transported to or from the premises of the owner.



(Ord. 308, passed 4-11-1967)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.041  LICENSE APPLICATIONS.



   License to own, possess or harbor a dog shall be issued by the City
Clerk upon application for license and payment of the license fee required by
this subchapter. The application for license shall be accompanied by proof of
vaccination of the dog for rabies within one year prior to the effective date
of the license by a veterinarian licensed to practice veterinary medicine;
provided, that when the dog is vaccinated with modified live rabies virus of
chick embryo origin, proof of vaccination within two years prior to the
effective date of the license shall be deemed compliance with the foregoing
provision. It shall be the duty of any person owning or harboring a dog on or
before May 1 of each year or on or before any dog becomes six months of age,
or within 30 days after the person becomes a resident of the city, or within
30 days after he or she becomes the owner of a dog six months of age or more
to apply for a license; provided that no person or family unit shall keep
more than two dogs of the age of six months or over without first having
obtained a kennel license from the state. Further provided, that any person
who runs a dog kennel that is properly licensed by the state need not apply
for individual dog licenses under this subchapter. The applicant for a dog
license shall give his or her full name and address and the age and
description of the dog. If the applicant has become a resident of the city
within 30 days, the applicant shall give the date of becoming a resident or
acquiring a dog, as the case may be. All dog licenses hereafter issued shall
expire on May 1 in the year following their issuance.



(Ord. 308, passed 4-11-1967)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.042  LICENSE FEES.



   (A)   License fees shall be as follows: $3 for each dog, whether
male or female. At the time of issuing the same, and for each renewal
thereof, provided that when the license is issued from the State Humane
Society they are authorized to deduct the sum of $0.50 for each license so
issued, to pay the State Humane Society for the administrative costs
incurred, before depositing the balance with the licensing officer.



   (B)   In case of a dog which has been duly licensed in another
county, city or village in the state, or by lawful authority of any state in
the United States of America, if application is made by the owner or person
harboring a dog within 30 days prior to the expiration of his or her foreign
license, the fee shall be $1 for each dog. The Clerk shall retain and file
the foreign license and return it to the owner thereof on demand if the owner
at any time desires the return of the license and deposits with the Clerk his
or her Hamtramck license in exchange thereof.



   (C)   When application is made for a license after May 1, or after a
dog is six months of age, or more than 30 days after the dog has been
acquired or its owner has moved into the city, an additional charge shall be
made by way of penalty amounting to $1 for each dog, provided, however, in
the case of anyone moving into the city after May 1, or owning or acquiring a
dog becoming six months of age after May 1, or acquiring a dog after May 1,
and furnishing satisfactory proof to the Clerk of the fact, the license fee
shall be the same as for licenses issued prior to May 1.



   (D)   In the case of any license issued after December 15, provided
the owner proves to the satisfaction of the City Clerk that the dog was not
acquired by the owner prior to November 15, or did not become six months of
age prior to November 15, or that the owner was not a resident of the city
and owner of the dog prior to November 15, the fees shall be $1 for each dog.



   (E)   In case at any time the vaccination against rabies is no
longer required, licenses for unimmunized dogs may be issued upon payment of
a fee of $4 or if application is made after May 15, of any year, $5.50.



(Ord. 308, passed 4-11-1967)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.043  TAGS.



   Upon issuance of a license there shall be delivered to the licensee by
the Clerk, a license tag of metal or other suitable material, and not less
than one inch in length or diameter; containing the number of the license
duly stamped or engraved thereon, the year of issuance, the words:
“Licensed, Hamtramck, Michigan” and also bearing the word:
“Immunized.” In case at any time the vaccination against rabies is no
longer required by the county, the word “Immunized” shall be omitted from
the license tag for an unimmunized dog. Every person owning or harboring a
dog shall provide the same with a substantial collar of durable material and
shall be responsible for attaching the license tag securely thereto, and
shall cause the collar with license tag attached thereto, to be worn by the
dog. Absence of the collar and license tag from any dog shall be prima facie
evidence that the dog is not licensed and any person finding the dog on his
or her premises or running at large, may seize and deliver the dog to the
pound. No person shall remove any license tag from any dog without the
consent of the person owning or harboring the dog and no tag shall be used on
the collar of harness of any dog other than the dog for which the tag was
issued. In case of the loss of a tag the owner may secure a duplicate from
the City Clerk upon payment of $0.50.



(Ord. 308, passed 4-11-1967)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.044  KEEPING OF DANGEROUS DOGS.



   (A)   No person shall harbor or keep any dog which by loud, or
frequent or habitual barking, yelping or howling shall cause a serious
annoyance to the neighborhood or to people passing to and fro upon the
streets.



   (B)   No person shall own or harbor a vicious dog or a dog that has
been afflicted with rabies. Any person who shall have in his or her
possession a dog which has contracted rabies, or which has been bitten by an
animal suspected of being afflicted with rabies, or which has bitten any
person shall, upon demand of the animal control officer or the health officer
or any police officer of the city, produce and surrender up the dog to the
animal control officer or Health Department of the city to be held for
observation for a period of ten days. Provided, that with the approval of the
Health Department or animal control officer, any dog may be surrendered to a
registered veterinarian or to any approved, non-profit corporation organized
for the purpose of sheltering dogs, or may be confined for a period of ten
days at the owner’s home. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or
allow the removal from his or her premises of a dog so confined for
observation without the written permission of the health officer or animal
control officer. Every owner, or other person, upon ascertaining that a dog
is rabid, shall immediately notify the animal control officer or a police
officer who shall either remove the dog to the pound or summarily destroy it.
Whenever any dog is brought to the pound for having bitten a person, the
animal control officer may, if deemed necessary and after holding the dog for
a sufficient length of time to meet the requirements of the Health
Department, cause the dog to be destroyed as a vicious animal.



(Ord. 308, passed 4-11-1967)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.045  POUND.



   The city shall provide and maintain a dog pound or its equivalent
facilities and it shall be the duty of the animal control officer, or any
other person employed by the Chief of Police for that purpose, and of any
police officer of the city, to promptly seize, take up and place in the pound
all dogs that may be found running at large, or being kept or harbored any
place within the city contrary to the provisions of this subchapter.



(Ord. 308, passed 4-11-1967)



§ 90.046  POUND FEES.



   (A)   The owner of a dog impounded under the provisions of this
subchapter may claim the dog by properly identifying himself or herself as
the owner of the animal and upon meeting the following conditions:



      (1)   Payment of an impounding fee of $2.50;



      (2)   Payment of a boarding fee of $1.00 for each 24 hours or
fraction thereof that the dog is held, after the first 24 hours; and



      (3)   The showing of a dog license for the dog, or if the dog
has no license, then the securing of a license and the showing of proof of
vaccination of the dog for rabies.



   (B)   It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to destroy
in a humane manner, all impounded dogs which are not claimed and released
within three days after being impounded; provided, however, if in his or
her  judgment, the dog is valuable or otherwise desirable for keeping, the
animal control officer may dispose of the dog to any reasonable person who
will undertake to remove the dog from the city or keep and harbor the dog
within the city in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter. The
bodies of all dogs destroyed at the pound or elsewhere in the city shall be
disposed of by the animal control officer in a manner approved by the Health
Department.



(Ord. 308, passed 4-11-1967)



§ 90.047  ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of the animal control officer or other
person designated by the Chief of Police for the purpose, to make diligent
inquiry as to the dogs owned, harbored or kept, or kennels operated in the
city, and whether the dogs and kennels are licensed.



   (B)   Any dog found unlicensed after May 1 of each year may be
seized and impounded by the animal control officer or other authorized person.



   (C)   If the owner or person harboring the dog be known, the animal
control officer or other officer shall file a complaint against the owner or
person in the Municipal Court; provided, however, the person owning or
harboring the dog may in lieu of having his or her dog seized and impounded
or having a complaint filed against him or her, pay to the animal control
officer for the use of the city, a penalty of $3, which penalty will be
returned to the owner if within ten days after payment of same he or she
procures a license for the dog.



(Ord. 308, passed 4-11-1967)



§ 90.048  CRUELTY TO DOGS.



   No person owning or harboring any dog, or any other person, shall treat
a dog in a cruel or inhuman manner, or wilfully or negligently cause or
permit any dog to suffer unnecessary torture or pain.



(Ord. 308, passed 4-11-1967)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.049  STRAY DOGS.



   Any stray dog unclaimed by its owner within 72 hours after it has been
picked ups, any dog running at large in the streets or public places in the
city, or any dog which may in any manner disturb the quiet of any person or
neighborhood or any dog which shall bite a person may be declared to be a
nuisance, subject to abatement by the Police Department or the Department of
Health, in accordance with the terms and provisions of this subchapter and
the rules and regulations of the Police Department and the Department of
Health applicable thereto.



(Ord. 308, passed 4-11-1967)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.050  LEADER DOG; NO FEES.



   Dog licenses required under this subchapter shall be issued by the
licensing officer of the city without any charge therefore to leader dogs
made use of by blind persons. All licenses issued under this subchapter shall
expire upon May 1 following their issue.



(Ord. 308, passed 4-11-1967)




POULTRY




§ 90.065  LOCKING OR TYING WINGS PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, by himself,
herself or another, to lock or tie the wings of any chicken, turkey, goose,
duck or other domestic fowl for the purpose of weighing or handling or cause
the same to be done.



(Ord. 282, passed 3-12-1963)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.066  OVERCROWDING PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to overcrowd
in any crate, box or other receptacle rabbits, domestic fowl or poultry or to
fail to provide proper food, water, shelter or sanitation for the same.



(Ord. 282, passed 3-12-1963)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.067  SALE, BARTER OR GIVE AWAY OF FOWL AS PETS OR NOVELTIES.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to sell, or
offer for sale, barter or give away baby chicks, rabbits, ducklings or other
fowls as pets or novelties, whether or not dyed, colored or otherwise
artificially treated. This subchapter shall not be construed to prohibit the
display or sale of natural chicks or ducklings in proper brooder facilities
by hatcheries or stores engaged in the business of selling the same to be
raised for commercial purposes.



(Ord. 282, passed 3-12-1963)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.068  VIOLATION.



   In case of any violation of this subchapter, it shall be the duty of
any fully appointed humane officer, peace officer, sheriff or health officer
to seize the fowl or pets and provide the necessary care and attention, and
the fowl or pets shall not be returned until all expenses for the care and
attention shall have been paid.



(Ord. 282, passed 3-12-1963)



§ 90.069  LIMITS.



   Rabbits, ducks, and other small animals are limited to a total of six
per household and require a license obtained annually from the City Clerk’s
office with a fee annually set by City Council. Chickens and roosters are not
permitted. Prior to issuance of the annual permit the city shall either
inspect or cause to be inspected any outdoor animal coops, houses, or
enclosures for compliance with this chapter.



(Ord. 2014-64, passed 8-12-2014)



§ 90.070  PIGEONS.



   No person shall keep, maintain or harbor any pigeons within the city
except upon the conditions prescribed in this section, which conditions are
hereby declared to be in addition to such restrictions as may be contained in
all other ordinances. A license shall be obtained annually from the City
Clerk’s office with a fee annually set by City Council. Prior to issuance
of the annual permit the city shall either inspect or cause to be inspected
any outdoor coop, houses, or enclosures for compliance with this chapter.



(Ord. 2014-64, passed 8-12-2014)



§ 90.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Animals.



      (1)   Any person violating any of the provisions §§ 90.001
through 90.025 shall upon conviction thereof be subject to a fine of not more
than $500 or to imprisonment for a period of not more than 90 days or to both
a fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court.



      (2)   Each day that a violation is continued or permitted to
exist shall constitute a separate offense punishable upon conviction as
herein provided.



(Ord. 412, passed 5-8-1984)



   (B)   Licensing, immunization and reasonable control of dogs.  Any
person or persons violating any of the provisions of §§ 90.040 through
90.050 shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not exceeding
$500 or imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or both a fine and imprisonment
in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 308, passed 4-11-1967)



   (C)   Poultry.  Any person, firm or corporation violating §§
90.065 through 90.068 shall be prosecuted and upon conviction of the
violation shall be guilty of misdemeanor and punished by a fine not exceeding
the sum of $100 or by imprisonment in the Wayne County Jail, or other place
of confinement as may be hereafter established by the City Council, for a
period not exceeding 30 days, or both a fine and imprisonment in the
discretion of the court having jurisdiction of the cause.



(Ord. 282, passed 3-12-1963)



CHAPTER 91:  FIREWORKS



Section



   91.001   Definitions



   91.002   Prohibition on use of consumer fireworks



   91.003   Possession of consumer fireworks by minor



   91.004   Sale, give, furnish to minor



   91.005   Ignition, discharge and use of consumer fireworks



   91.006   Restrictions on use when under the influence



   91.007   Enforcement; seizure



 



   91.999   Penalty



§ 91.001  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   APA. The American Pyrotechnics Association.



   CONSUMER FIREWORKS. Fireworks devices that are designed to produce
visible efforts by combustion, that are required to comply with the
construction, chemical composition, and labeling regulations promulgated by
the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission under 16 CFR parts 1500
and 1507, and that are listed in APA standard 87-1, 3.1.2-3-5. CONSUMER
FIREWORKS do not include low impact fireworks.



   DISPLAY FIREWORKS. Large fireworks devices that are explosive materials
intended for use in fireworks displays and designed to produce visible or
audible effects by combustion, deflagration, or detonation, as provided in 27
CFR 555.11, 49 CFR 172 and APA standard 87-1, 4.1.



   FIREWORK or FIREWORKS. Any composition or device, except for a starting
pistol, flare gun, or a flare, designed for the purpose of producing a
visible or audible effect by combustion, deflagration or detonation.
FIREWORKS consist of consumer fireworks, low impact fireworks, articles
pyrotechnic, display fireworks and special effects.



   LOW IMPACT FIREWORKS. Ground and handheld sparkling devices as that
phrase is defined under APA standards 87-1, 3.1, 3.1.1 to 3.1.8 and 3.5.



   MINOR. An individual who is less than 18 years old.



   NATIONAL HOLIDAY. Legal public holidays:



      (1)   New Years Day, January 1.



      (2)   MLK Day, third Monday in January.



      (3)   Washington’s Birthday, third Monday in February.



      (4)   Memorial Day.



      (5)   Independence Day.



      (6)   Labor Day.



      (7)   Columbus Day.



      (8)   Veterans Day.



      (9)   Thanksgiving Day.



      (10)   Christmas Day.



   NOVELTIES. That term as defined under APA standard 87-1, and all of the
following: toy plastic or paper caps for toy pistols in sheets, strips, rolls
or individual caps containing not more than .25 of a grain of explosive
content per cap, in packages labeled to indicate the maximum explosive
content per cap; flitter sparklers in paper tube not exceeding one-eighth
inch in diameter.



   PERSON. An individual, agent, association, charitable organization,
company, LLC, corporation, labor organization, or any other legal or
commercial entity.



(Ord. 486, passed 11-6-2002; Am. Ord. 2014-41, passed 6-10-2014)



§ 91.002  PROHIBITION ON USE OF CONSUMER FIREWORKS.



   No person shall ignite, discharge or use consumer fireworks within the
City of Hamtramck, except this prohibition shall not preclude any person from
the ignition, discharge and use of consumer fireworks on the day preceding,
the day of, or the day after a national holiday, provided further, however,
that no person shall ignite, discharge or use consumer fireworks on those
days, between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m., consistent with Sec. 7
(2) of Public Act 65 of 2013. This provision does not apply to City of
Hamtramck sponsored events.



(Ord. 2014-41, passed 6-10-2014)  Penalty, see § 91.999



§ 91.003  POSSESSION OF CONSUMER FIREWORKS BY MINOR.



   A minor shall not possess consumer fireworks.



(Ord. 2014-41, passed 6-10-2014)  Penalty, see § 91.999



§ 91.004  SALE, GIVE, FURNISH TO MINOR.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale, sell, furnish,
give or cause to be sold, furnished or given any consumer fireworks to a
person under the age of 18 years.



(Ord. 486, passed 11-6-2002; Am. Ord. 2014-41, passed 6-10-2014)  Penalty,
see § 91.999



§ 91.005  IGNITION, DISCHARGE AND USE OF CONSUMER FIREWORKS.



   No person shall ignite, discharge or use consumer fireworks on public
property, school property, church property or the property of another without
that person or organization’s express permission to use those fireworks on
those premises.



(Ord. 2014-41, passed 6-10-2014)  Penalty, see § 91.999



§ 91.006  RESTRICTIONS ON USE WHEN UNDER THE INFLUENCE.



   A person shall not use consumer fireworks or low impact fireworks while
under the influence of alcoholic liquor, a controlled substance or
combination of alcoholic liquor and a controlled substance (as defined by
M.C.L.A. §§ 257.1d and 257.8b).



(Ord. 2014-41, passed 6-10-2014)  Penalty, see § 91.999



§ 91.007  ENFORCEMENT; SEIZURE.



   (A)   The City Fire Marshal, Fire Chief, or their respective
designee(s), or sworn law enforcement officers of the city are authorized to
enforce the provisions of this chapter.



   (B)   If the City Fire Marshal, Fire Chief, or their respective
designee, or a sworn law enforcement officer of the city, determines that a
violation of this chapter has occurred, the Fire Marshal, Fire Chief, or
designee, or sworn officer may seize the consumer fireworks as evidence of
the violation.



(Ord. 2014-41, passed 6-10-2014)  Penalty, see § 91.999



§ 91.999  PENALTY.



   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall upon
conviction thereof be subject to a fine of not more than $500 or to
imprisonment for a period of not more than 93 days or both. Each day that a
violation is continued or permitted to exist shall constitute a separate
offense.



(Ord. 486, passed 11-6-2002; Am. Ord. 2014-41, passed 6-10-2014)



CHAPTER 92:  DANGEROUS OR ABANDONED BUILDINGS



Section



   92.001   Dangerous buildings defined



   92.002   Standards for repair, vacation or demolition



   92.003   Dangerous buildings; nuisances



   92.004   Duties of Housing Code Inspector



   92.005   Duties of Housing Code Board of Appeals



   92.006   Duties of City Attorney



   92.007   Emergency cases



   92.008   When owner absent from the city



   92.009   Administrative liability



   92.010   Duties of Fire Department



   92.011   Duties of Police Department



 



   92.999   Penalty



§ 92.001  DANGEROUS BUILDINGS DEFINED.



   All buildings or structures which have any or all of the following
defects shall be deemed DANGEROUS BUILDINGS:



   (A)   Those whose interior walls or other vertical structural
members list, lean or buckle to an extent that a plumb line passing through
the center of gravity falls outside of the middle third of its base;



   (B)   Those which, exclusive of the foundation, show 33% or more, of
damage or deterioration of the supporting member or members or 50% of damage
or deterioration of the non-supporting enclosing or outside walls or covering;



   (C)   Those which have improperly distributed loads upon the floors
or roofs or in which the same are overloaded or which have insufficient
strength to be reasonably safe for the purpose used;



   (D)   Those which have been damaged by fire, wind or other causes so
as to have become dangerous to life, safety, morals or the general health and
welfare of the occupants or the people of the city;



   (E)   Those which have become or are so dilapidated, decayed,
unsafe, unsanitary or which so utterly fail to provide the amenities
essential to decent living that they are unfit for human habitation or are
likely to cause sickness or disease, so as to work injury to the health,
morals, safety or general welfare of those living therein;



   (F)   Those having light, air and sanitation facilities which are
inadequate to protect the health, morals, safety or general welfare of human
beings who live or may live therein;



   (G)   Those having inadequate facilities for egress in case of fire
or panic or those having insufficient stairways, elevators, fire escapes or
other means of communication;



   (H)   Those which have parts thereof which are so attached they may
fall and injure members of the public or property;



   (I)   Any building or structure which becomes hazardous to the
safety, health or welfare of the public by reason of inadequate maintenance,
dilapidation, obsolescence or abandonment;



   (J)   Those buildings existing in violation of any provision of the
Building Code of this city or any provision of the Fire Prevention Code or
other ordinances of this city;



   (K)   Any building which shall become vacant and open at door or
window, leaving the interior exposed to the elements or accessible to
entrance by trespassers or animals;



   (L)   Any building which has been damaged, vandalized or has
deteriorated to an extent as to be unfit or unsuitable for occupancy and
which has not been made habitable or safe to the standards of this chapter
within 30 days after notice by the building official upon the last known
owner or person having the right to possession thereof; and/or



   (M)   Any sign, fence, shed, lean-to, cellar or other structure
which has become so rotted, broken, infirm or dilapidated as to be likely to
fall over or otherwise injure persons coming upon the premises.



(Ord. 394, passed 5-6-1980)



§ 92.002  STANDARDS FOR REPAIR, VACATION OR DEMOLITION.



   The following standards shall be followed in substance by the Building
Inspector or the Housing Code Inspector in ordering repair, vacation or
demolition.



   (A)   If the “dangerous building” can reasonably be repaired so
that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this chapter, it
shall be ordered repaired.



   (B)   If the “dangerous building” is in a condition as to make
it dangerous to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of its
occupants, it shall be ordered to be vacated.



   (C)   In any case where a “dangerous building” is 50% damaged or
decayed or deteriorated from its original value or structure, it shall be
demolished, and in all cases where a building cannot be repaired so that it
will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this chapter it shall be
demolished. In all cases where a “dangerous building” is a fire hazard
existing or erected in violation of the terms of this chapter or any
ordinance of the city or statute of the state, it shall be demolished.



(Ord. 394, passed 5-6-1980)  Penalty, see § 92.999



§ 92.003  DANGEROUS BUILDINGS; NUISANCES.



   All “dangerous buildings” within the terms of § 92.001 of this
chapter are hereby declared to be public nuisances, and shall be repaired,
vacated or demolished as hereinbefore and hereinafter provided.



(Ord. 394, passed 5-6-1980)  Penalty, see § 92.999



§ 92.004  DUTIES OF HOUSING CODE INSPECTOR.



   The Housing Code Inspector shall:



   (A)   Inspect or cause to be inspected semiannually, all public
buildings, schools, halls, churches, theaters, hotels, tenements, commercial,
manufacturing or loft buildings for the purpose of determining whether any
conditions exist which render those places a “dangerous building” within
the terms of § 92.001 of this chapter;



   (B)   Inspect any building, wall or structure about which complaints
are filed by any person to the effect that a building, wall or structure is
or may be existing in violation of this chapter;



   (C)   Inspect any building, wall or structure reported (as
hereinafter provided for) by the Fire or Police Departments of this city as
probably existing in violation of the terms of this chapter;



   (D)   Inspect annually buildings in the following sections of this
city, to determine whether they are “dangerous buildings” within the
terms of § 92.001 of this chapter;



   (E)   (1)   Notify in writing the owner, occupant, lessee,
mortgagee, agent and all other persons having an interest in the building as
shown by the land records of the Recorder of Deeds of the county, of any
building found by him or her to be a “dangerous building” within the
standards set forth in § 92.001 of this chapter that:



         (a)   The owner must vacate, or repair or demolish the
building in accordance with the terms of the notice and this chapter;



         (b)   The occupant or lessee must vacate the building or
may have it repaired in accordance with the notice and remain in possession;
and



         (c)   The mortgagee, agent or other persons having an
interest in the building as shown by the land records of the Recorder of
Deeds of the county may at his or her own risk repair, vacate or demolish the
building or have the work or act done.



      (2)   Provided, that any person notified under this division
to repair, vacate or demolish any building shall be given reasonable time,
not exceeding 30 days, as may be necessary to do, or have done, the work or
act required by the notice provided for herein.



   (F)   Set forth in the notice provided for in division (E) hereof, a
description of the building and a picture of the building, or structure
deemed unsafe, a statement of the particulars which make the building or
structure a “dangerous building” and in order requiring the same to be
put in the condition as to comply with the terms of this chapter within a
length of time, not exceeding 30 days, as is reasonable;



   (G)   Report to the Housing Code Board of Appeals and the Building
Inspector any noncompliance  with the notice provided for in divisions (E)
and (F) hereof;



   (H)   Appear at all hearings conducted by the Housing Board of
Appeals and testify as to the condition of “dangerous buildings;” and



   (I)   Place a notice on all “dangerous buildings” reading as
follows:



      This building has been found to be a dangerous building by the
Housing Code Inspector. This notice is to remain on this building until it is
repaired, vacated or demolished in accordance with the notice which has been
given the owner, occupant, lessee, mortgagee or agent of this building, and
all other persons having an interest in the building as shown by the land
records of the Recorder of Deeds of the County of Wayne. It is unlawful to
remove this notice until the notice is complied with.



(Ord. 394, passed 5-6-1980)  Penalty, see § 92.999



§ 92.005  DUTIES OF HOUSING CODE BOARD OF APPEALS.



   The Housing Code Board of Appeals shall:



   (A)   Upon receipt of a report of the Housing Code Inspector as
provided for in § 92.004(G) hereof, give written notice to the owner,
occupant, mortgagee, lessee, agent and all other persons having an interest
in the building as shown by land records of the Recorder of Deeds of the
county to appear before the Housing Board of Appeals on the date specified in
the notice to show cause why the building or structure reported to be a
“dangerous building” should not be repaired, vacated or demolished in
accordance with the statement of particulars set forth in the Housing Code
Inspector’s notice provided for herein in § 92.004(F);



   (B)   Hold a hearing and hear testimony as the Housing Code
Inspector or the owner, occupant mortgagee, lessee or any other person having
an interest in the building as shown by the land records of the Recorder of
Deeds of the county shall offer relative to the “dangerous building;”



   (C)   Make written findings, of fact from the testimony offered
pursuant to division (B) as to whether or not the building in question is a
“dangerous building” within the terms of § 92.001 hereof;



   (D)   Issue an order based upon findings of fact made pursuant to
division (C) commanding the owner, occupant, mortgagee, lessee, agent and all
other persons having an interest in the building as shown by the land records
of the Recorder of Deeds of the county, to repair, vacate or demolish any
building found to be a “dangerous building” within the terms of this
chapter and provided that any person so notified, except the owners, shall
have the privilege of either vacating or repairing the “dangerous
building”; or any person not the owner of the “dangerous building” but
having an interest in the building as shown by the land records of the
Recorder of Deeds of the county may demolish the “dangerous building” at
his or her own risk to prevent the acquiring of a lien against the land upon
which the “dangerous building” stands by the city as provided in division
(E) hereof;



   (E)   If the owner, occupant, mortgagee or lessee fails to comply
with the order provided for in division (D) hereof, within ten days, the
Housing  Code Inspector shall cause the building or structure to be
repaired, vacated or demolished as the facts may warrant, under the standards
hereinbefore provided for in § 92.002 of this chapter, and shall with the
assistance of the City Attorney cause the costs of the repair, vacation or
demolition to be charged against the land on which the building existed as a
municipal lien or cause the costs to be added to the tax duplicate as an
assessment or to be levied as a special tax against the land upon which the
building stands or did stand or to be recovered in a suit at law against the
owner; provided, that in cases where the procedure is desirable and any delay
thereby caused will not be dangerous to the health, morals, safety or general
welfare of the people of this city, the Housing Code Inspector shall notify
the City Attorney to take legal action to force the owner to make all
necessary repairs or demolish the building; and



   (F)   Report to the City Attorney the names of all persons not
complying with the order provided for in division (D) above.



(Ord. 394, passed 5-6-1980)



§ 92.006  DUTIES OF CITY ATTORNEY.



   The City Attorney shall:



   (A)   Prosecute all persons failing to comply with the terms of the
notices provided for herein  in §§ 92.004(E) and (F), and the order
provided for in § 92.005(D);



   (B)   Appear at all hearings before the Housing Board of Appeals in
regard to dangerous buildings;



   (C)   Bring suit for collect all municipal liens, assessments or
costs, incurred by the Housing Code Inspector in repairing or causing to be
vacated or demolished dangerous buildings; and



   (D)   Take any other legal action as is necessary to carry out the
terms and provisions of this chapter.



(Ord. 394, passed 5-6-1980)



§ 92.007  EMERGENCY CASES.



   In cases where it reasonably appears that there is immediate danger to
the life or safety of any person unless a dangerous building as defined
herein is immediately repaired, vacated or demolished, the Building Inspector
shall report the facts to the Housing Code Inspector and the Housing Board of
Appeals shall cause the immediate repair, vacation or demolition of the
dangerous building. The costs of an emergency repair, vacation or demolition
of the dangerous building shall be collected in the same manner as provided
in § 92.005(E) hereof.



(Ord. 394, passed 5-6-1980)



§ 92.008  WHEN OWNER ABSENT FROM THE CITY.



   In cases, except emergency cases, where the owner, occupant, lessee or
mortgagee is absent from the city, all notices or orders provided for herein
shall be sent by registered mail to the owner, occupant, mortgagee, lessee
and all other persons having an interest in the building as shown by the land
records of the Recorder of Deeds of the county to the last known address of
each, and a copy of the notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the
“dangerous building”to which it relates. The mailing and posting shall be
deemed adequate service.



(Ord. 394, passed 5-6-1980)



§ 92.009  ADMINISTRATIVE LIABILITY.



   No officer, agent or employee of the city shall render himself or
herself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or
property as result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his
or her duties under this chapter. Any suit brought against any officer, agent
or employee of the city as a result of any act required or permitted in the
discharge of his or her duties under this chapter shall be defended by the
City Attorney until the final determination of the proceedings therein.



(Ord. 394, passed 5-6-1980)



§ 92.010  DUTIES OF FIRE DEPARTMENT.



   The employees of the Fire Department shall  make a report in writing
to the Housing Code Inspector of all buildings or structures which are, may
be, or are suspected to be “dangerous buildings” within the terms of this
chapter. The reports must be delivered to the Housing Code Inspector within
24 hours of the discovery of the buildings by any employee of the Fire
Department.



(Ord. 394, passed 5-6-1980)



§ 92.011  DUTIES OF POLICE DEPARTMENT.



   All employees of the Police Department shall make a report in writing
to the Housing Code Inspector of any buildings or structures which are, may
be or are suspected to be “dangerous buildings” within the terms of this
chapter. The reports must be delivered to the Housing Code Inspector within
24 hours of the discovery of the buildings by any employee of the Police
Department.



(Ord. 394, passed 5-6-1980)



§ 92.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   The owner of any “dangerous building” who shall fail to
comply with any notice or order, to repair, vacate or demolish the building
given by any person authorized by this chapter to give the notice or order
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined
not exceeding $500 for each offense and a further sum of $10 for each and
every day the failure to comply continues beyond the date fixed for
compliance or 90 days imprisonment or in the discretion of the court both a
fine and imprisonment.



   (B)   The occupant or lessee in possession who fails to comply with
any notice to vacate and who fails to repair the building in accordance with
any notice given as provided for in this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not exceeding $500 for
each offense and a further sum of $10 for each and every day the failure to
comply continues beyond the date fixed for compliance or 90 days
imprisonment, or in the discretion of the court both a fine and imprisonment.



   (C)   Any person removing the notice provided for in § 92.004(I)
hereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined
not exceeding $500 for each offense.



(Ord. 394, passed 5-6-1980)



CHAPTER 93:  NUISANCES



Section



Junk, Trash, Abandoned Vehicles and the Like



   93.001   Definitions



   93.002   Determination



   93.003   Trash and abandoned vehicles—misdemeanor

   93.005   Abandoned dwellings—misdemeanor

Noxious Weeds and Vegetation



   93.035   Purpose



   93.036   Definitions

   93.038   Duty of occupant or owner

Trash; Abandoned and Junk Vehicles; Abandoned Dwellings; Storage of Building

   93.046   Junk automobiles—civil infraction
