   (F)   Living or sleeping rooms.  No living or sleeping rooms in
direct connection with any part of the restaurant will be tolerated.



(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923; Am. Ord. 271, passed 7-3-1962)  Penalty, see §
119.999



§ 119.005  CONDUCT OF BUSINESS.



   (A)   No licensee shall permit any disorderly conduct in his or her
place of business, nor shall any licensee permit his or her place of business
to become a resort or meeting place for thieves, prostitutes or other
disorderly persons, nor shall any licensee permit any gambling in his or her
place of business or permit the placing or use of any gambling apparatus or
paraphernalia about his or her premises, nor shall any licensee permit any
lewd, obscene or immoral exhibition or entertainment on his or her premises
or any other conduct likely to corrupt the morals of the youth.



   (B)   Licensees providing entertainment, amusement, exhibitions,
music or places for dancing shall comply with and abide by all rules and
regulations of the Police Department and other proper authorities relating
thereto.



   (C)   All licensees operating under Class A licenses may open their
places of business at 5:00 a.m. and remain open not later than 2:00 a.m. of
the following morning and no longer.



   (D)   No licensee operating under a Class A license shall sell,
procure for, or furnish, directly or indirectly, to any minor under the age
of 21 years, any beer, wine, whiskey or other intoxicating liquor, nor permit
any minor to loiter in or about his or her place of business.



   (E)   No licensee operating under a Class A license shall employ any
person under the age of 21 years to do any work in connection with that place
of business.



(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923; Am. Ord. 121, passed 12-28-1933)  Penalty, see
§ 119.999



§ 119.006  HOURS OF OPERATION.



   Whenever the business shall be carried on in conjunction with some
other form of business which, under a provision of the regulations regulating
the same, shall be required to close at a particular hour or remain closed
until a particular time, then the business herein proposed to be licensed
shall be closed according to the provisions of the regulations covering the
business operated in connection therewith.



(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.007  FEES TO BE DEPOSITED IN GENERAL FUND.



   The money derived from the issuance of the licenses shall be turned
over to the City Treasurer and deposited in the General Fund of the city.



(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.008  REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE.



   (A)   The City Council may, at any time, for sufficient cause proved
to the satisfaction of the Council after notice and hearing, suspend or
revoke any license granted under the provisions of this subchapter and order
the business so licensed to be closed.



   (B)   After the notice closing the business, no business of the
nature herein proposed to be licensed shall be conducted or carried on in the
place until a new license shall have been issued under the provisions of this
subchapter and the issuance thereof approved by the City Council or the
suspension imposed by the City Council be lifted.



(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923)  Penalty, see § 119.999




PUBLIC MARKETS




§ 119.020  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   HUCKSTER.  Any person who sells food or other products not produced,
manufactured or made by himself or herself, which he or she has purchased for
resale, by virtue of or which have been consigned for him or her for sale.



   MARKET MASTER.  Any person who, by virtue of owning, leasing, or
controlling vacant property, rents or leases, stands, stalls or places the
same thereon for the buying and selling of articles of food.



   PERSON.  All natural persons, firms, partnerships, corporations and
all associations of natural persons, incorporated or unincorporated, whether
acting by themselves or by a servant, agent or employee. All PERSONS who
violate any of the provisions of this subchapter, whether as owner or as
agent, servant or employee, shall, except as herein otherwise provided, be
equally liable as principals.



   PRODUCER.  Any person who vends in a public market, articles or
products grown or produced by him, her or any member of his or her family
residing with him or her upon property owned, rented or controlled by him or
her. It shall include any person who represents exclusively a non-profit
association of producers of farm products which markets the products produced
by its members.



   PUBLIC MARKET or MARKET PLACE.  A place on vacant property used for
buying and selling farm products and the accommodation of producers’ and
hucksters’ wagons in which the products are brought to or taken from the
place.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930; Am. Ord. 153, passed 11-29-1935; Am. Ord. 158,
passed 10-6-1936)



§ 119.021  PUBLIC MARKET; LICENSE REQUIRED.



   No person shall establish or conduct a public market or market place as
herein defined within the corporate limits of the city without first having
obtained a license from the City Clerk. Application for the license shall be
made in writing to the City Clerk and shall be upon printed blanks to be
furnished by the City Clerk, which shall set forth, among other things, the
place where the business is to be conducted, the name, age, residence and
previous experience of the applicant. If the applicant be a partnership, the
names and addresses of all partners and the name under which the business is
to be conducted shall be given. If the applicant is a corporation, the names
and addresses of all the officers and the name of the corporation shall be
given. The application shall, before the issuance of the license, be referred
to the health officer, who shall make an investigation and recommendation to
the City Clerk within a reasonable time after the filing of the application.
If the City Clerk is satisfied that the applicant is a suitable person to
conduct a public market or market place, has never been convicted of a
felony, that the proposed public market or market place is equipped with one
automatic dial scale of 300 pounds capacity and one computing scale of 100
pounds capacity, sealed by the Sealer of Weights and Measures (the scales to
be located for the convenience of customers in checking the weights of
purchases), then he or she shall grant the license upon the payment to the
City Treasurer of a license fee in the amount of $200 and the filing with the
City Clerk of a surety company bond in the amount of $1,000 conditioned for
the faithful observance of the terms of this subchapter or any ordinance
amendatory thereof or supplemental hereto. Provided, however, that no license
shall be granted to any person, firm, partnership or corporation to operate
or conduct a public market or market place within a radius of 2,000 feet of
any other market or market place licensed under the provisions of this
subchapter.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930; Am. Ord. 105, passed 8-18-1932; Am. Ord. 150,
passed 10-24-1935)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.022  PRODUCER OR HUCKSTER; LICENSE REQUIRED.



   (A)   No producer or huckster shall engage in his or her business in
a public market or market place within the corporate limits of the city
without first having obtained a licence therefor from the City Clerk.
Application for a producer’s license to engage in business in a public
market or market place shall be made in writing upon blanks furnished by the
City Clerk, giving the name, age, address and previous experience of the
applicant, the names and kinds of the products he or she produces and intends
to sell at the market, the place where he or she raises the products, the
names of all persons in his or her employ who shall appear at the market to
sell the products the names of all persons employed by him or her at the
premises where he or she raises the products and any other information as may
be deemed necessary for the protection of the public welfare and the proper
enforcement of this subchapter, together with an agreement that, if license
is granted to him or her, he or she will not allow or permit anyone to sell
his or her products in a market other than the members of his or her
immediate family or the persons actually employed by him or her in the
raising of produce and that a violation of the agreement shall be sufficient
cause for the revocation of his or her license. The City Clerk may require
all information to be sworn to be the applicant. The application shall be
referred to the health officer who shall make an investigation and
recommendation to the City Clerk within a reasonable time after receiving the
application. If the City Clerk if satisfied that the applicant is a suitable
person to engage in the business, has not been convicted of any felony, or
the offense of short weight, or been barred from any public market, he or she
shall grant the license and issue the same upon the payment to the City
Treasurer of the license fee of $1.



   (B)   Application for huckster’s license shall be made in writing
upon blanks furnished by the City Clerk, giving the name, age, address and
previous experience of the applicant, the names and kinds of the products he
or she intends to sell at the market and any other information as may be
deemed necessary for the protection of the public welfare and the proper
enforcement of this subchapter. The City Clerk may require all information to
be sworn to by the applicant. The application shall be referred to the health
officer who shall make an investigation and recommendation to the City Clerk
within a reasonable time after receiving the application. If the City Clerk
is satisfied that the applicant is a suitable person to engage in the
business, has not been convicted of a felony, or the offense of short weight,
or been barred from any public market, he or she shall grant a license and
issue the same upon the payment to the City Treasurer of the license fee of
$25.



   (C)   At the time of the issuance of the license, the City Clerk
shall give to each producer or huckster a suitable plate to be displayed by
the licensee in a conspicuous place at the stall where he or she engages in
his or her business in the public market. No producer or huckster shall
operate more than one stall under one license.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930; Am. Ord. 105, passed 8-18-1932)  Penalty, see §
119.999



§ 119.023  RESTRICTION FOR HUCKSTER.



   No huckster who has been licensed to peddle on the streets and alleys
of the city shall do business within 500 feet of any public market. The
huckster shall not do business in any public market in the city unless he or
she first obtains the license required by this subchapter. It shall be
unlawful for any producer to sell his or her products on the streets, alleys
or public places of the city without first obtaining a license therefor.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.024  ARTICLES ALLOWED TO BE SOLD IN PUBLIC MARKETS.



   (A)   The following articles are allowed to be sold in public
markets or market places: any article of food or food products of any nature
whatsoever, provided that the handling, sale and storage of same complies
with all sanitary regulations of the Health Department and the regulations of
the city. It shall be unlawful to sell, display, expose or offer for sale any
other articles than food or food products in a public market, or to sell,
display, expose or offer for sale, or demonstrate or solicit patronage for
any business, merchandise, goods or real estate.



   (B)   The term FOOD as used herein, shall include all articles used
for food, drink, confectionery or condiment intended to be eaten or drank by
man or other animals, whether simple, mixed or compound.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930; Am. Ord. 126, passed 7-3-1934)  Penalty, see §
119.999



§ 119.025  INSPECTION.



   All articles of food in a public market shall be subject to the
inspection of the health officer at all reasonable times.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.026  PRODUCTS UNLAWFUL TO SELL.



   It shall be unlawful to sell, offer or expose for sale in any public
market any adulterated, bad, diseased, impure or unwholesome articles of food
or food products. It shall be the duty of the market master to prevent the
display of those articles.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.027  GARBAGE AND RUBBISH RECEPTACLES.



   The market master shall furnish suitable garbage and rubbish
receptacles of a number and type required and approved by the health officer
of the city. It shall be his or her duty to cause producers and hucksters to
deposit all garbage and rubbish in the receptacles.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.028  SANITATION REQUIREMENTS.



   Producers and hucksters are hereby required to thoroughly clean their
stalls, stands or places after market hours and before leaving the same. No
person shall deposit vegetable refuse or other garbage, broken crates, boxes,
barrels or pieces thereof, paper or other rubbish in any place in a public
market except in the proper permanent concrete or iron or steel receptacles
which shall be erected by the market master. It shall be unlawful to burn any
garbage or rubbish in any public market.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.029  UNLAWFUL TO RENT TO UNLICENSED PERSON.



   It shall be unlawful for a market master to rent or allow the use of
any stall stand or place in any public market or market place to any person
who is not licensed under the provisions of this subchapter.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.030  REVOCATION OF LICENSE.



   A violation of the provisions of this subchapter, a conviction of the
charge of having violated any other ordinance of the city, repeated verified
complaints against any producer or huckster who sells in a public market,
giving reasonable conclusive evidence that the person has practiced deception
in his or her dealings in the market by displaying or selling his or her
produce so packed and faced as to misrepresent the average quality or
condition of the produce in the package, or by knowingly giving false
information regarding the origin, variety, quality, condition or value of the
products which he or she sells, or by similar sharp practices, shall, in
addition to any other penalties which may be inflicted, be cause for the City
Council to bar the person from the privileges and grounds of the public
markets for a period of time as may be deemed advisable by the Council and to
revoke the license issued to the person. The action shall be preceded by a
hearing before the City Council at which the person involved shall have an
opportunity to fully present his or her defense against the charges made
against him or her. It shall be unlawful for the market master to permit any
person barred as aforesaid by the City Council to occupy any place in or do
business in a public market.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.031  LICENSES AND RECEIPTS TO BE DISPLAYED AND FURNISHED.



   All producers and hucksters shall display their licenses and furnish
signed receipts for goods purchased upon request. Stalls, stands or places
occupied by hucksters in a public market shall be plainly designated as that
by appropriate signs furnished by the market master and approved by the
health officer or City Manager’s designee.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.032  HEALTH OFFICER SUPERVISION.



   Public markets and market places shall be under the supervision of the
health officer of the city or any officer so authorized by the City Manager.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930)



§ 119.033  EXPIRATION OF LICENSE.



   All licenses issued hereunder shall expire on May 30 each year unless
sooner revoked by the City Council for cause. No license shall be issued for
less than one year, nor shall any license be assigned or transferred to any
other person.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.034  BUILDING AND EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS.



   Before the health officer or City Manager’s designee shall approve
the application for a public market or market place, he or she shall be
satisfied that the building and equipment for the business conform to the
following rules.



   (A)   Floor.  Tight and solid, constructed of concrete or similar
substance, easily washed and flushed.



   (B)   Garbage and rubbish receptacles.  Of a number and type
required by the health officer with covers.



   (C)   Equipment.  Permanent roof over dressed meat, fish and
poultry. Cases and counters containing meat, fish and poultry to be protected
by partitions of glass, wood or metal so erected as to keep the same in a
cleanly and sanitary manner to meet the approval of the food inspector of the
city, the meat, fish and poultry to be kept and displayed so that it shall
not be exposed to the elements.



   (D)   Drainage facilities.  To be approved by the health officer or
City Manager’s designee.



   (E)   Adequate toilet facilities.  For men and women.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.035  HOURS OF OPERATION.



   (A)   Public markets and market places licensed under the provisions
of this subchapter shall be closed at 6:00 p.m. each day, with the exception
of Thursday of each week, and kept closed until 4:00 a.m. of the following
day; on Thursday of each week the public markets and market places shall be
closed at 8:00 p.m. and kept closed until 4:00 a.m. of the following day.



   (B)   Provided, however, that the markets and market places shall be
closed all day on the first day of each week, commonly called Sunday.



   (C)   After the closing of the public markets and market places, it
shall be the duty of the market master to see that the place is thoroughly
cleaned and the floors flushed.



(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930; Am. Ord. 105, passed 8-18-1932)  Penalty, see §
119.999




SALE OF TAINTED MEAT, VEGETABLES AND OTHER FOODSTUFFS




§ 119.050  PROHIBITING THE SALE OR OFFERING FOR SALE, OR HAVING IN
POSSESSION FOR THE PURPOSE OF SELLING OR OFFERING FOR SALE, OF ANY DECAYED,
TAINTED OR SPOILED MEATS, VEGETABLES OR OTHER FOOD STUFFS.



   No person or firm or corporation shall sell, offer for sale, or have in
possession for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any decayed,
tainted or spoiled meat, vegetables or food stuffs of any kind, within the
city.



(Ord. 60, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.051  VIOLATION.



   Each and every person who shall sell, offer for sale, or have in
possession for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any decayed,
tainted or spoiled meat, vegetables, food stuffs of any kind within the city,
either as principal, officer, agent or employee shall be deemed to be
violating the provisions of this subchapter.



(Ord. 60, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.052  KEEPING TAINTED FOOD NEAR GOOD FOOD PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE OF
VIOLATION.



   The having or keeping of any decayed, tainted or spoiled meat,
vegetables or food stuffs of any kind in any refrigerator, ice box or case,
wherein are usually kept good meat, vegetables or other food stuffs to be
sold or offered for sale in the city, shall be deemed prima facie evidence of
the violation of terms of this subchapter.



(Ord. 60, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.053  INSPECTION.



   It shall be the duty of the health officer and food inspector of the
city or City Manager’s designee to investigate the premises in every case
where there is reasonable ground to believe that decayed, tainted or spoiled
meat, vegetables or food stuffs of any kind are being sold, offered for sale,
or had in the possession for the purpose of offering for sale, and for that
purpose the officers shall have the right at reasonable hours to enter the
premises of any store, meat market, butcher shop, restaurants or lunch room
where meat, vegetables or any other food stuffs whatsoever are publicly or
offered for sale.



(Ord. 60, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999




SALE OF FRESH OR SMOKED MEAT




§ 119.065  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   No person or persons, firm or corporation shall, own, operate, or
conduct any business consisting, wholly or in part of the sale of fresh or
smoked meats at retail within the city, without first securing from the Clerk
a license therefor, as hereinafter provided.



(Ord. 64, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.066  CITY CLERK AUTHORIZATION.



   The City Clerk of the city is hereby authorized and directed to issue
license to any person or persons, firm or corporation to own, operate, or
conduct within the city a business consisting wholly or in part of the sale
of fresh or smoked meats at retail upon filing with the Clerk a bond, to be
approved by the City Council, in the sum of $100, conditioned upon the
faithful compliance by the licensee with all the provisions of the state laws
now or hereafter enacted relating to the business of selling fresh or smoked
meats at retail and all ordinances, or parts of ordinances, of the city now
in effect or which may be hereafter adopted relating in any way to the
business of selling fruit or smoked meats at retail within the city. Before
the license shall be issued there shall be paid to the City Treasurer the
license fee of $1. The license when issued shall entitle the licensee to
conduct business until April 1 next following the issuance of the license,
unless revoked sooner by the City Council for cause.



(Ord. 64, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.067  RESTRICTING HANDLING BY PUBLIC.



   No fresh or smoked meats shall be exposed for sale upon any counter,
block or slab, in any meat market, butcher shop, store, stall or booth in
which fresh or smoked meats are sold at retail in the city in a manner as to
permit handling by the general public, but shall be protected by partitions
of glass, wood or metal, so erected as to keep the same in a clean and
sanitary manner to meet the approval of the food inspector.



(Ord. 64, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.068  SANITARY CONDITIONS REQUIRED.



   Every meat market, butcher shop, store, stall or booth in the city in
which fresh or smoked meats are sold at retail shall be kept in a neat,
orderly, clean and sanitary condition, subject  at all reasonable hours to
inspection by the proper officials of the city.



(Ord. 64, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.069  SANITARY TRANSPORT OF GOODS.



   All fresh or smoked meats carried or transported to, or from, any meat
market, butcher shop, store, stall or booth, in the city, where fresh or
smoked meats are sold at retail shall be so carried and transported only in
vehicles that are kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and all fresh meats
carried therein, shall at all times, be kept clean and protected by proper
coverings from dust, flies and filth.



(Ord. 64, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.070  MEAT FROM UNFIT ANIMALS.



   No person shall sell, offer or expose for sale, at retail, or barter or
trade, the meat of any animal which is in any way crippled, diseased,
emaciated or otherwise unfit for human food.



(Ord. 64, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.071  MEAT FROM CALF LESS THAN FOUR WEEKS OLD.



   No person shall sell, offer or expose for sale at retail, or barter or
trade, the meat of any calf less than four weeks old.



(Ord. 64, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.072  MEAT PURCHASED FROM SOURCE OTHER THAN A UNITED STATES INSPECTED
ESTABLISHMENT.



   Every person, firm or corporation licensed under the provisions of this
subchapter shall report to the food inspector of the city, within 24 hours
thereafter, the matter of the purchase of any fresh meat or meat food
products purchased from any other source than from a United States inspected
establishment or a slaughtering or meat food product manufacturing
establishment, licensed by either the Detroit Board of Health or the City
Council; the report shall give the name and address of the persons from whom
the meat or meat products, are purchased, together with a statement and
description of the articles comprising the purchase.



(Ord. 64, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.073  PERSONAL HYGIENE.



   Each and every person handling fresh meats at retail, either as owner,
butcher, clerk or employee, in any meat market, butcher shop, store, stall or
booth, in  the city, shall at all times keep himself or herself and all
parts of his or her clothing in a clean and sanitary condition, and no person
who shall be affected with any vile, contagious diseases shall be at any time
permitted to handle or sell any fresh meats at retail within the city.



(Ord. 64, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.074  SANITARY REFRIGERATORS, MEAT COUNTERS, BLOCKS, TOOLS, UTENSILS
AND APPARATUS REQUIRED.



   All ice boxes, refrigerators, meat counters, blocks, tools, utensils
and apparatus used in connection with any business of selling fresh meats at
retail within the city shall be kept in a neat, clean and sanitary condition.



(Ord. 64, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.075  FORFEITURE OF LICENSE.



    Any person or persons, firm or corporation, selling fresh or smoked
meats at retail within the city who, or which, shall be convicted of the
violation of any of the terms of this subchapter shall, in addition to all
other penalties prescribed by law or ordinance, as punishment for the
violation, be liable to forfeiture of license granted under the provisions of
this subchapter, upon proper action by the City Council.



(Ord. 64, passed 8-2-1928)  Penalty, see § 119.999




SALE OF FOOD TO THE PUBLIC IN BULK




§ 119.090  PERMANENT STRUCTURE OR BUILDING REQUIRED.



   No person or persons, firm, partnership or corporation shall, own,
operate or cause to be operated within the city, any business conducted for
the purpose of selling articles of food unless the business is operated in a
permanent structure or building meeting the requirements of the Building
Code, without first obtaining a license therefore from the Clerk and
complying with the terms of this subchapter.



(Ord. 106, passed 10-25-1932)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.091  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   STORE, SHOP AND PLACE OF BUSINESS, WHERE FOOD IS SOLD TO THE PUBLIC. 
Shall not be deemed to include restaurants or meat markets, nor the wagons or
vehicles used by hucksters or peddlers or parks primarily used for amusement
purposes, or markets.



(Ord. 106, passed 10-25-1932)



§ 119.092  CITY CLERK AUTHORIZATION.



   (A)   The City Clerk is hereby authorized to grant a license to any
person of good character, or to any partnership or corporation, to engage in
the business of operating or conducting a store, shop or other place of
business for the sale of food to the public in bulk upon receiving from the
applicant the proper certificate from the Health Department as hereinafter
provided, and upon payment to the City Treasurer of the sum of $1 as a
license fee.



   (B)   The license shall cover but one place of business, which shall
be stated therein. Provided, that the license fees shall not be in lieu of
the license fees required to be paid under the provisions of the regulations
of the city relative to the sale of baked goods or any other specific food
products for the sale of which regulations are now in effect or may be
hereafter adopted providing for the license of the same.



   (C)   Every license shall expire on December 31 of each year.



(Ord. 106, passed 10-25-1932; Am. Ord. 111, passed 5-2-1933)



§ 119.093  CERTIFICATE FROM HEALTH DEPARTMENT.



   Before the City Clerk shall issue any license provided for in §
119.090, the applicant shall furnish him or her a certificate from the Health
Department stating that the establishment where applicant conducts, or
intends to conduct, the  business is a proper place in which to conduct the
business.



(Ord. 106, passed 10-25-1932)



§ 119.094  APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE.



   Blank applications for the certificate shall be issued by the Health
Department. The applications shall contain the information as shall be
required by the Health Department, and shall further contain an agreement by
which the applicants consent to have the inspectors of the Health Department
enter, examine, and inspect any part of the premises used in conducting such
business, or any produce or food sold or for sale therein, and to take
samples of the food for the purpose of analysis. The applications shall
further contain an agreement that the premises occupied by the business shall
be provided with sanitary toilets having at least one stool therein for every
25 persons employed on the premises, and with suitable and sanitary wash
rooms and toilet facilities, and with sanitary refuse receptacles, and with
floors that can be properly cleansed and flushed, and that the applicants
will at all times keep the floors thereof properly cleansed and flushed. The
applications shall further contain an agreement that the applicant agrees to
conform to the rules and regulations of the Health Department relative to the
conduct of the business. The Health Department is authorized to issues
certificates upon application of any person, firm or corporation desirous of
engaging in or continuing to engage in the business, after determining that
the place or establishment where the applicants conduct or intend to conduct
the business is a proper place in which to conduct the business. No
determination shall be made until the Health Department determines by
inspection that the premises meet with all the requirements of this section.



(Ord. 106, passed 10-25-1932)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.095  REFUSAL TO ISSUE OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE.



   The City Clerk is hereby authorized to refuse to issue a license, or
the Council may revoke a license upon satisfactory proof that the applicant
is not of good character, or is not the proper person to have a license, or
that the applicant conducts the place or establishment in violation of the
rules of the Health Department, or that the place or establishment where he
or she conduct ths business is not a proper place in which to conduct the
business, or that the place or establishment does not comply with all of the
requirements of § 119.094, or that the place or establishment is not kept
and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition at all times.



(Ord. 106, passed 10-25-1932)



§ 119.096  VIOLATION.



   The conviction of any licensee on the charge of having violated any of
the provisions of this subchapter shall be cause for suspension or revocation
of his or her license.



(Ord. 106, passed 10-25-1932)



§ 119.097  GARBAGE AND REFUSE.



   No person shall deposit vegetable refuse or other garbage, broken
crates, boxes, barrels, or pieces thereof, paper, or other rubbish on or in
the place or establishment, nor burn any garbage or rubbish in a place or
establishment, except in places which may be provided for that specific
purpose.



(Ord. 106, passed 10-25-1932)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.098  LICENSE REQUIRED FOR EACH BUSINESS.



   Where several businesses for selling articles of food are conducted
under one roof by separate individuals, partnerships, associations or
corporations, each owner of the business shall be required to secure a
license in accordance with the provisions herein.



(Ord. 106, passed 10-25-1932)



§ 119.099  COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.



   Any person, partnership, association or corporation now operating any
business conducted of the purpose of selling articles of food at the present
time in noncompliance with this subchapter shall have 90 days from the date
at which this subchapter becomes effective to comply with the provisions
herein.



(Ord. 106, passed 10-25-1932)




SALE OF FOOD SUPPLIES AND FOOD PRODUCT AT RETAIL




§ 119.110  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   No person, firm, corporation, association or partnership shall operate,
maintain, open or establish, any business consisting wholly or in part of the
sale of food supplies and food products at retail within the city, without
first having obtained a license therefor as hereinafter provided.



(Ord. 101, passed 11-10-1931)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.111  APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.



   Every person, firm, corporation, association or partnership desiring to
operate, maintain, open or establish within the city a business consisting
wholly or in part of the sale of food supplies and food products at retail,
shall make application for a license therefor to the City Clerk of the city,
on a form prescribed and furnished by the City Clerk, which application shall
set forth the name of the owner, manager, trustee lessee, receiver or other
person desiring the license, the name of the store, the location, including
the street number of the store, and the other facts as the City Clerk may
require. If the applicant desires to operate, maintain, open or establish
more than one place of business, he or she shall make a separate application
for a license to operate, maintain, open or establish each place of business,
but the respective places for which the applicant desires to secure licenses
may all be listed on one application blank.



(Ord. 101, passed 11-10-1931)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.112  APPLICATION AND CITY CLERK.



   (A)   As soon as practicable after the receipt of the application,
the City Clerk shall carefully examine the same to ascertain whether it is in
proper form and contains the necessary and requisite information, If, upon
examination, the City Clerk shall find that any application is not in proper
form and does not contain the necessary and requisite information, he or she
shall return the application for correction.



   (B)   If an application is found to be satisfactory, and if the
license fee as herein prescribed shall have been paid, the City Clerk shall
issue to the applicant a license for each place of business for which an
application for license shall been made.



   (C)   Each licensee shall display the license so issued in a
conspicuous place in the place of business for which the license is issued.



(Ord. 101, passed 11-10-1931)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.113  LICENSE FEE.



   (A)   Every person, firm, corporation, association or copartnership,
opening, established, operating or maintaining one or more places of business
within the city under the same general management, supervision or ownership,
shall pay the license fees hereinafter prescribed:



      (1)   The license fee for one place of business consisting,
wholly or in part of the sale of food supplies and food products at retail
shall be $25.



      (2)   The license fee for two places for business under the
same general management, supervision or ownership, shall be $50 for each
place of business.



      (3)   The license fee for three places of business under the
same general management, supervision or ownership, shall be $75 for each
place of business.



      (4)   The license for four or more places of business under
the same general management, supervision or owners shall be $1,000 for each
place of business.



   (B)   The license, when issued, shall entitle the licensee to
conduct the business until April 15 next following, the issuance of the
license, unless sooner revoked by the City Council for cause. The license fee
shall be paid to the City Treasurer before the issuance of the license and,
in case the time intervening between the date of application and the date of
expiration shall be less than one year, the City Treasurer shall receive the
prorata amount of the license fee, which however, in no case shall be less
than one-half thereof.



(Ord. 101, passed 11-10-1931)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.114  PARTIES COVERED BY THESE PROVISIONS.



   The provisions of this subchapter shall be construed to apply to every
person, firm, partnership, corporation or association, either domestic or
foreign, which is controlled on held with others by majority stock ownership,
or ultimately controlled or directed by one management or association of
ultimate management.



(Ord. 101, passed 11-10-1931)  Penalty, see § 119.999




POULTRY




§ 119.155  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   (A)   No person shall engage in the business of a wholesale
slaughter poultry dealer, wholesale poultry dealer, retail poultry dealer or
retail stand dealer in the city unless he or she shall has obtained a license
therefor from the City Clerk; and no dealer shall vend poultry on or off the
streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city; all sales to be in a building only.



   (B)   Nothing in this subchapter shall be construed:



      (1)   To prevent any farmer from killing, dressing and
selling, in the open market, unless diseased, any poultry intended for food
that he or she has raised, fed or slaughtered, nor any dealer or merchant
from buying or selling the same as provided by, state law;



      (2)   As affecting interstate commerce; or



      (3)   To prevent a hauler from bringing poultry into the city
and to sell or consign same to a licensed wholesale dealer; but the handling,
killing, dressing, sale, purchase or merchandising of the poultry shall be
subject to the terms of this subchapter to the extent that same does not
conflict with any state or federal law.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.156  FEE.



   (A)   Annual licenses of a poultry dealer under this subchapter
shall be issued in the name of the City Clerk to any person who qualifies as
herein provided.



   (B)   The City Clerk shall charge and collect as follows:



 

Wholesale slaughter poultry dealer
 

$25 per year



Wholesale poultry dealer
 

$25 per year



Retail poultry dealer
 

$10 per year



Retail stand of live poultry
 

$5 per year




 



   (C)   All licenses required in this subchapter shall expire on May 1
of each year.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.157  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   PERSON.  Individuals, partnership, firm, association or corporation.



   RETAIL POULTRY DEALER.  Every person, individual, partnership, firm,
association or corporation not a wholesale poultry dealer who deals in and/or
sells poultry at retail.



   VEHICLE.  The conveyance in which the poultry is carried, and includes
automobile, truck, wagon or cart.



   WHOLESALE POULTRY DEALER.  Every person, individual, partnership,
firm, association or corporation:



      (1)   Operating a regularly established store or warehouse for
the purchase, sale or consignment of poultry at wholesale in the city, or who
deals in, purchases, sells or offers for sale or delivery at wholesale any
poultry used or intended for human consumption; or



      (2)   Not operating a regularly established store or warehouse
for the sale of poultry at wholesale in the city who deals in, sells or
offers for sale or delivery at wholesale any poultry used or intended for
human consumption, by traveling from place to place or along or upon the
streets, alleys or public thoroughfares of the city from one prospective
buyer to consignee to another, and offers to sell or consign, or does sell or
consign and/or delivers from a vehicle poultry to another person, who buys or
receives the poultry for re-sale in some form, and not for personal
consumption.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)



§ 119.158  DISEASED POULTRY.



   No person shall sell, offer or expose for sale at retail, wholesale, or
trade, any poultry afflicted with downers, tuberculosis, gaps, swollen heads
or eyes, other disease or defects which render the poultry unfit for human
food. The city veterinarian, or health inspector in consultation with the
city veterinarian, shall have the power to condemn, seize and destroy all
poultry unfit for human consumption, under the rules and regulations as the
Board of Health may adopt.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.159  CONFORMANCE TO SANITARY REQUIREMENTS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to bring within the limits
of the city, to be sold or offered for sale therein at wholesale or retail,
any poultry for any slaughterhouse situated outside its limits, whose owner,
lessee or occupant has not substantially conformed to the sanitary
requirements of the Board of Health.



   (B)   The Board of Health is hereby authorized to require from any
person an affidavit or other satisfactory proof of compliance with this
provision.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)



§ 119.160  REGULATIONS GOVERNING POULTRY SLAUGHTERHOUSES.



   Application for the approval of plans and specifications and for permit
shall be made by the owner of the site to the Department of Health, upon
official blanks furnished for that purpose by the Department. No permit to
conduct a poultry slaughterhouse shall be issued by the Department of Health
unless the, plans and specifications of the proposed slaughterhouse shall
have been approved by the Department.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.161  FLOOR SPACE.



   The floor space of the building used as a poultry slaughterhouse shall
cover an area of at least 550 square feet in order to permit the receipt and
delivery of poultry and poultry in crates and the storage of empty crates,
entirely within the premises of the poultry slaughterhouse.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.162  PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS.



   (A)   Application for the approval of the plans and specifications
of the poultry slaughterhouse proposed to be erected shall be made upon
official forms furnished by the Department of Health and duplicate copies of
the plans and specifications shall be submitted with the application.
Specifications shall be submitted with all plans, explaining in detail the
work to be done and the material to be used, and where the work to be done is
shown on the plans and not mentioned in the specifications or where mentioned
in the specifications and not shown on the plans, it shall be taken as
mentioned in both.



   (B)   Duplicate copies of the plans and specifications shall be
submitted and when the plans and specifications are approved, construction
work must be started within 90 days thereafter, and the work shall be
continuous until completed in a thorough, workmanlike manner.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.163  CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE OF POULTRY SLAUGHTERHOUSE.



   No permit to conduct a poultry slaughterhouse will be issued by the
Department of Health unless, the following  minimum requirements as to
construction shall have been in each instance fully complied with in
accordance with the approved plans and specifications.



   (A)   Floors, construction.  The floors shall be constructed of
cement, concrete or other approved water-tight, non-absorbent material, so
graded and drained as to discharge all liquid matter in properly trapped
sewer in compliance with the Building Code.



   (B)   Ceilings and walls.  The ceilings shall be of a smooth, hard
impervious material free from crevices, cracks, ledges or projections. The
walls shall be of cement, concrete or other approved water-tight,
non-absorbent material with a smooth finish to the entire height of the
ceiling and shall be painted. The junctions with the ceilings and floors
shall be maintained in a tight and sanitary manner.



   (C)   Height of ceilings.  All ceilings shall be at least ten feet
in height, measured from the surface of the floor to the ceiling.



   (D)   Ventilation.  Adequate ventilation to extend ten feet above
adjacent properties to the external air by natural means shall be provided
for every room in which poultry is stored, killed or which is used in
connection with the slaughterhouse, and in compliance with the Building Code
of the city.



   (E)   Lights. Adequate natural or artificial light approved by the
Department of Health shall be provided in every room in which poultry is
stored or killed.



   (F)   Killing room.  A separate room shall be provided which shall
be used as a killing room, which shall have an area of at least 80 square
feet. The width or length of this room shall not be less than eight feet. A
bleeding trough must be provided; it shall be of adequate capacity and be
approved by the Department of Health. The walls and face of the trough must
be of cement, concrete or other approved water-tight, non-absorbent material
with a smooth finish and shall discharge over properly trapped and sewer
connected drains. A proper metal receptacle shall be provided to hold each
bird after being slaughtered, the receptacle shall be placed where the
poultry may be disposed of in a sanitary manner. The provisions of this
regulation shall not apply to a poultry slaughterhouse in which a wholesale
business is carried on principally, except that poultry shall be killed in
places in receptacles approved by the Department of Health.



   (G)   Dry plucking rooms.  Where dry plucking is the method always
employed, a separate room shall be provided, which shall be used exclusively
for the dry plucking of poultry killed at the premises. The area of this room
shall be at least 100 square feet. The width or length of this room shall not
be less than eight feet. The walls shall be constructed of approved
water-tight, nonabsorbent tile or brick, and the floor and ceiling shall be
constructed of non-absorbent, water-proof material; floor to be graded and
drained. Proper receptacles shall be provided for the holding, storing or
keeping of all feathers.



   (H)   Waiting room.  A separate room shall be provided as a waiting
room for the customers. The area of this room shall be at least 550 square
feet.



   (I)   Storage; crates or batteries.  A separate room shall be
provided for the storage of live poultry in crates or batteries. The area of
this room shall be at least 270 square feet. Cages or batteries shall be
elevated at least one foot above the floor level and shall not be placed
nearer than two feet from the side walls of the building.



   (J)   Water supply.  Permanent fixtures shall be provided for the
furnishing of an adequate supply of fresh water for flushing all parts of the
premises.



   (K)   Rat-proofing.  The room or receptacle for the storage of food
for the poultry shall be constructed rat-proof.



   (L)   Toilet facilities.  Adequate water-closet accommodation for
male and female persons shall be provided, and sufficient fixtures with hot
and cold running water for washing purposes shall be provided at all times;
the toilet room or rooms shall be ventilated to the outside air by a direct
or an approved indirect method.



   (M)   Screening.  All doors, windows and other openings to the
outer air shall be properly and adequately screened. All doors shall be
equipped with self closing devices.



   (N)   Hot water.  Adequate facilities shall be provided to ensure a
sufficient supply of running hot water at all times.



   (O)   Odors.  Suitable and adequate means shall be provided for the
disposal of offensive odors.



   (P)   Empty crates.  A separate room shall be provided for the
storage of empty crates.



   (Q)   Garbage disposal.  All garbage shall be disposed by Saturday,
midnight, by the operators of the poultry business. It shall be unlawful for
the operators or their employees to deposit the garbage in the alleys or
other public places. The garbage shall be burned in incinerators or carried
out beyond the confines of the city.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.164  PERMIT.



   The application for the permit to conduct a poultry slaughterhouse
shall be made upon official forms furnished by the Department of Health. No
permit will be unless the plans and specifications of the proposed poultry
slaughterhouse shall have first been approved by the Department in accordance
with the provisions of these regulations.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)



§ 119.165  MAINTENANCE.



   Every poultry slaughterhouse shall be conducted in strict compliance
with the following rules which shall govern the maintenance and operation.



   (A)   Cleanliness.  Every poultry slaughterhouse, the yard
adjoining same and all air shafts, courts and open places connected therewith
shall be at all times kept in a clean, sanitary condition, free from
accumulation of refuse, garbage and offensive material and nuisances of all
kinds.



   (B)   Floors; washing.  All floors shall be kept and maintained in
a clean, sanitary condition and in good repair and free from rubbish and
offensive material.



   (C)   Walls; cleaning.  The side walls of all rooms used for the
storage or killing of poultry shall be kept in a clean, sanitary condition
and in good repair. Walls and ceilings shall be cleaned and painted whenever
required by the Department of Health.



   (D)   Ventilation.  All parts of every poultry slaughterhouse shall
be properly ventilated and adequately lighted at all times.



   (E)   Plumbing.  All plumbing fixtures and toilet facilities shall
be kept and maintained in a clean, sanitary condition and in good repair.



   (F)   Plucking room.  All plucking of poultry shall be done
exclusively in the plucking room.



   (G)   Feather receptacles.  Plucking of poultry shall be performed
in a manner that all feathers shall be thrown or placed in the receptacles
provided for the purpose.



   (H)   Storage of empty crates.  All empty crates shall be kept and
stored exclusively in the storage room. The area of this room shall be at
least 150 square feet. No empty crates shall be kept or permitted to remain
outside of the poultry slaughterhouse.



   (I)   Poultry at large; prohibited.  No poultry shall be allowed or
permitted at large upon the premises but shall be kept at all times in the
batteries or crates provided for that purpose.



   (J)   Screens.  The screens, windows, doors and other openings to
the outer air shall be kept clean and in good and repair.



   (K)   Doors not to be left open.  All doors shall be half-closing
and not permitted to remain open except for ingress or egress.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.166  STRUCTURAL CHANGES.



   No structural change or alterations shall be made in any poultry
slaughterhouse building unless the same shall have first been approved or
ordered by the Department of Building or the Department of Health.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.167  DEVIATION FROM SUBCHAPTER.



   In existing poultry slaughterhouses, where it would be impracticable or
unreasonable to require strict compliance with this subchapter, the health
officer with the approval of the City Council may permit deviation therefrom.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)



§ 119.168  PERMITS; RENEWAL ANNUALLY.



   Permits to carry on or conduct a poultry slaughterhouse in the city
shall be granted by the Department of Health of the city for each poultry
slaughterhouse conducted or maintained in the city and each permit shall
expire on May 1 of the calendar year following the issue thereof, and shall
be renewed annually before the expiration thereof.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)



§ 119.169  NEW PERMIT.



   Upon proof by report from the Inspector of the Department of Health
that the premises on which a poultry slaughterhouse permit has been issued by
the Department of Health has become vacant or has not been used or is
discontinued for use as a slaughterhouse for the period of six months or
more, or where the permittee has died, or where the premises has been
destroyed by fire, a new permit must be obtained and new plans and
specifications filed, passed upon and approved by the Department of Health,
as herein provided.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)



§ 119.170  BASEMENTS.



   No poultry shall be killed in any basement.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.171  NOT APPLICABLE TO BUTCHER.



   The terms and provisions of this subchapter shall not apply to a
regular licensed butcher who slaughters 50 or less fowl per week upon his or
her own premises.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)



§ 119.172  ENFORCEMENT.



   The Department of Health shall be charged with the enforcement of this
subchapter, and the Department of Health is hereby authorized to adopt the
rules and regulations as may be necessary to carry into effect the provisions
of this subchapter.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)




BAKERY




§ 119.185  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   It shall not be lawful for any person, firm or corporation to carry on
or conduct the trade or business of a baker, either in person or by employing
any other person to carry on the trade or business under his, her or its
direction within the city, without having obtained from the Clerk a license
for that purpose.



(Ord. 40, passed 7-14-1925)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.186  APPLICATION.



   Every person, firm or corporation desirous of carrying on or conducting
the trade or business shall make application in writing to the Clerk of the
city for a license, setting forth the street number of the place of business
in which the trade or business is intended to be carried on. The Clerk shall
have power to grant the license upon the payment of $5. All licenses shall
expire upon May 1 next following the issuance of the same. The Clerk shall
record in a book, to be kept in his or her office for public inspection, the
name, street and number of the place of business of each person, firm or
corporation to whom the license shall be issued.



(Ord. 40, passed 7-14-1925)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.187  CERTIFICATE REQUIRED.



   Before the Clerk shall issue any license, the applicant shall furnish
to him or her a certificate from the Board of Health stating that the
establishment where the applicant conducts or is about to conduct the
business is a proper place in which to conduct the business. The Board of
Health is hereby authorized to issue the certificate upon application of any
person, firm or corporation desirous of engaging in or of continuing to
engage in the business. Blank applications for the purpose shall be issued by
the Board of Health. Applications shall contain the information, having
relation to the health of the city, as shall be required by the Board of
Health; and shall further contain an agreement by which the applicant
consents to the inspectors of the Board of Health having the right to enter
the premises where the business is conducted for the purpose of examining or
inspecting same, or any bread or other baked goods manufactured or kept
therein. The application shall further contain an agreement on the part of
the applicant that he or she will conform to the rules and regulations of the
Board of Health relative to the conduct of the business.



(Ord. 40, passed 7-14-1925)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.188  SANITARY CONDITIONS REQUIRED.



   (A)   Every licensee shall conduct his or her establishment in a
cleanly and sanitary manner.



   (B)   No licensee shall sell or offer for sale or manufacture any
bread or other goods baked or prepared by him or her which are not clean and
wholesome and which would be deleterious to health.



(Ord. 40, passed 7-14-1925)  Penalty, see § 119.999




FOOD HANDLER CARD




§ 119.200  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   FOOD ESTABLISHMENT.  Any place in the city in which food or beverage
is served or sold for human consumption on the premises or elsewhere. The
establishments shall include, but not be limited to, restaurants, cafeterias,
coffee shops, taverns, soda foundations, itinerant restaurants, bakeries and
grocery stores.



   VENDOR.  Anyone who transports, distributes  or operates equipment to
transport or distribute food for human consumption in the city.



(Ord. 270, passed 6-5-1962)



§ 119.201  CARD REQUIRED.



   No person shall be employed or shall work in a food handling
establishment in the city or be employed as a vendor unless he or she has a
food handler’s card from the Board of Health of the city as hereinafter set
forth.



(Ord. 270, passed 6-5-1962)  Penalty, see § 119.999



§ 119.202  APPLICATION.



   Applicants for the food handlers cards in the city shall file an
application for the card with the Board of Health of city on forms approved
by the Board of Health, which shall issue the food handlers card to the
applicant, when a negative chest x-ray report has been approved and filed by
the Board of Health.



(Ord. 270, passed 6-5-1962)



§ 119.203  ANNUAL FEE.



   Before the food handlers’ card is issued to any applicant by the
Board of Health, the applicant shall pay to the City Treasurer an annual fee
of $2, and the food handlers’ card issued to the applicant shall be
effective from the date of the issue until April 30 next following. Providing
however, that person handling food for fraternal, religious, educational,
social or civic organizations and not in their employ shall not required to
pay the fee. Cards issued without payment of fee shall be effective only in
conjunction with food handling in the fraternal, religious, educational,
social or civic organizations.



(Ord. 270, passed 6-5-1962)  Penalty, see § 119.999



MOBILE FOOD VEHICLE VENDORS



§ 119.220  SHORT TITLE.



   This subchapter may be referred to as the City of Hamtramck Mobile Food
Vehicle Ordinance.



(Ord. 2013-052, passed 3-12-2013)



§ 119.221  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purposes of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   MOBILE FOOD VEHICLE. A motorized vehicle which may upon issuance of a
license by the City Clerk and conformance with the regulations established by
this subchapter may temporarily park upon a public street and engage in the
service, sale or distribution of ready to eat food for individual portion
service to the general public directly from the vehicle.



   MOBILE FOOD VEHICLE VENDOR. The registered owner or a mobile food
vehicle or the owner’s agent or employee; and referred to in this
subchapter as “vendor.”



(Ord. 2013-052, passed 3-12-2013)



§ 119.222  SCOPE.



   The provisions of this subchapter apply to mobile food vehicles engaged
in the business of cooking, preparing and distributing food or beverage with
or without charge upon or in public and private restricted spaces. This
subchapter does not apply to vehicles which disperse food and that move from
place to place and are stationary in the same location for no more than 15
minutes at a time, such as ice cream trucks. This subchapter does not apply
to mobile food vehicles participating in special events sponsored or approved
by the city.



(Ord. 2013-052, passed 3-12-2013)



§ 119.223  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, including any religious,
charitable or nonprofit organization, to operate within the city a mobile
food vehicle without having obtained from the City Clerk a current and valid
license for that purpose.



   (B)   A person or organization desiring to operate a mobile food
vehicle shall make written application for such license to the City Clerk and
shall include the following:



      (1)   Name, signature, phone number, email contact and
business address of the applicant.



      (2)   A description of the preparation methods and food
product offered for sale including the intended menu.



      (3)   Information on the mobile food vehicle to include year,
make, and model of the vehicle and dimensions, which shall not exceed 36 feet
in length or nine feet in width.



      (4)   Information setting forth the proposed hours of
operation, area of operations, plans for power access, water supply and
wastewater disposal.



      (5)   Copies of all necessary license or permits issued by the
Wayne County Health Department.



      (6)   Insurance coverage:



         (a)   Proof of general comprehensive liability policy
with limits of no less than $1,000,000 combined single limit coverage issued
by an insurer licensed to do business in the State of Michigan and which
names the city as an additional insured.



         (b)   Proof of public liability and property damage
motor vehicle policy with limits of no less than $1,000,000 issued by an
insurer licensed to do business in the State of Michigan.



   (C)   All vendors receiving a license under this subchapter shall
pay the annual fee as set from time to time by the City Council.



   (D)   The City Clerk shall issue no more than ten active mobile food
vehicle licenses for any calendar year. Each mobile food vehicle license
shall expire on June 30 of each year.



   (E)   A license issued under this subchapter shall not be
transferable from person to person.



   (F)   A license is valid for one vehicle only and shall not be
transferred between vehicles.



(Ord. 2013-052, passed 3-12-2013)



§ 119.224  REGULATIONS.



   (A)   No operator of a mobile food vehicle shall park, stand, or
move a vehicle and conduct business in areas of the city where the license
holder has not been authorized to operate. Mobile food vehicles are permitted
in the following locations: public parking spaces and commercial alleyways
fronting and adjacent to Joseph Campau, Conant, Caniff and Holbrook; public
parks as approved by the Department of Community and Economic Development.
Special locations may be authorized from time to time as approved by the
Department of Community and Economic Development after consultation and
approval from the Fire Chief and Police Chief.



   (B)   The customer service area for mobile food vehicles shall be on
the side of the truck that faces a curb, lawn, or sidewalk when parked. No
food service shall be provided on the driving lane side of the truck. No food
shall be prepared, sold, or displayed outside of mobile food vehicles.



   (C)   No mobile food vehicle vendor shall provide or allow any
dining area within ten feet of the mobile food vehicle, including but not
limited to tables and chairs, booths, stools, benches or stand up counters.



   (D)   Customers shall be provided with single service articles such
as plastic utensils and paper plates and a waste container for disposal. All
mobile food vehicle vendors shall offer a waste container for public use
which the vendor shall empty at its own expense. All trash and garbage
originating from the operation of mobile food vehicles shall be collected and
disposed of off-site by the operator(s) each day. Spills of food or food
by-products shall be cleaned up forthwith. No dumping of gray, or waste water
on the streets is permitted.



   (E)   No mobile food vehicle shall make or cause to be made any
unreasonable or excessive noise. The operation of all mobile food vehicles
shall be in compliance with the city noise ordinance, including generators.
No loud music, other high-decibel sounds, horns, or amplified announcements
are permitted.



   (F)   Signage is only allowed when placed on the mobile food
vehicles. No separate freestanding signs are permitted.



   (G)   No flashing or blinking lights, or strobe lights are allowed
on mobile food vehicles or related signage when the vehicle is parked and
engaged in serving customers. All exterior lights over 60 watts shall contain
opaque, hood shields to direct the illumination downward.



   (H)   Mobile food vehicles when parked on public streets shall be
parked in conformance with all applicable parking restrictions, and shall not
hinder the lawful parking or operation of other vehicles.



   (I)   A mobile food vehicle shall not be parked on the street
overnight or left unattended or unsecured at any time food is in the vehicle.
Any mobile food vehicle found to be unattended shall be considered a public
safety hazard and may be ticketed, towed and/or impounded.



   (J)   A vendor shall not operate a mobile food vehicle within 500
feet of any fair, festival, special event or civic event that is licensed and
sanctioned by the city unless the vendor has obtained permission from both
the city and event coordinator.



   (K)   The issuance of a mobile food vehicle license does not grant
or entitle the vendor to the exclusive use of any service route or parking
space.



   (L)   A vendor shall not operate on private property without first
obtaining written consent to operate from the affected private property
owner. A private property owner shall not permit parking by a mobile food
vehicle until a special use permit has been obtained to permit such use.



   (M)   No mobile food vehicle shall use external signage, bollards,
seating or other equipment not contained within the vehicle. When extended,
awnings for mobile food vehicles shall have a minimum clearance of seven feet
between the ground level and the lowest point of the awning or support
structure.



   (N)   Any power required for the mobile food vehicle located on a
public way shall be self- contained and a mobile food vehicle shall not use
utilities drawn from the public right-of-way. Mobile food vehicles on private
property may use electrical power from the property being occupied or an
adjacent property, but only when the property owner provides written consent
to do so. All power sources must be self-contained. No power cable or
equipment shall extend at or across any city street, alley, or sidewalk.



   (O)   Mobile food vehicles shall not be parked within 150 feet of an
existing, brick and mortar restaurant during the hours when such restaurant
is open to the public for business unless the owner has provide written
consent to do so. This does not include LCC establishment where the primary
source of revenue is generated from a source other than dining.



(Ord. 2013-052, passed 3-12-2013)



§ 119.225  ENFORCEMENT.



   (A)   Any license holder operating a mobile food vehicle in
violation of any provision of this subchapter or any rules and regulations
promulgated by the city shall be subject to a civil fine to be set by City
Council ordinance. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate and
distinct offense.



   (B)   Once a license has been issued it may be revoked, suspended or
not renewed by the City Clerk for failure to comply with the provisions of
this subchapter and any rules or regulations promulgated by the city.



(Ord. 2013-052, passed 3-12-2013)



§ 119.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Generally.  Any person violating any provision of this
chapter for which no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.999.



   (B)   Restaurants.  Any person, firm or corporation who or which
shall violate any of the provisions of §§ 119.001 through 119.008, or shall
fail to comply with the same, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine
of not less than $10 nor more than $100, together with costs of prosecution,
or by imprisonment in the Wayne County Jail for a period of not more than 90
days, or by both a fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court
trying the offender. In case any corporation shall be fined under the
provisions of §§ 119.001 through 119.008 it shall be lawful to collect the
fine and costs in an action of assumpsit to be brought in any court of
competent jurisdiction.



(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923)



   (C)   Sale of tainted meat, vegetables and other foodstuffs.



      (1)   Every person, firm or corporation convicted of violating
the provisions of §§ 119.050 through 119.053 shall be punished by a fine of
not to exceed $100 and costs of prosecution, and, in default of the payment
of the fine and costs, the court may make a further sentence that the
offender by imprisoned in the Wayne County Jail, or another place of
imprisonment as may be hereafter established by the City Council of city as a
place of confinement, until the fine and costs be paid, but not longer than
90 days, or, in the discretion of the Court having jurisdiction of the cause,
both a fine and imprisonment may be imposed.



      (2)   In the event that there shall be imposed upon a
corporation any fine and costs, or either, or both, for the violation of any
of the terms of §§ 119.050 through 119.053, then it shall be lawful to
collect the fine and costs, or either, or both, in an action of assumpsit
before any court of competent jurisdiction.



(Ord. 60, passed 8-2-1928)



   (D)   Sale of fresh meat or smoked meat.  Every person, firm or
corporation convicted of violating the provisions of §§ 119.065 through
119.075 shall be punished by a fine of not to exceed $100 and costs of
prosecution, and, in default of the payment of the fine and costs, the court
may make a further sentence that the offender by imprisoned in the Wayne
County Jail, or another place of imprisonment as may be hereafter established
by the City Council as a place of confinement, until the fine and costs be
paid, but not longer than 90 days, or, in the discretion of the Court having
jurisdiction of the cause, both a fine and imprisonment may be imposed. In
the event that there shall be imposed upon a corporation any fine and costs,
or either, or both, for the violation of any of the terms of §§ 119.065
through 119.075, then it shall be lawful to collect the fine and costs, or
either, or both, in an action of assumpsit before any court of competent
jurisdiction.



(Ord. 64, passed 8-2-1928)



   (E)   Sale of food to the public in bulk.  Any person, firm,
corporation, copartnership or association convicted of violating any of the
provisions of §§ 119.090 through 119.099 shall be punished by a fine not to
exceed $100 and costs of prosecution, or by imprisonment in the Wayne County
Jail, or another place of confinement as may be hereafter designated by the
City Council, for a period not to exceed 90 days, or both a fine and
imprisonment at the discretion of the court. In the event that there shall be
imposed upon any corporation any fine and costs, or either, or both, for the
violation of any of the terms of §§ 119.090 through 119.099, then it shall
be lawful to collect the fine and costs, or either, or both, in an action of
assumpsit before any court of competent jurisdiction.



(Ord. 106, passed 10-25-1932)



   (F)   Sale of food supplies and food product at retail.  Every
person, firm, corporation, association or copartnership who or which shall
violate or fail to comply with the provisions of §§ 119.110 through 119.114
shall upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not to exceed $100
and costs of prosecution and, in default of the payment of the fine and
costs, the court may make a further sentence that the offender be imprisoned
in the Wayne County Jail, or another place of imprisonment as may be
hereafter designated by the City Council as a place of confinement, until the
fine and costs be paid, but not longer than 90 days, or, in the discretion of
the court having jurisdiction of the cause, both the fine and imprisonment
may be imposed. In the event that there shall be imposed upon a corporation
any fine and costs, or either, or both, for the violation or failure to
comply with the terms of §§ 119.110 through 119.114, it shall be lawful to
collect the fine and costs, or either, or both, in an action of assumpsit
before any court of competent jurisdiction.



(Ord. 101, passed 11-10-1931)



   (G)   Poultry.  Any violation of or failure to comply with the
provisions of §§ 119.155 through 119.172 shall be punished by a fine of not
to exceed $100 and costs of prosecution, or by imprisonment in the city
prison, Wayne County Jail, or any workhouse in the state authorized to
receive prisoners from the city, for not to exceed 90 days, or by both a fine
and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 223, passed 8-22-1950)



   (H)   Bakery.  Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate
any of the provisions of §§ 119.185  through 119.188 or fail to comply
with the same shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not
more than $100 or by imprisonment far not more than 90 days in the Wayne
County Jail, or by both a fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the
court. In case of the conviction of any corporation of the violation of the
terms of §§ 119.185 through 119.188, the amount of the fine and costs
imposed upon a conviction, together with the costs of same, may be collected
in an action of assumpsit in any court of competent jurisdiction.



(Ord. 40, passed 7-14-1925)



   (I)   Food handler card.  Any person, firm, association or
corporation, who violates any of the provisions of §§ 119.200 through
119.203 shall be prosecuted and upon conviction of the violation shall be
guilty of misdemeanor and punished by a fine not exceeding the sum of $100 or
by imprisonment in the Wayne County Jail, or another place of confinement as
may be hereafter, establishment by the City Council, not exceeding 90 days,
or both a fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court having
jurisdiction of the cause.



(Ord. 270, passed 6-5-1962)



CHAPTER 120:  HANDBILL DISTRIBUTORS AND HOUSE-TO-HOUSE SOLICITORS



Section



   120.001   Purpose



   120.002   Definitions



   120.003   License required



   120.004   Application



   120.005   Investigation



   120.006   License fees



   120.007   Identification requirement



   120.008   Transfer of license



   120.009   Revocation of license



   120.010   Appeal



   120.011   Distribution



   120.012   Exemptions



 



   120.999   Penalty



§ 120.001  PURPOSE.



   To protect the people against the nuisance of, and incident to, the
promiscuous distribution of handbills and circulars, particularly commercial
handbills, with the resulting detriment and danger to public health and
safety, the public interest, convenience and necessity requires the
regulation thereof, and to that end the purposes of this chapter are
specifically declared to be as follows:



   (A)   To protect the people against the unlawful activities or
operations of solicitors or handbill distributors, by requiring the
registration of all such solicitors or handbill distributors, together with
the names of their employers, and by regulating the business of handbill and
advertising distribution through the imposition of reasonable license fees;



   (B)   To protect local residents against trespassing by solicitors
or handbill distributors upon the private property of such residents if they
have given reasonable notice that they do not wish to be solicited by such
persons or do not desire to receive handbills or advertising matter;



   (C)   To protect the people against the health and safety menace and
the expense incident to the littering of the streets and public places by the
promiscuous and uncontrolled distribution of advertising matter and
commercial handbills;



   (D)   To preserve to the people their constitutional right to
receive and disseminate information by distinguishing between the nuisance
created by the promiscuous distribution of advertising and commercial
circulars and the right to deliver noncommercial handbills to all who are
willing to receive the same.



(Ord. 2010-6, passed 5-11-2010)



§ 120.002  DEFINITIONS.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   DISTRIBUTE.  The act of handing out or delivering handbills or samples
to any structure within the city limits whether or not the handbill or sample
is affixed to that structure in some way or packaged in some manner in a box,
container, envelop, bag or like covering.



   HANDBILL.  Any printed or written matter, any sample or device,
dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or
otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature.



   HANDBILL DISTRIBUTOR.  Any person engaging or engaged in the business
for hire or gain of distributing samples or handbills, other than newspapers
distributed to subscribers thereof, and any person receiving compensation
directly or indirectly for the distribution of such handbill.



   HOUSE-TO-HOUSE SOLICITOR.  Any person, whether a resident of the city
or not, traveling either by foot or any type of conveyance from place to
place, from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to
