   132.999   Penalty




LARCENY




§ 132.001  LARCENY FROM THE CITY’S PUBLIC LIBRARIES.



   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to procure, or take
in any way from any public library in the city, or from the City Public
Library any book, pamphlet, map, chart, painting, picture, photograph,
periodical, newspaper, magazine manuscript or exhibit, or any part thereof,
with intent to convert the same to his or her own use and upon conviction
hereof violations shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $100 or by
imprisonment not to exceed 30 days, or by both a fine and imprisonment in the
discretion of the court.



(Ord. 196, passed 8-21-1944)



§ 132.002  LARCENY FROM VACANT BUILDINGS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to steal or
unlawfully remove or in any manner damage any fixture, attachment or other
property belonging to, connected with or used in the construction of any
vacant structure or building, whether built or in the process of construction
or to break into any vacant structure or building with the intention of
unlawfully removing, taking therefrom, or in any manner damaging any fixture,
attachment or other property belonging to, connected with or used in the
construction of the vacant structure of building, whether built or in the
process of construction, and upon conviction violations hereof, shall be
punished by a fine not to exceed $500 and costs of prosecution, or by
imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or by both a fine and imprisonment in the
discretion of the court.



(Ord. 196, passed 8-21-1944)



§ 132.003  LARCENY OF GOODS VALUED UP TO $100.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to steal
or unlawfully take any money, goods or property of any other person, firm or
corporation of the value of $100 or less.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city, while a
store is open to the public, to knowingly and willfully alter, transfer,
remove and replace, conceal or otherwise misrepresent the price at which
property is offered for sale, with intent not to pay for property or to pay
less than the price at which the property is offered for sale, if the
resulting difference in price is less than $100.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful, while a store is open to the public,
with intent to defraud, obtain or attempt to obtain money or property from
the store as a refund or exchange for property that was not paid for and
belongs to the store with a value of less than $100.



(Ord. 196, passed 8-21-1944; Am. Ord. 435, passed 10-12-1989)  Penalty, see
§ 132.999




BREAKING AND ENTERING




§ 132.015  BREAKING AND ENTERING OUTSIDE SHOWCASE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to break and enter, or
to attempt to break or enter without breaking at any time any outside
showcase or other outside enclosed counter used for the display of goods,
wares or merchandise with the intent to steal or to commit the crime of
larceny therein and upon conviction violations hereof, shall be punished by a
fine not to exceed $200 and costs of prosecution, or by imprisonment not to
exceed 90 days, or by both a fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the
court.



(Ord. 196, passed 8-21-1944)



§ 132.016  BREAKING AND ENTERING COIN BOX.



   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to maliciously and
wilfully, by and with the aid and use of any key, instruments, devices or
explosives, blow or attempts to blow or forces or attempts to force an
entrance into any coin box, depository box, newspaper coin box or other
receptacle established and maintained for the convenience of the public or of
any person or persons not making payment for any inside of merchandise or
service, wherein is contained any money or thing of value or for any person
to extract or obtain or attempt to extract or obtain therefrom any money or
thing of value so deposited or contained therein, and upon conviction hereof
violators shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $200 and costs of
prosecution, or by imprisonment not to exceed 90 days or by both a fine and
imprisonment within the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 196, passed 8-21-1944)




GRAFFITI




§ 132.030  PROHIBITION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person without authorization of the public
authority having supervision of the public property involved, or of the owner
of private property involved, to place or insert or cause to be placed or
inserted in any manner whatsoever any inscription drawing, mark and/or
graffiti on any street, sidewalk, alley, thoroughfare, public or private
building, monument, fence, structure, vehicle and/or real or personal
property of any type.



(Ord. 389, passed 3-11-1980)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.031  POSTING NOTICES AND SIGNS.



   All public authorities having supervision of public property may post
notices and signs to publicize the provisions of this subchapter.



(Ord. 389, passed 3-11-1980)




TRESPASS




§ 132.044  TRESPASS UPON LANDS OR PREMISES OF ANOTHER.



   A person shall not:



   (A)   Enter the lands or premises of another without lawful
authority after having been forbidden to do so by the owner or occupant or
the agent of the owner or occupant.



   (B)   Remain without lawful authority on the land or premises of
another after being notified to depart by the owner or occupant or the agent
of the owner or occupant.



(Ord. 2013-011, passed 1-22-2013)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.045  WITH INTENT TO COMMIT CRIME OR DAMAGE PROPERTY.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon lands or premises
owned by another or owned by any unit of government without lawful authority,
for the purpose of committing any crime or damaging any property thereon.



(Ord. 370, passed 12-6-1977)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.046  PROHIBITED WHERE NOTICE POSTED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon lands or premises
owned by another or owned by any unit of government, without lawful authority
where notice posted by the owner prohibits unauthorized entry thereon.



(Ord. 370, passed 12-6-1977)  Penalty, see § 132.999




DAMAGING SCHOOL PROPERTY




§ 132.060  DAMAGING.



   No person shall damage, destroy or deface any public, private or
parochial school building, or any building occupied by any public, private or
parochial school building or the grounds, out-buildings, fences, trees or
other appurtenances or fixtures belonging thereto.



(Ord. 298, passed 3-2-1965)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.061  NOISE, DISTURBANCE OR IMPROPER DIVERSION.



   No person shall wilfully or maliciously make or assist in making any
noise, disturbance or improper diversion, by which the peace, quietude or
good order of any public, private or parochial school is disturbed.



(Ord. 298, passed 3-2-1965)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.062  PROFANE, INDECENT OR IMMORAL LANGUAGE.



   No person shall use profane, indecent or immoral language or indulge in
indecent or immoral conduct in any building or on any property adjacent to
any building in the city occupied as a public, private or parochial school.



(Ord. 298, passed 3-2-1965)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.063  IMMEDIATE DEPARTURE WHEN DIRECTED.



   Any person found to be creating a disturbance in any private, public or
parochial school or on the surrounding school grounds shall leave immediately
when so directed by the principal or by any other person designated by the
principal.



(Ord. 298, passed 3-2-1965)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.064  NOT A REGULARLY ENROLLED STUDENT, TEACHER, PARENT OR OTHER
EMPLOYEE.



   No person who is not a regularly enrolled student, teacher, parent or
other employee shall enter and remain in any school building, whether public,
private or parochial, in the city, for any reason whatever unless the person
has received written permission from the principal or other person designated
by the principal, to be in any public, private or parochial school building.



(Ord. 298, passed 3-2-1965)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.065  BORROWING MONEY OR VALUABLES FROM STUDENT.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to borrow or attempt to borrow any
money or thing of value from any student in any public, private or parochial
school or on any public, private or parochial school property in the city or
during any time when any student is going to or returning from any regularly
scheduled session of any school without first obtaining the written approval
of the principal of the school or other person designated by the principal to
issue a written approval.



(Ord. 298, passed 3-2-1965)  Penalty, see § 132.999




DEFACING SERIAL NUMBERS




§ 132.080  CONCEALMENT OR MISREPRESENTATION OF IDENTITY.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership or corporation,
to conceal or misrepresent the identity of any motor, household appliance or
mechanical device by removing or defacing the manufacturer’s serial or
motor number or by altering or replacing any part of the motor, appliance or
mechanical device bearing the serial or motor number with a new or replaced
part upon which the proper serial or motor number has not been stamped or
placed.



(Ord. 219, passed 8-11-1949)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.081  POSSESSION NOT PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE OF VIOLATION.



   In all prosecutions under this subchapter, possession by any dealer,
distributor, wholesaler or person, firm, partnership or corporation in the
business of buying and selling of any motor, appliance or mechanical device
with the manufacturer’s serial or motor number removed, defaced or altered
or with a part bearing the number replaced by one on which the proper number
does not appear, shall be prima facie evidence of violation of the provision
of this subchapter.



(Ord. 219, passed 8-11-1949)  Penalty, see § 132.999




POLITICAL CAMPAIGN LITERATURE




§ 132.095  UNLAWFUL TO POST OR DISTRIBUTE NEAR CHURCH.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership or
association or any group of  persons to pass out, hand deliver or in any
other manner to distribute or post, or to induce, persuade or employ other
person or persons to pass out, hand, deliver or in any other manner to
distribute or post in any place in and about any property of any church or
other place of regular religious assembly or within 100 feet from the
property located within the city any printed, typewritten or written leaflet,
card, pamphlet, newspaper,  poster or any other printed or written matter or
literature or any photostats, stenciled copies or any other facsimile of
same, in furtherance of any political campaign in favor of or against any
candidate for any public office or in favor of or against any political,
public or legislative issue, question or proposal.



(Ord. 204, passed 1-7-1947)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.096  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CHURCH.  Any edifice, temple, chapel or building used exclusively for
the preaching of the word of Gospel and religious services according to the
liturgy, rituals or tenets of the religion or faith of the congregation
belonging thereto.



   OTHER PLACE OF REGULAR RELIGIOUS ASSEMBLY.  Any building which is
maintained regularly and principally for preaching of the word of Gospel and
for religious services and instructions in accordance with the accepted
practices of the congregation or in accordance with the liturgy, rituals or
tenets of the religious sect or denomination of the congregation belonging
thereto.



   PROPERTY.  Includes any edifice, temple, chapel or building used for
the religious services as defined in the definitions above and all the land
thereunder and next adjacent to it, and all other buildings located on the
land and used in furtherance of the religious purposes of the congregation,
whether the property is owned by or leased, rented or kept by or for the
church or other place of regular religious assembly.



(Ord. 204, passed 1-7-1947)



§ 132.097  PROHIBITION OF VOTING POLLS.



   This subchapter shall not be construed or defined as to prohibit the
establishment of voting polls on the property hereinbefore mentioned in this
subchapter for the purpose of conducting elections for the convenience of the
electors residing in the voting precinct or ward, within which the property
is located, or to post in the voting polls all necessary notices to the
election workers or to the voters as required by the election laws of the
state, or to post any other registration or election notices or notices of
the meetings of the Board of Review or near the  property as may be required
by the laws of state or the City Charter of the city.



(Ord. 204, passed 1-7-1947)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.098  NO PROHIBITION AGAINST PASSING OUT CAMPAIGN LITERATURE NEAR
CHURCH.



   This subchapter shall not be construed or defined as to prohibit the
passing out, handing, delivering or in any manner distributing in about any
property of any church or any other place of regular religious assembly of
any leaflet, card, pamphlet, newspaper, sign, poster or any other printed or
written matter or literature against any legislative proposal seeking to
restrict or interfere with the religious liberty, as guaranteed by the First
Amendment to the Constitution of the United States and by Article II, Section
3 of the Constitution of the state.



(Ord. 204, passed 1-7-1947)




DISCOUNTING OF SCRIP




§ 132.110  ACCEPTANCE AT FACE VALUE.



   No person, firm or corporation shall accept any scrip note or
certificate in lien of federal currency in exchange for any commodity or
other thing of value except at the face value of the scrip, note or
certificate.



(Ord. 112, passed 5-2-1933)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.111  LIABLE FOR AMOUNT OF DISCOUNT.



   Any person, firm or corporation accepting scrips, note or certificate
in violation of § 132.110 of this subchapter shall be liable to the person
from whom the scrip, note or certificate was accepted at less than face
value, for the amount of the discount placed upon it by the person, firm or
corporation, and shall also be liable to the fine and/or imprisonment
hereinafter provided for violation of the provisions of this subchapter.



(Ord. 112, passed 5-2-1933)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.112  RETURN OF SCRIP.



   Any holder of scrip, note or certificate who accepts any commodity or
other thing of value in exchange for scrip, note or certificate at less than
face value of same shall, upon tender back of the commodity or thing of value
so received, be given back the scrip, note or certificate.



(Ord. 112, passed 5-2-1933)



§ 132.113  PROHIBITION AGAINST HIGHER PRICE DUE TO PAYMENT BY SCRIP.



   No person, firm or corporation shall charge a higher price for any
commodity or other thing of value by reason of the fact that it is paid for
in scrip or other note or certificate issued in lieu of federal currency.



(Ord. 112, passed 5-2-1933)  Penalty, see § 132.999




ADVERTISING




§ 132.125  GENERALLY.



   Any person, firm, corporation or association who, with intent to sell
or in any way dispose of merchandise, securities, service or anything offered
by a person, firm, corporation or association, directly or indirectly, to the
public for sale or distribution or with intent to increase the consumption
thereof or to induce the public in any manner to enter into any obligation
relating thereto or any interest therein, makes, publishes, disseminates,
circulates or places before the public or causes directly or indirectly to be
made, published, disseminated, circulated or placed before the public in this
city, in a newspaper or other publication or in the form of a book, notice,
handbill, poster, bill, circular, pamphlet or letter or in any other way an
advertisement of any sort regarding merchandise, securities, service or
anything so offered to the public which advertisement contains any
representation or statement which is untrue, deceptive or misleading or
intended to subject any person to disadvantage or injury through the
publication of false or deceptive statements, shall be guilty of an offense
punishable as hereinafter provided. Provided, however, that the provisions of
this subchapter shall not apply to any owner, publisher, printer, agent or
employee of a newspaper or other publication, periodical or circular, who, in
good faith and without knowledge of the falsity or deceptive character
thereof, publishes, causes to be published or takes part in the publication
of the advertisement.



(Ord. 78, passed 9-18-1928)



§ 132.126  DECEPTIVE ADVERTISING.



   It shall be deemed deceptive advertising and a violation of the
provisions of this subchapter for any person, firm or corporation engaged in
the business of buying and selling new or second-hand furs, wearing apparel,
jewelry, furniture, pianos, phonographs, other musical instruments or other
similar commodities or any form of property, real, personal or mixed or in
the business of furnishing any kind of service, to advertise by “liner
ads” or otherwise, the articles, property or service for sale in a manner
indicating that the sale is being made by a private party or householder not
engaged in the business. Every person, firm or corporation engaged in any
business shall, in advertising goods, property or service for sale, either
through “liner ads” or otherwise, affirmatively and unmistakably indicate
or state that the seller is a business concern and not a private party.



(Ord. 78, passed 9-18-1928)



§ 132.127  PUBLISHER’S DUTIES.



   No newspaper or other publication or employee thereof, shall hereafter
accept advertisement for its classified or other columns without, at the
time, obtaining the name and address of the advertiser and making a record of
the same. The record shall be retained by the newspaper or other publication
obtaining the same for a period of two weeks and shall be subject to the
examination of any police officer. No newspaper or other publication or
employee thereof, shall knowingly accept any advertisement from any person,
firm or corporation engaged in any of the businesses mentioned in § 132.126
of this subchapter if the advertisement is made ostensibly by a private party
or does not affirmatively state that the advertiser is a business concern and
is not a private party.



(Ord. 78, passed 9-18-1928)



§ 132.128  SIGN TO BE POSTED.



   Any person, firm or corporation engaged in any of the businesses
mentioned in § 132.126 hereof, whether conducting the business in a store,
business block, residence or other building, shall at all times, keep a
conspicuous sign posted on the outside of his or her establishment and
another conspicuous sign in the salesroom, which sign shall clearly state or
indicate that the seller is a business concern and not a private party or
householder, provided that the exterior sign shall not be required where the
seller has no control over the exterior of the premises where the business is
conducted.



(Ord. 78, passed 9-18-1928)  Penalty, see § 132.999



§ 132.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Generally.  Any person violating any provision of this
chapter for which no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.999.



   (B)   Larceny.  Any person violating any of the provisions of §
132.003 shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not more than
$500 or imprisonment for a period of not more than 90 days, or both a fine
and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 435, passed 10-12-1989)



   (C)   Graffiti.



      (1)   Any person violating any provision of §§ 132.030 and
132.031 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.



      (2)   Any person violating any of the provisions §§ 132.030
and 132.031 shall upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine not to
$500 or imprisonment not to exceed 90 days or both a fine and imprisonment,
in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 389, passed 3-11-1980)



   (D)   Trespass.  Any person convicted violating any of the
provisions of §§ 132.045 and 132.046 shall be punished by a fine not to
exceed $500, or imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or by both a fine and
imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 370, passed 12-6-1977)



   (E)   Damaging school property.  Any person violating any of the
provision of §§ 132.060 through 132.065 shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount not
exceeding $500 or be imprisoned for a period not exceeding 90 days or be both
so fined and imprisoned, in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 298, passed 3-2-1965)



   (F)   Defacing serial numbers.  Any person, firm, co-partnership or
corporation violating any provision of §§ 132.080 and 132.081 shall, upon
conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than $500 or
imprisonment in the Wayne County Jail for a period not exceeding 90 days, or
by both  a fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 219, passed 8-11-1949)



   (G)   Political campaign literature.  Any person, firm,
corporation, partnership or association violating any provisions of  §§
132.095 through 132.098 shall be deemed as guilty of breach of peace and upon
conviction thereof by proper tribunal shall be punished by a fine not to
exceed $100, and/or costs of prosecution or imprisonment in the Wayne County
Jail for a period of not more than 90 days or both a fine and imprisonment,
in discretion of the court.



(Ord. 204, passed 1-7-1947)



   (H)   Discounting of scrip.  Every person, firm, corporation
convicted of violating any provision of §§ 132.110 through 132.113 shall be
punished by a fine or not to exceed $500 and costs of prosecution, and in
default of payment of the fine and costs, the court may make a further
sentence that the offender be imprisoned in the Wayne County Jail or another
place of imprisonment as may hereafter be established by the City Council as
a place of confinement until the fine and costs be paid but not longer than
90 days, or in the discretion of the court having jurisdiction of the cause,
both a fine and imprisonment may be imposed. In the event that there shall be
imposed upon any corporation any fine and costs, or either, or both, for the
violation of any of the provisions of this §§ 132.110 through 132.113, then
it shall be lawful to collect the fine and costs, or either, or both, in an
action of assumpsit before any court of competent jurisdiction.



(Ord. 112, passed 5-2-1933)



   (I)   Advertising.  Every person, firm, or corporation convicted of
violating, or failing to comply with the provisions §§ 132.125 through
132.128 shall be punished by a fine of not to exceed $500 and costs of
prosecution and, in default of the payment of the fine and costs, the court
may make a further sentence that the offender be imprisoned in the Wayne
County Jail, or another place of imprisonment as may be hereafter established
by the City Council as a place of confinement, until the fine and costs be
paid, but not longer then 90 days, or, in the discretion of the court having
jurisdiction of the cause, both a fine and imprisonment may be imposed. In
the event that there shall be imposed upon any corporation any fine and
costs, or either, or both, for the violation of any of the terms of §§
132.125 through 132.128, then it shall be lawful to collect the fine and
costs, or either, or both, in an action of assumpsit before any court of
competent jurisdiction.



(Ord. 78, passed 9-18-1928)



CHAPTER 133:  WEAPONS



Section



General Provisions



   133.001   Aiming firearms



   133.002   Aiming and discharging firearm



   133.003   Injury by discharge of firearm



   133.004   Possession or control of firearms while intoxicated



   133.005   Confiscation of firearms



Prohibiting the Possession, Sale and Advertising of Replica and Facsimile
Firearms



   133.020   Definitions



   133.021   Possession or transfer prohibited



   133.022   Display, market for sale or sale prohibited



   133.023   Advertisement prohibited



   133.024   Exemptions



   133.025   Permitted



   133.026   Drawing, exhibiting or brandishing prohibited



   133.027   Drawing, exhibiting or brandishing around peace officer,
firefighter, emergency medical technician or paramedic



   133.028   Seizure and forfeiture



Pistols



   133.040   Definition



   133.041   Presentation for safety inspection



Switch Blades



   133.055   Definition



   133.056   General prohibition



   133.057   Regarding minors under the age of 21



   133.058   Knives with blades more than three inches in length



   133.059   Exceptions



 



   133.999   Penalty




GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 133.001  AIMING FIREARMS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to intentionally,
without malice, point or aim any firearm at or toward any other person.



(Ord. 196, passed 8-21-1944)  Penalty, see § 133.999



§ 133.002  AIMING AND DISCHARGING FIREARM.



   It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to discharge, without
injury to another person, any firearm, while intentionally without malice,
aiming at or toward any person.



(Ord. 196, passed 8-21-1944)  Penalty, see § 133.999



§ 133.003  INJURY BY DISCHARGE OF FIREARM.



   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to maim or injure
any other person by the discharge of any firearm pointed or aimed
unintentionally, without malice at any person.



(Ord. 196, passed 8-21-1944)  Penalty, see § 133.999



§ 133.004  POSSESSION OR CONTROL OF FIREARMS WHILE INTOXICATED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city, while under the
influence of an alcoholic liquor, controlled substance or any other
exhilarating or stupefying drug, or the combination of alcoholic liquor and a
controlled substance, to carry, have in possession or control, or use in any
manner or discharge any firearms.



(Ord. 196, passed 8-21-1944; Am. Ord. 2013-010, passed 1-22-2013)  Penalty,
see § 133.999



§ 133.005  CONFISCATION OF FIREARMS.



   All weapons, guns, pistols or firearms carried, possessed or used
contrary to §§ 133.001 through 133.004 are hereby declared forfeited to the
city.



(Ord. 196, passed 8-21-1944)




PROHIBITING THE POSSESSION, SALE AND ADVERTISING OF REPLICA AND FACSIMILE
FIREARMS




§ 133.020  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   FIREARM.  Any weapon from which a dangerous projectile may be
propelled by using explosives, gas or air as a means of propulsion including
any shotgun, rifle, pistol or other device of a similar character.



   REPLICA OR FACSIMILE FIREARMS.  Any devices or objects made of
plastic, wood, metal or any other material which are replicas, facsimiles or
toy versions of, or are otherwise recognizable as a pistol, revolver,
shotgun, sawed-off shotgun, rifle, machine gun, rocket launcher, starter
pistol, air gun, inoperative firearm or other firearm. As used in this
subchapter, the words REPLICA OR FACSIMILE FIREARMS shall include, but are
not limited to, toy guns, theatrical production props, hobby models (either
in kit form or fully assembled) or any other devices which might reasonably
be perceived to be real firearms.



(Ord. 428, passed 8-11-1988)



§ 133.021  POSSESSION OR TRANSFER PROHIBITED.



   It is unlawful for any person to possess or transfer replica or
facsimile firearms within the corporate limits of the city.



(Ord. 428, passed 8-11-1988)  Penalty, see § 133.999



§ 133.022  DISPLAY, MARKET FOR SALE OR SALE PROHIBITED.



   It is unlawful for any person to display, market for sale or sell
replica or facsimile firearms within the corporate limits of the city.



(Ord. 428, passed 8-11-1988)  Penalty, see § 133.999



§ 133.023  ADVERTISEMENT PROHIBITED.



   It is unlawful for any person to place an advertisement in any
newspaper, magazine, handbill, sign, poster, other publications or other
advertising media with knowledge that the purpose of the advertisement, in
whole or in part, is to promote within the corporate limits of the city the
possession, transfer or sale of objects designed and manufactured as replica
of facsimile firearms.



(Ord. 428, passed 8-11-1988)  Penalty, see § 133.999



§ 133.024  EXEMPTIONS.



   The provisions of this subchapter shall not apply to replica or
facsimile firearms which, because of their distinct color, exaggerated size
or permanently affixed international blaze orange markings on the receiver
portions of the product and blaze orange plug recessed no more than six
millimeters from the muzzle end of the barrel, cannot reasonably be perceived
to be real firearms.



(Ord. 428, passed 8-11-1988)



§ 133.025  PERMITTED.



   (A)   The possession, manufacture, marketing, distribution and sale
of replica or facsimile firearms are permitted if the devices are possessed,
manufactured, distributed or sold:



      (1)   Solely for subsequent transportation in intrastate,
interstate or foreign commerce;



      (2)   Solely for lawful use in theatrical productions
including motion picture, television and stage productions; or



      (3)   Toy guns or firearms.



   (B)   The devices shall not be displayed to the general public or
sold for other uses within the corporate limits of the city regardless of
where manufactured or purchased.



(Ord. 428, passed 8-11-1988)



§ 133.026  DRAWING, EXHIBITING OR BRANDISHING PROHIBITED.



   It is unlawful for any person to draw, exhibit or brandish replica or
facsimile firearms or simulate the drawing, exhibiting or brandishing of
replica or facsimile firearms, in a rude, threatening or angry manner with
intent to frighten, vex, harass or annoy any other person.



(Ord. 428, passed 8-11-1988)  Penalty, see § 133.999



§ 133.027  DRAWING, EXHIBITING OR BRANDISHING AROUND PEACE OFFICER,
FIREFIGHTER, EMERGENCY MEDICAL TECHNICIAN OR PARAMEDIC.



   It is unlawful for any person, with knowledge that a peace officer,
firefighter, emergency medical technician or paramedic is engaged in the
performance of his or her duties, to draw, exhibit or brandish replica or
facsimile firearms in their presence.



(Ord. 428, passed 8-11-1988)  Penalty, see § 133.999



§ 133.028  SEIZURE AND FORFEITURE.



   Any replica or facsimile firearms possessed or sold, or displayed with
the intent to sell, or manufactured within the corporate limits of the city
with intent to sell in violation of this subchapter, or used in a rude,
threatening or angry manner, shall be seized and forfeited to the city.



(Ord. 428, passed 8-11-1988)  Penalty, see § 133.999




PISTOLS




§ 133.040  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   PISTOL.  Any firearm loaded or unloaded 30 inches or less in length or
any firearm loaded or unloaded, which by its construction and appearance
conceals it as a firearm.



(Ord. 330, passed 8-25-1970)



§ 133.041  PRESENTATION FOR SAFETY INSPECTION.



   Any person within the city who owns or comes into possession of a
pistol as defined in § 133.040, shall present the weapon for safety
inspection to the Chief of Police of the city. A certificate of inspection
shall thereupon be issued in triplicate, containing the name, age, address,
description and signature of the person presenting the pistol for inspection
together with a full description thereof, the original of the certificate
shall be delivered to the registrant, the duplicate thereof shall be mailed
within 48 hours to the Commissioner of the State Police and the triplicate
shall be retained and filed in the office of the Chief of Police. The
provisions of this section shall not apply to wholesale or retail dealers in
firearms or to collections of pistols kept solely for the purpose of display,
as relics, curios or antiques, not made for modern ammunition or permanently
deactivated.



(Ord. 330, passed 8-25-1970)  Penalty, see § 133.999




SWITCH BLADES




§ 133.055  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   DART.  A pointed weapon or stick, thrown by hand.



   SWITCH-BLADE or SELF-OPENING KNIFE.  A knife containing a blade or
blades which can be opened by depressing a button, pressure on the handle,
release of a spring or other mechanical contrivance.



(Ord. 191, passed 9-21-1943; Am. Ord. 287, passed 2-11-1964; Am. Ord. 300,
passed 5-27-1965)



§ 133.056  GENERAL PROHIBITION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, keep,
possess, use or loan any switch-blade or self-opening knife; provided, that
the prohibition of this section shall not apply to any one-armed person in
possession of a knife in connection with his or her living requirements.



(Ord. 191, passed 9-21-1943; Am. Ord. 287, passed 2-11-1964; Am. Ord. 300,
passed 5-27-1965)  Penalty, see § 133.999



§ 133.057  REGARDING MINORS UNDER THE AGE OF 21.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away
or loan to any minor under the age of 21 years any dart or knife.



(Ord. 287, passed 2-11-1964; Am. Ord. 300, passed 5-27-1965)  Penalty, see
§ 133.999



§ 133.058  KNIVES WITH BLADES MORE THAN THREE INCHES IN LENGTH.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to be in possession of a
knife with a blade more than three inches in length in any of the streets,
alleys, parks, boulevards or other public property or schools in the city or
in any dance hall, theater, amusement park, liquor establishment, store or
other private property generally frequented by the public for purposes of
education, recreation, amusement, entertainment, sport or shopping.



   (B)   This section shall not apply to any person in possession of
any knife when it is used or carried in good faith as a tool of honest work,
trade, business, sport or recreation when the person in possession of the
knife is actively engaged therein or actively engaged in going to or
returning from  honest work, trade, business, sport or recreation.



(Ord. 287, passed 2-11-1964; Am. Ord. 300, passed 5-27-1965)  Penalty, see
§ 133.999



§ 133.059  EXCEPTIONS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to be in
possession of any knife, dart or instrument of any description that could be
used for cutting or stabbing, in any of the streets, alleys, parks,
boulevards or other public property or schools in the city or in any dance
hall, theater, amusement park, liquor establishment, store or other private
property generally frequented by the public for purposes of education,
recreation, amusement, entertainment, sport or shopping; provided, that this
section shall not apply to any person under 21 years of age being in
possession of any knife when it is used or carried in good faith as a tool of
honest work, trade, business, sport or recreation or when used or carried in
good faith as equipment related to and required for any legitimate sport,
recreation or youth character building program (Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts and
the like), when actively engaged therein or actively engaged in going to or
returning from honest work, trade, business, sport, recreation or youth
character building program.



(Ord. 287, passed 2-11-1964; Am. Ord. 300, passed 5-27-1965)



§ 133.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Firearms.



      (1)   Except as provided in division (A)(2) below, conviction
for violation of any of the provisions of §§ 133.001 through 133.005 shall
be punished by a fine not to exceed $500 or by imprisonment of not more than
90 days or by both a fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 196, passed 8-21-1944)



      (2)   (a)   An individual without a concealed pistol permit
who has an alcohol content of .08 or more grams per 100 milliliters of blood,
per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine or because of the
consumption of alcoholic liquor, a controlled substance, or a combination of
alcoholic liquor and a controlled substance, the individual’s ability to
use a firearm is visibly impaired is guilty of a misdemeanor subject to
punishment of not more than 90 days imprisonment and a fine of not more than
$100 for carrying or possessing a firearm, or both, and not more than $500
for using or discharging a firearm, or both.



         (b)   An individual with a concealed pistol permit shall
be reported to the firearm licensing board and subject to the following
penalties depending on his or her blood alcohol level:



            1.   A civil infraction with a fine of up to $100
for a person with .02 to .079 BAC (blood alcohol level) or deemed to be
visibly impaired;



   



            2.   A misdemeanor punishable by up to 90 days
imprisonment and a $100 fine for a person with .08 to .099 BAC;



            3.   A misdemeanor punishable by up to 90 days
imprisonment and a $100 fine for a person with .10 or more BAC.



   (B)   Prohibiting the possession, sale and advertising of replica
and facsimile firearms.  Any person violating any of the provisions of §§
133.020 through 133.028 shall upon conviction thereof be subject to a fine of
not more than $500 or to imprisonment for a period of not more than 90 days
or to both a fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 428, passed 8-11-1988)



   (C)   Pistols.  Any person found guilty of violating §§ 133.040
and 133.041 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine
not to exceed $100 or imprisonment not to exceed 90 days and/or both a fine
and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 330, passed 8-25-1970)



   (D)   Switch blades.



      (1)   Any police officer of the city may and it shall be his
or her duty to arrest without process any person found violating any
provision of §§ 133.055 through 133.059.



      (2)   Any person violating any of the provisions of § 133.055
through 133.059 shall, upon conviction thereof, be subjected to a fine not
exceeding $500, or imprisonment in the Wayne County Jail for a period not
exceeding 90 days, or both a fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the
court.



(Ord. 191, passed 9-21-1943; Am. Ord. 287, passed 2-11-1964; Am. Ord. 300,
passed 5-27-1965; Am. Ord. 2013-010, passed 1-22-2013)

   134.999   Penalty




YOUTH TOBACCO AND MARIJUANA




§ 134.001  TITLE.



   This subchapter shall be known as the Youth Tobacco and Marijuana
Subchapter.



(Ord. 478, passed 12-18-2001)



§ 134.002  PURPOSE.



   By enacting this subchapter, the city is acting to protect the public
health, safety or general welfare of the residents.



(Ord. 478, passed 12-18-2001)



§ 134.003  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CHEWING TOBACCO.  Loose tobacco or a flat, compressed cake of tobacco
that is inserted into the mouth to be chewed or sucked.



   DRUG PARAPHERNALIA.  All equipment, products and materials of any kind
that are used, intended for use or designed for use in planting, propagating,
cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting,
producing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing,
containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise
introducing into the human body a controlled substance.



   MARIJUANA.  All parts of the plant Cannabis sativa L., growing or not
growing, the seeds thereof; the resin extracted from any part of the plant;
and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of
the plant or its seeds or resin. It does not include the mature stalks of the
plant, fiber produced from the stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of the
plant, any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or
preparation of the mature stalks, except the resin extracted therefrom,
fiber, oil or cake or the sterilized seed of the plant which in incapable of
germination.



   TOBACCO SNUFF.  Shredded, powdered or pulverized tobacco that may be
inhaled through the nostrils, chewed or placed against the gums.



(Ord. 478, passed 12-18-2001)



§ 134.004  USE OF TOBACCO PRODUCT BY MINORS; PROHIBITION.



   A person under 18 years of age shall not possess or smoke cigarettes,
cigars or marijuana or possess or chew, suck or inhale chewing tobacco,
tobacco snuff, tobacco or narcotic paraphernalia; or possess or use tobacco
in any other form, on a public highway, street, alley, park, sidewalk or
other land used for public purposes or in a public place of business,
education or amusement.



(Ord. 478, passed 12-18-2001)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.005  NONINTERFERENCE WITH RIGHT OF PARENT OR GUARDIAN.



   This subchapter does not interfere with the right of a parent or legal
guardian in the rearing and management of his or her minor children or wards
within the bounds of his or her own private premises.



(Ord. 478, passed 12-18-2001)



§ 134.006  ENFORCEMENT.



   Any police officer or official of the city designated by the Mayor
shall have full authority to enforce this subchapter.



(Ord. 478, passed 12-18-2001)




CURFEW




§ 134.020  PROHIBITION.



   It shall be unlawful for a minor to be on the public streets,
playgrounds, vacant lots or other unsupervised place if the minor is under 18
years of age, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. except Fridays
and Saturdays, when the time for minors 16 and 17 years of age shall be
between 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.



(Ord. 407, passed 7-26-1983)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.021  THEATERS, MOVING PICTURE SHOWS, BOWLING ROOMS AND OTHER PLACES
OF AMUSEMENT.



   It shall be unlawful for a minor to be in a theater, moving picture
show, bowling room or other place of amusement:



   (A)   If the minor is under 12 years of age, between the hours of
7:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.; and



   (B)   If the minor is 12 years of age and under 18 years of age,
between the hours of 9:30 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.; except Fridays and Saturdays
when the time for minors 16 and 17 years of age shall be between 10:30 p.m.
and 6:00 a.m.



(Ord. 407, passed 7-26-1983)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.022  BILLIARD OR POOL HALLS.



   It shall be unlawful for any minor under 17 years of age to remain in
or play billiards or pool in a billiard or pool hall; provided, that the
provisions of this section do not apply to private residences, private clubs,
schools, churches, duly licensed family hobby and recreation centers,
fraternal organizations or any other civic agency, organization or
institution.



(Ord. 407, passed 7-26-1983)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.023  CHILD UNDER SIXTEEN ENROLLED IN A DAY SCHOOL PROGRAM.



   It shall be unlawful for any child under 16 years of age or enrolled in
a day school program other than a college or university, to remain in any
restaurant, lunchroom, candy store, confectionery, bowling room, ice cream
parlor, in any theater or other public place of entertainment or any other
public place unless it is part of an organized school program, during the
school hours of the child.



(Ord. 407, passed 7-26-1983)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.024  EXCEPTIONS.



   The provisions of this subchapter do not apply to:



   (A)   A minor accompanied by his or her parent, legal guardian or
other adult person having the care or custody of the minor; or



   (B)   A minor going to or returning from work; provided that the
minor’s hours of employment do not violate state law; provided further that
the minor possesses a signed statement issued by his or her employer within
the previous 90 days setting forth the minor’s hours of employment; and
provided further that the minor shall be exempt from the requirements of this
subchapter for not more than one hour before the minor’s work day begins
and for not more than one hour after the minor’s work day ends.



(Ord. 407, passed 7-26-1983)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.025  DUTY OF BUSINESS OWNER/OPERATOR.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any theater owner, moving picture
operator, theater licensee, bowling room, poolroom, billiard room,
restaurant, lunch room, candy store, confectionery or ice cream parlor
proprietor or the operator, manager or employee of the establishment to
permit a minor to remain in any establishment contrary to the provisions of
this subchapter.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for the proprietor, manager or employee
of any theater, bowling room, restaurant, lunchroom, candy store,
confectionery or ice cream parlor or any other public place to permit a minor
to remain in any establishment during the respective school hours of the
child after due notification of the school hours of the child by the school
authorities, the police or the parents of the child.



(Ord. 407, passed 7-26-1983)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.026  DUTY OF PARENT, LEGAL GUARDIAN OR OTHER ADULT PERSON.



   It shall be unlawful for the parent, legal guardian or other adult
person having the care or custody of a minor under 18 years of age to
knowingly permit the minor to violate any provisions of this subchapter.



(Ord. 407, passed 7-26-1983)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.027  ILLEGAL TO ASSIST, AID, ABET OR ENCOURAGE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to assist, aid, abet or encourage
any minor to violate any of the provisions of this subchapter.



(Ord. 407, passed 7-26-1983)  Penalty, see § 134.999




SALE OF SPRAY PAINT




§ 134.040  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   SPRAY PAINT.  Any adherent pigmented substance dispersed in particles,
by means of an atomizer or applicator.



(Ord. 390, passed 3-25-1980)



§ 134.041  ILLEGAL TO POSSESS, BUY, TRANSFER OR RECEIVE POSSESSION.



   No person under 18 years of age shall possess, buy, transfer possession
or receive possession of spray paint.



(Ord. 390, passed 3-25-1980)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.042  ILLEGAL FOR PERSON TO ASSIST, AID, ABET OR ENCOURAGE POSSESSION
BY MINOR.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to assist, aid, abet or encourage
any person under 18 years of age to violate § 134.041.



(Ord. 390, passed 3-25-1980)  Penalty, see § 134.999




SALE OF LIQUOR




§ 134.055  FURNISHING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE WITHOUT PRESCRIPTION TO MINOR.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to give or furnish any alcoholic
beverage to a minor except upon authority of and pursuant to a prescription
of a duly licensed physician.



(Ord. 303, passed 8-24-1965)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.056  POSSESSION OF LIQUOR BY MINOR.



   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to
purchase, consume or knowingly possess any alcoholic liquor on any public
place or on private property or place or to knowingly possess, transport or
have under his or her control in any motor vehicle any alcoholic liquor,
unless the person is employed by a licensee under the Michigan Liquor Control
Code of 1998 and is possessing, transporting or having the alcoholic liquor
in a motor vehicle under his or her control during regular, working hours and
in the course of his or her employment.



(Ord. 303, passed 8-24-1965; Am. Ord. 2013-12, passed 1-22-2013)  Penalty,
see § 134.999



§ 134.057  FREQUENTING TAVERNS.



   No minor person under the age of 21 years shall enter in, frequent or
remain in any tavern, saloon, bar room or other place within the corporate
limits of the city where spiritous or other intoxicating liquors are sold,
given away or furnished for consumption upon the premises and no proprietor,
keeper, manager or other person shall permit any child to enter in, frequent
or remain in any place or shall encourage or induce any minor child to enter
in, frequent or remain therein.



(Ord. 201, passed 7-9-1946)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.058  LAWFUL EMPLOYMENT NOT PROHIBITED.



   This subchapter shall not be construed to prevent the lawful employment
of any minor child pursuant to the provisions of the laws of the state, now,
or which may hereafter become effective.



(Ord. 201, passed 7-9-1946)



§ 134.059  EXCEPTIONS.



   This shall not be construed to include within its purview any
restaurant, hotel or place of amusement, the principal business of lodging or
legitimate forms of amusement and wherein the service of spiritous or
intoxicating liquor is incidental thereto.



(Ord. 201, passed 7-9-1946)




SALE OF MODEL GLUE




§ 134.070  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   MODEL GLUE.  Any glue or cement of the type commonly used in the
building of model airplanes, boats and automobiles, containing toluene,
acetone or other solvent or chemical having the property of releasing toxic
vapors.



(Ord. 301, passed 8-10-1965)



§ 134.071  PROHIBITION AGAINST INHALATION.



   No person shall, for the purpose of causing a condition of
intoxication, euphoria, excitement, exhilaration, stupefaction or dulling of
the senses or nervous system, intentionally smell or inhale the fumes from
any model glue provided, however that this section  shall not apply to the
inhalation of any anesthesia for medical or dental purpose.



(Ord. 301, passed 8-10-1965)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.072  PROHIBITION AGAINST POSSESSION, BUYING, SELLING TRANSFERRING OR
RECEIVING POSSESSION.



   No person shall, for the purpose of violating or aiding another to
violate any provision of this subchapter, intentionally possess, buy, sell,
transfer possession or receive possession of any model glue.



(Ord. 301, passed 8-10-1965)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.073  EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   Except as provided in division (C) hereof and § 134.074, no
person under 21 years of age shall possess or buy any model glue.



   (B)   Except as provided in division (C) hereof and § 134.074, no
person shall sell or transfer. possession of any model glue to another person
under 21 years of age.



   (C)   Provided, however, a person may sell or transfer possession of
model glue to a person under 21 years of age for model building or other
lawful use where the minor has in his or her possession and exhibits the
written consent of his or her parent or guardian.



(Ord. 301, passed 8-10-1965)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.074  WRITTEN CONSENT.



   A person making a sale or transfer of possession of model glue to a
person under 21 years of age who exhibits the written consent of his or her
parent or guardian, shall record the name, address, sex and age of the minor
and the name and address of the consenting parent or guardian. All data
required by this section shall be kept in a permanent type register available
for inspection by the Police Department for a period of at least six months.



(Ord. 301, passed 8-10-1965)  Penalty, see § 134.999




MOVIE THEATERS




§ 134.100  PROHIBITING CHILDREN IN THEATERS AND OTHER PLACES OF AMUSEMENT.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any theater owner, moving picture
operator, theater licensee, operator, manager, employee, parent or guardian
to permit any child under the age of 16 years unaccompanied by a parent or
guardian or an adult in whose care or custody the parent or guardian has
placed the child, to remain in any theater, moving picture show or other
place of amusement within the city after the hour of 9:30 p.m.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any theater owner, moving picture
operator, theater license, operator, manager or employee to permit any male
minor under the age of 18 years or any female minor under the age of 21
years, to be admitted to or to be permitted to remain in any theater, moving
picture show or any other place of amusement within the city between the
hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. and it shall be unlawful for any male minor
under the age of 24 years to apply for admission or to remain in any theater,
moving picture show or any other place of amusement within the city between
the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any theater owner, moving picture
operator, theater licensee, operator, manager or employee, parent or guardian
to permit any child under the age of 16 years to remain in any theater,
moving picture show or other place of amusement within the city between the
hours of 8:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. except during school vacation periods and on
school vacation days.



(Ord. 168, passed 6-9-1938)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.101  NOTICE TO BE POSTED.



   Notice of the provisions of this subchapter shall be placed or posted
in a conspicuous place in the lobby of each theater.



(Ord. 168, passed 6-9-1938)



§ 134.102  EMPLOYMENT OF MINORS.



   No theater owner, moving picture operator, theater licensee, operator,
manager or employee, by himself, herself or another shall employ, engage or
otherwise permit employment, engagement or use any minor under the age of 16
years, as an employee, entertainer or any other capacity, in or about the
premises, provided, however, that so-called traveling road shows may engage
or employ a minor under the age of 17 years, provided the employment or
engagement is approved by the Department of Labor of the state, and provided
that minors under 17 years pursuing apprenticeship courses as part of their
training may be employed when the employment has the approval of the State
Labor Department and a permit issued by the Board of Education covering the
employment in the city.



(Ord. 168, passed 6-9-1938)



§ 134.103  ADMISSION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person other than a parent, guardian or an
adult person in whose care a parent or guardian has placed a child, to
purchase an admission ticket for a child or assist in any way whatsoever any
child to gain admittance into any theater where admittance is unlawful under
the terms of the provisions of this subchapter.



(Ord. 168, passed 6-9-1938)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.104  DUTY OF MANAGER OR OWNER.



   It shall be the duty of the manager or owner of any theater or motion
picture show to make a reasonable effort to see that the provisions of this
subchapter are carried out. By complying with the list of suggestions as
given in this section, any theater owner or manager shall have made his or
her contribution to the effectiveness of this subchapter.



   (A)   The theater schedule should be so arranged that a complete
show is finished before 9:30 p.m. 



   (B)   The theater should warn all children who seek to enter after
the feature picture has started that they will have to leave when the show is
completed.



   (C)   The theater should by, flashing a slide or running a trailer
notice on the screen (before lighting the theater) urge all children to leave
after the performance.



   (D)   The theater may be lighted for a period not less than one
minute at the end of the completed show sometime between 9:00 and 9:30 p. m.



   (E)   The theater should have its ushers see that children do not
remain in the theater after 9:30 p.m.



   (F)   The theater shall use reasonable judgment in deciding whether
or not a child is under 16 years of age.



(Ord. 168, passed 6-9-1938)  Penalty, see § 134.999




ABANDONED ICE BOXES AND REFRIGERATORS




§ 134.115  UNLAWFUL TO ABANDON IF IT CONTAINS AN AIR-TIGHT DOOR OR LOCK
WHICH MAY NOT BE RELEASED FOR OPENING FROM THE INSIDE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to leave
outside of a building or dwelling, in a place accessible to children, any
abandoned, unattended or discarded ice box, refrigerator or any other
container of any kind, which has an air-tight door or lock which may not be
released for opening from the inside of the ice box, refrigerator or
container.



(Ord. 233, passed 9-29-1953)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.116  REMOVAL OF AIR-TIGHT SNAP LOCK.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to leave
outside of any building or dwelling, in a place accessible to children any
abandoned, unattended or discarded ice box, refrigerator or any other
container of any kind which has an air-tight snap-lock or other device
thereon, without first removing the snap-lock or doors from the ice box,
refrigerator or container.



(Ord. 233, passed 9-29-1953)  Penalty, see § 134.999




STREET TRADES




§ 134.130  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the words STREET TRADE shall mean
the business, occupation, undertaking or pursuit of:



   (A)   Peddling;



   (B)   Boot blacking;



   (C)   Delivering goods, wares, merchandise, telegrams, newspapers,
magazines, periodicals, advertising matter or any other printed or written
material;



   (D)   Distributing, selling or offering for sale goods, wares,
merchandise, newspapers, magazines, periodicals, advertising matter or any
other printed or written material;



   (E)   Soliciting subscriptions for newspapers, magazines or
periodicals;



   (F)   Offering services for hire or gain when conducted in any
street, alley, park, square or other public place or in the lobby or entrance
of any building frequented by the public or conducted by house to house
canvassing; or



   (G)   Soliciting funds for the awarding of prizes by punch boards or
otherwise.



(Ord. 130, passed 1-4-1935)



§ 134.131  AGE LIMITATION.



   No male under 12 years of age and no female under 18 years of age shall
engage in any street trade.



(Ord. 130, passed 1-4-1935)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.132  PROHIBITION DURING SCHOOL HOURS.



   No person under 17 years of age shall engage in any street trade during
school hours, unless legally excused from school, as now and hereafter
provided by law. No person under the age of 17 shall engage in any street
trade between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., provided that on
Saturdays he or she may so engage until 10:00 p.m. and provided further that
any person under the age of 17 and over the age of 14 may deliver periodicals
or newspapers on a regularly established route to regular customers until
10:00 p.m. No person under the age of 17 years shall engage in any street
trade for a period longer than eight hours in any one day.



(Ord. 130, passed 1-4-1935)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.133  UNLAWFUL EMPLOYMENT.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, association, partnership,
corporation or organization to hire or employ or permit to be hired or
employed or suffer to work in any street trade any minor contrary to the
terms of this subchapter. No person, firm, association, partnership,
corporation or organization shall give, sell, deliver or consign any goods,
wares or merchandise including newspapers, magazines, periodicals,
advertising matter or any printed or written material to any minor for the
purpose of selling, distributing or delivering the same in any street trade
in violation of the terms of this subchapter. It shall be unlawful for any
parent, guardian or custodian to suffer, permit, allow or induce any minor to
engage in any street trade contrary to the provisions of this subchapter.



(Ord. 130, passed 1-4-1935)  Penalty, see § 134.999



§ 134.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Generally.  Any person violating any provision of this
chapter for which no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.999.



   (B)   Use of tobacco product by minors; prohibition.  A violation
of § 134.004 constitutes a municipal civil infraction, punishable by a fine
of $50 for the first offense and $100 for each additional offense within one
year.



(Ord. 478, passed 12-18-2001)



   (C)   Curfew.



      (1)   Any person over 17 years of age, any firm or corporation
violating the provisions of §§ 134.020 through 134.027 shall upon
conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not to exceed the sum of $500 or
imprisonment for a period not to exceed 90 days, or both a fine and
imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.



      (2)   Any minor under 17 years of age, subject to the
jurisdiction of the juvenile division of the probate court, shall be dealt
with in the manner prescribed by the laws of the state.



(Ord. 407, passed 7-26-1983)



   (D)   Sale of spray paint.  Any person violating any of the
provisions of §§ 134.040 through 134.042 upon conviction thereof, shall be
punished by a fine not to exceed $500 or imprisonment not to exceed 90 days
or both a fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 390, passed 3-25-1980)



   (E)   Sale of liquor.



      (1)   Any person who shall be in violation of any of the
provisions of §§ 134.055 and 134.056 shall upon conviction thereof be
subject to a fine not to exceed $500 or imprisonment for a period not to
exceed 90 days or both a fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the
court.



(Ord. 303, passed 8-24-1965)



      (2)   Any minor-child or other person willfully violating the
provisions of § 134.057 hereof shall be guilty of misdemeanor and upon
conviction be punished by a fine not to exceed $100 or by imprisonment in the
Wayne County Jail not to exceed 90 days or both a fine and imprisonment, in
the discretion of the court.



(Ord. 201, passed 7-9-1946)



   (F)   Sale of model glue.  Any person or minor over the age of 16
violating any provisions of §§ 134.070 through 134.074 shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction be punished by a fine not to
exceed $500 or by imprisonment in the Wayne County Jail not to exceed 90 days
or both a fine and imprisonment. Each day the violation is committed or
permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be
punishable as that hereunder. Any minor under the age of 17 years of age
violating any of the provisions of §§ 134.070 through 134.074 shall be
dealt with in accordance with juvenile court laws and procedures.



(Ord. 301, passed 8-10-1965)



   (G)   Movie theaters.  Any child who shall violate the provisions
of §§ 134.100 through 134.104 shall be considered as committing a
delinquent act. Any person over 17 years of age violating the provisions §§
134.100 through 134.104 shall have committed a misdemeanor and shall be
punished by a fine of not less than $10 nor more than $100 or imprisonment
for not less than ten days, nor more than 90 days, or both, in the discretion
of the court.



(Ord. 168, passed 6-9-1938)



   (H)   Abandoned ice boxes and refrigerators.  Any person, firm or
corporation violating any of the provisions of §§ 134.115 and 134.116 shall
be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined
not exceeding $100 or by imprisonment for not in excess of 90 days. Each day
the violation is committed or permitted to continue, shall constitute a
separate offense and shall be punishable as that thereunder.



(Ord. 233, passed 9-29-1953)



   (I)   Street trades.  Any person of the age of 17 years or more who
violates any of the provisions of §§ 134.130 through 134.133 shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, shall be punished by a fine of
not more than $100 or by imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or by both a
fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. Any child under the age
of 17 years who violated any of the provisions of §§ 134.130 through
134.133 shall be deemed a delinquent child and shall be dealt with as a
juvenile delinquent.



(Ord. 130, passed 1-4-1935; Am. Ord. 2010-5, passed 5-11-2010)



CHAPTER 135:  PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY



Section



   135.001   Title



   135.002   Statement of purpose



   135.003   Definitions



   135.004   Parental duties



   135.005   Notification



 



   135.999   Penalty



§ 135.001  TITLE.



   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the “Parental
Responsibility Chapter.”



(Ord. 2010-5, passed 5-11-2010)



§ 135.002  STATEMENT OF PURPOSE.



   By enacting this chapter the city requires a parent of a minor child to
exercise reasonable control over that child to prevent that child from
committing any delinquent act.



(Ord. 2010-5, passed 5-11-2010)



§ 135.003  DEFINITIONS.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE.  Any drug, substance or immediate precursor
included in Schedules 1 to 5 of Part 72 of the Michigan Public Health Code,
as amended.



   DELINQUENT ACT.  An act which violates the laws of the United States,
the laws of the State of Michigan, or an ordinance of the city, or which
would cause a minor to come under the jurisdiction of the Family Division of
the Circuit Court, as defined by M.C.L.A. 712A.2. as amended “Delinquent
act” does not include a traffic violation which is designated as a civil
infraction.



   MINOR.  Any unemancipated person under the age of 17.



   PARENT.  The mother, father, legal guardian and any other person
having the care of custody of a minor, or any person 17 years of age or older
with whom the minor resides, at the time that the delinquent act is alleged
to have been committed by the minor.



(Ord. 2010-5, passed 5-11-2010)



§ 135.004  PARENTAL DUTIES.



   (A)   It is the continuous duty of the parent of any minor to
exercise reasonable control to prevent the minor from committing any
delinquent act.



   (B)   No parent of any minor shall fail to exercise reasonable
parental control over the minor.  The exercise of reasonable parental
control shall include, but is not limited to, the following:



      (1)   Taking reasonable steps to insure that minors for whom
the Parent has responsibility do not commit delinquent acts.



      (2)   Keeping controlled substances out of the home and out of
the possession of the minor, except those drugs duly prescribed by a licensed
physician or other authorized medical professional.



      (3)    Keeping firearms out of the possession of the minor,
except those used for hunting in accordance with all applicable laws and
regulations and with the knowledge and supervision of a parent.



      (4)   Requiring the minor to observe the curfew ordinance of
the city.



      (5)   Requiring the minor to attend regular school sessions
and forbidding the minor to be absent from class without parental or school
permission.



      (6)   Arranging proper supervision for the minor when the
parent is absent.



      (7)   Forbidding the minor from willfully or maliciously
destroying property belonging to another person.



      (8)   Forbidding the minor from knowingly possessing stolen
property.



      (9)   Forbidding the minor from possessing alcoholic
beverages, and/or tobacco products.



      (10)   Seeking help from the appropriate governmental
authorities or private agencies in handling or controlling the minor when
necessary.



      (11)   Assisting or cooperating with governmental authorities
in their efforts to handle or control the minor, including the production of
the minor for court appointments and hearings.



(Ord. 2010-5, passed 5-11-2010)  Penalty, see § 135.999



§ 135.005  NOTIFICATION.



   Whenever a minor is arrested or detained for the commission of any
delinquent act within the city, the Police Department shall immediately
attempt to notify the parent of such arrest or detention, and the parent's
responsibility under this chapter.  A record of such notification efforts
shall be kept by the Police Department.



(Ord. 2010-5, passed 5-11-2010)



§ 135.999  PENALTY.



   Any person who shall be in violation of any of the provisions of §
135.004 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof be
subject to a fine not to exceed $500 or imprisonment for a period not to
exceed 90 days or both a fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the
court; the court may in its discretion, consider, as an alternative to the
levy of the above fine and imprisonment, disregard sentencing which may
include but not necessarily be limited to, community service, parenting
classes and/or any combination of like penalties.



(Ord. 2010-5, passed 5-11-2010)

CONSTRUCTION CODE




§ 150.001  TITLE.



   This subchapter shall be called the Construction Code Subchapter.



(Ord. 474, passed 4-20-2000)



§ 150.002  ADOPTION OF CODES.



   (A)   Pursuant to the provisions of the State Building, Electrical,
Mechanical and Plumbing Codes, in accordance with Public Act 230 of 1972, §
8(b)(6), being M.C.L.A. §§ 125.1501 through 125.1531, the Building,
Electrical, Mechanical and Plumbing Code official of the city is hereby
designated as the enforcing agency to discharge the responsibility of the
city under Public Act 230 of 1972, being M.C.L.A. §§ 125.1501 through
125.1531, State of Michigan.



   (B)   The city assumes responsibility for the administration and
enforcement of the Act throughout its corporate limits.



(Ord. 474, passed 4-20-2000; Am. Ord. 477, passed 10-5-2001)



§ 150.003  CONSTRUCTION BOARD OF APPEALS.



   (A)   Right of appeal; jurisdiction.  Pursuant to the provisions
and requirements or the codes adopted in § 150.002 above, the City
Construction Board or Appeals is hereby created and shall hear all appeals
taken from the Building, Mechanical, Plumbing and Electrical Codes, as
provided in the codes and other requirements of the State Construction Code
Act of 1972, Public Act 230 of 1972, being M.C.L.A. §§ 125.1501 through
125.1531.



   (B)   Construction Board of Appeals; appointment; term of office;
qualifications.  The Construction Board of Appeals shall consist of five
regular members and two alternate members who shall serve for a term of five
years pursuant to the adopted codes. Members of the Construction Board of
Appeals shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall be qualified by experience
and training to perform the duties of the Construction Board of Appeals and,
where required, registered in accordance with state law. A clerical person
appointed by the Civil Service Commission shall serve as the secretary to the
Construction Board of Appeals and shall file a detailed record of all
proceedings and decisions in the office of the City Clerk, and provide to the
appellant a copy of the procedures, under which the hearing will be
conducted, and a copy of the decision of the Construction Board of Appeals.



   (C)   Open Meetings Act; Freedom of Information Act.  The business
of the Construction Board of Appeals shall be conducted at public meetings
held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act, Public Act 267 of 1976, being
M.C.L.A. §§ 15.261 through 15.275. Public notice of the time, date and
place of the meeting shall be given in the manner required by the Open
Meetings Act. A record of decisions made by the Construction Board of
Appeals, properly indexed and any other writing prepared, owned, used, in the
possession of, or retained by the Construction Board of Appeals in the
performance of an official function shall be made available to the public in
compliance with the Freedom of Information Act, Public Act 422 of 1976, being
M.C.L.A. §§ 15.231 et seq.



   (D)   Fees.  The appellant shall pay a mandatory nonwaivable fee at
the time of filing an appeal to the City Treasurer before any appeal is
considered. The fee shall be established as provided in § 150.006. Unless
the applicant provides written notice of his or her intent to withdraw his or
her appeal at least 72 hours prior to the public meeting scheduled for that
purpose, the fee is nonrefundable.



   (E)   Compensation.  The City Council shall fix, by an annual
resolution, the amount of any per diem compensation provided to members of
the Construction Board of Appeals. The members shall request in writing to
the code official reimbursement for any actual and necessary expenses
incurred in connection with their duties as a member of the Construction
Board of Appeals. If the code official shall approve, he or she shall forward
the request to the City Controller.



(Ord. 474, passed 4-20-2000)  Penalty, see § 150.999



§ 150.004  CONTRACTOR REGISTRATION.



   (A)   Registration.  Residential builders, maintenance and
alteration contractors, plumbing, mechanical, electrical, alarm, awning or
sign contractors who are lawfully licensed by the state shall be permitted to
do work for which they are licensed in the city upon registering as a
contractor in the city limits upon payment of a fee provided by resolution or
ordinance of the City Council. A license holder must make the application.



   (B)   Term and issuance of registration.  All contractor
registrations issued by the city shall expire as provided by state law and in
accordance with division (A) above, which includes presentation of the
license and payment of the required fee.



(Ord. 474, passed 4-20-2000; Am. Ord. 482, passed 4-8-2002; Am. Ord. 484,
passed 5-30-2002)



§ 150.005  VEHICLE IDENTIFICATION.



   (A)   Identification required.  No person engaged in any
construction or work regulated under this section and subchapter shall
operate a truck or commercial vehicle upon the streets and highways of the
city unless the name and address of the person or business operating the
vehicle is displayed conspicuously on the outside of the commercial vehicle.



   (B)   Definition.  For the purpose of this section, the following
definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.



      COMMERCIAL VEHICLE.  All motor vehicles used for the
transportation of employees, goods, services and ware including vehicles
designed to tow other vehicles. Vehicles belonging to employees of
contractors and used only for personal transportation to a job site, shall
not be included.



(Ord. 474, passed 4-20-2000)  Penalty, see § 150.999



§ 150.006  FEES.



   (A)   Schedule of fees.  The City Council, shall by resolution or
ordinance, establish reasonable fees to be charged by the city for acts and
services performed by the code official or his or her duly authorized
representative, the Construction Board of Appeals, the Plan Commission and
the Zoning Board of Appeals. The fees shall be intended to bear a reasonable
relation to the cost, including overhead, to the city for the acts and
services, including, without limitation in case of the city, issuance of
building permits, examination of plans and specifications, inspection of
construction undertaken pursuant to a building permit and the issuance of
certificate of use and occupancy, and in the case of the Construction and
Zoning Boards of Appeals, hearing appeals in accordance with law and
ordinances of this city.



   (B)   Fees; effective.  Fees authorized by resolution or ordinance,
unless specifically set forth in a dollar amount within the resolution or
ordinance, shall be effective upon publication in a newspaper having general
circulation in the city.



(Ord. 474, passed 4-20-2000)



§ 150.007  APPLICATION OF BUILDING PERMIT; AVAILABILITY UNDER FREEDOM OF
INFORMATION ACT; COMPLIANCE WITH ZONING.



   (A)   Application; form; contents.  Except as otherwise provided by
ordinance adopting a nationally recognized code pursuant to Public Act 230 of
1972, being M.C.L.A. §§ 125.1501 through 125.1531, before commencing any
construction of, or in, a building or structure, the owner or owner’s
agent, shall submit an application in writing to the Division for a building
permit. A site plan showing the dimensions, and the location of the proposed
building or structure and other buildings or structures on the same premises,
shall be submitted with the application. The application shall contain the
full  name and complete address, by street and number, of the owner(s) in
fee of the premises on which the building or structure will be used. If
construction is proposed to be undertaken by a person other than the owner,
the statement shall also contain the full name and complete address, by
street and number, of the person proposing the construction. The owner, or
the owner’s attorney, agent, engineer, architect or builder may make the
application. A person shall not be recognized as the agent, attorney,
engineer, architect or builder of another person unless the person files with
the Division a written instrument, which could be an architectural,
engineering or construction contract, power of attorney or a notarized letter
of authorization signed by the owner designating the person as the agent,
attorney, architect, engineer or builder and, in case of a builder, setting
forth the builder’s state license number.
